◆ ks_eval_rf_hard_optimal_duration()

STATUS ks_eval_rf_hard_optimal_duration ( KS_RF *  rf,
const char *const  desc,
int  order,
float  flip,
float  offsetFreq 
)

Sets up a KS_RF object with a rectangular (hard) pulse with optimal duration for fat selection/saturation

This function creates a hard RF pulse with optimal duration for fat selection/saturation. Hard pulses are typically used as non-slice selective RF pulses. Their slice profile is sinc-like and with this function you can create a hard pulse with a sinc-minima at the center of the spectral fat-peak. You can select wich minima using the input 'order'. A higher order generates a longer pulse duration with a more narrow frequency response. If the pulse is tuned to the fat peak, using input 'offsetFreq', the minimia will instead end up at the water-peak. The resolution of the RF pulse created is equal to the duration/2

Parameters
[out]rfKS_RF object to be created
[in]descA description (text string) of the KS_RF object. This description is used for pulse sequence generation (seen in the file generated by TimeHist in MGD Sim/WTools)
[in]orderSelect wich minima to use
[in]flipNominal flip angle of the RF pulse
[in]offsetFreqchoose center frequency offset
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1206  {
1207 
1208  if (order < 1) {
1209  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf_hard(%s): 'order' (%d, 3rd arg) must be positive", desc, order);
1210  }
1211 
1212  int duration = RUP_FACTOR((int)(1000000.0 * sqrt(pow(2.0 * PI * (float)order, 2) - pow((float)flip * (PI / 180.0), 2)) / fabs(2.0 * PI * offsetFreq)), GRAD_UPDATE_TIME);
1213 
1214  return ks_eval_rf_hard(rf, desc, duration, flip);
1215 
1216 }
ks_error
STATUS ks_error(const char *format,...) __attribute__((format(printf
Common error message function for HOST and TGT
ks_eval_rf_hard
STATUS ks_eval_rf_hard(KS_RF *rf, const char *const desc, int duration, float flip)
Sets up a KS_RF object with a rectangular (hard) pulse of a given duration.
Definition: KSFoundation_host.c:1153

◆ ks_eval_rf_binomial()

STATUS ks_eval_rf_binomial ( KS_RF *  rf,
const char *const  desc,
int  offResExc,
int  nPulses,
float  flip,
float  offsetFreq 
)

Sets up a KS_RF object as a Binomial RF pulse

This function creates a binomial RF pulse, which consists of a series of hard pulses. Binomial pulses are used for spectral selection. They utilize the difference in resonance frequency of different tissue types, such as water and fat. Increasing the number of sub-pulses will improve the spectral selectivity but also increse the pulse duration.

Parameters
[out]rfKS_RF object to be created
[in]descA description (text string) of the KS_RF object. This description is used for pulse sequence generation (seen in the file generated by TimeHist in MGD Sim/WTools)
[in]offResExcIf 0 the pulse will excite the spinns at the center frequency, If 1 the pulse will excite the spinns at the offset frequency (given by input: offsetFreq)
[in]nPulsesNumber of sub-pulses
[in]flipNominal flip angle of the RF pulse
[in]offsetFreqchoose center frequency offset in Hz
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1219  {
1220  KS_DESCRIPTION tmpdesc;
1221  int i, j;
1222 
1223  /* Don't allow empty description or a description with leading space */
1224  if (desc == NULL || desc[0] == ' ') {
1225  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf_binomial: RF name (2nd arg) cannot be NULL or leading space");
1226  }
1227  strncpy(tmpdesc, desc, KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH/2);
1228  tmpdesc[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH/2] = 0;
1229 
1230  /* Reset RF object */
1231  ks_init_rf(rf);
1232 
1233  /* Fill in wave object */
1234  sprintf(rf->rfwave.description, "%s.wave", tmpdesc);
1235 
1236  if (offResExc < 0 || offResExc > 1) {
1237  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf_hard(%s): 'offResExc' (3rd arg) must be either 0 or 1", rf->rfwave.description);
1238  }
1239  if (nPulses < 2 || nPulses > 10) {
1240  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf_hard(%s): 'nPulses' (4th arg) must be in range [2, 10]", rf->rfwave.description);
1241  }
1242 
1243  int pascalstriangle[9][10] = { {1,1},
1244  {1,2,1},
1245  {1,3,3,1},
1246  {1,4,6,4,1},
1247  {1,5,10,10,5,1},
1248  {1,6,15,20,15,6,1},
1249  {1,7,21,35,35,21,7,1},
1250  {1,8,28,56,70,56,28,8,1},
1251  {1,9,36,84,126,126,84,36,9,1} };
1252 
1253  int P[10];
1254  int pulseSum = 0;
1255  for (i = 0; i < nPulses; i++) {
1256  P[i] = pascalstriangle[nPulses - 2][i];
1257  pulseSum += P[i];
1258  }
1259 
1260  /* Calculate subpulse separation */
1261  float tau = fabs(1.0 / (2.0 * offsetFreq)); /* sec */
1262 
1263  /* Calculate number of samples so that each subpulse is as close as possible to maxB1, without exceeding it */
1264  float maxB1 = 0.20; /* Gauss */
1265  float pulseArea = (float) flip * (PI / 180.0); /* radians or Hz (depending on how you look at it) */
1266  float dt = RF_UPDATE_TIME / 1000000.0; /* sec */
1267  float subArea[10];
1268  int ntp[10];
1269  for (i = 0; i < nPulses; i++) {
1270  subArea[i] = (P[i] * pulseArea) / (pulseSum * 2.0 * PI * GAM); /* Gauss * sec */
1271  ntp[i] = ceil(subArea[i] / (maxB1 * dt)); /* number of time points in sub pulse */
1272  if (ntp[i] < 4 ) {
1273  ntp[i] = 4;
1274  }
1275  }
1276 
1277  int idx = 0;
1278  for (i = 0; i < nPulses; i++) {
1279 
1280  /* Calculate how much we have to attenuate this pulse
1281  to account for the fact that with this dwell time
1282  we couldn't hit the target flip exactly */
1283  float currentSubArea = ntp[i] * dt * maxB1; /* Gauss * sec */
1284  float amp = maxB1 * (subArea[i] / currentSubArea); /* Gauss */
1285 
1286  /* Flip every other sub pulse for off resonace excitaion */
1287  if (offResExc) {
1288  /* make sure the second center sub-pulse flips in the right direction */
1289  amp *= pow(-1.0, (float)(i + nPulses/2 % 2));
1290  }
1291 
1292  /* Stitch on the sub pulse */
1293  for (j = 0; j < ntp[i]; j++) {
1294  rf->rfwave.waveform[idx] = amp;
1295  idx++;
1296  }
1297 
1298  /* Stitch on the gap, skip for last sub pulse */
1299  if (i < nPulses - 1) {
1300  int ntp_gap = ceil(tau / dt - (float)ntp[i] / 2.0 - (float)ntp[i + 1] / 2.0);
1301  for (j = 0; j < ntp_gap; j++) {
1302  rf->rfwave.waveform[idx] = 0.0;
1303  idx++;
1304  }
1305  }
1306  }
1307 
1308  /* Make sure the resolution is divisible by 2 and the duration divisible by 4 */
1309  rf->rfwave.res = RUP_FACTOR(idx, 4);
1310  rf->rfwave.duration = rf->rfwave.res * RF_UPDATE_TIME;
1311  rf->iso2end = rf->rfwave.duration / 2;
1312  rf->start2iso = rf->rfwave.duration / 2;
1313  rf->bw = 0; /* ? */
1314  rf->flip = flip;
1315 
1316  /* If the resolution has been rounded up, place zeros at the end */
1317  for (j = idx; j < rf->rfwave.res; j++) {
1318  rf->rfwave.waveform[j] = 0.0;
1319  }
1320 
1321  /* Normalize waveform to one */
1322  ks_wave_multiplyval(&rf->rfwave, 1.0 / ks_wave_absmax(&rf->rfwave));
1323 
1324  /* Initialize amplitude to one */
1325  rf->amp = 1;
1326 
1327  /* Set the usage of the RF PULSE to off until .base.ninst > 0 (see ks_pg_rf() on HOST) */
1328  rf->rfpulse.activity = PSD_PULSE_OFF;
1329 
1330  /* Never allow binomial RF pulses to be stretched. We can avoid this by always setting extgradfile = 1 (even if this is not the case) */
1331  rf->rfpulse.extgradfile = 1;
1332 
1333  /* Initialize number of occurrences of RF pulse to zero */
1334  rf->rfpulse.num = 0;
1335 
1336  /* Save original waveform to fool rfstat, with abs(waveform) */
1337  float *saveWave = alloca(rf->rfwave.res * sizeof(float));
1338  if (offResExc) {
1339  memcpy(saveWave, rf->rfwave.waveform, rf->rfwave.res * sizeof(float));
1340  for (j = 0; j < rf->rfwave.res; j++) {
1341  rf->rfwave.waveform[j] = fabs(rf->rfwave.waveform[j]);
1342  }
1343  }
1344 
1345  /* Setup rfpulse structure */
1346  STATUS status = ks_eval_rfstat(rf);
1347  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1348 
1349  /* Put back the correct waveform */
1350  if (offResExc) {
1351  memcpy(rf->rfwave.waveform, saveWave, rf->rfwave.res * sizeof(float));
1352  }
1353 
1354  return SUCCESS;
1355 
1356 }
KS_RF::start2iso
int start2iso
Definition: KSFoundation.h:793
KS_RF::rfpulse
RF_PULSE rfpulse
Definition: KSFoundation.h:797
ks_error
STATUS ks_error(const char *format,...) __attribute__((format(printf
Common error message function for HOST and TGT
GAM
float GAM
KS_RF::flip
float flip
Definition: KSFoundation.h:789
ks_wave_absmax
float ks_wave_absmax(const KS_WAVE *wave)
Returns the maximum absolute value in a KS_WAVE sequence object
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:986
KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH
#define KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH
Definition: KSFoundation.h:112
ks_init_rf
void ks_init_rf(KS_RF *rf)
Resets a KS_RF sequence object to its default value (KS_INIT_RF)
Definition: KSFoundation_host.c:57
KS_WAVE::description
KS_DESCRIPTION description
Definition: KSFoundation.h:516
ks_eval_rfstat
STATUS ks_eval_rfstat(KS_RF *rf)
Sets up the RF_PULSE structure of a KS_RF object
Definition: KSFoundation_host.c:1359
KS_RF::rfwave
KS_WAVE rfwave
Definition: KSFoundation.h:798
KS_RF::amp
float amp
Definition: KSFoundation.h:792
KS_RF::iso2end
int iso2end
Definition: KSFoundation.h:794
maxB1
float maxB1[MAX_ENTRY_POINTS]
Definition: GERequired.e:260
KS_DESCRIPTION
char KS_DESCRIPTION[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH]
Definition: KSFoundation.h:178
KS_WAVE::res
int res
Definition: KSFoundation.h:517
ks_wave_multiplyval
void ks_wave_multiplyval(KS_WAVE *wave, float val)
In-place scalar multiplication of a KS_WAVE
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:1135
KS_WAVE::waveform
KS_WAVEFORM waveform
Definition: KSFoundation.h:519
KS_WAVE::duration
int duration
Definition: KSFoundation.h:518
KS_RF::bw
float bw
Definition: KSFoundation.h:790

◆ ks_eval_rfstat()

STATUS ks_eval_rfstat ( KS_RF *  rf)

Sets up the RF_PULSE structure of a KS_RF object

For RF scaling, SAR calculation, and RF heating calculations, GE uses a global array of RF_PULSE structs, where each RF pulse is associated with one RF_PULSE struct each. This struct array contains RF pulses from Prescan as well as the pulse sequence itself, and is normally declared in a grad_rf_<psd>.h file.

Here, each KS_RF object has its own RF_PULSE struct (the field .rfpulse), which this function sets up. The following fields in the KS_RF object must be set before calling this ks_eval_rfstat()

  1. .rfwave: Must contain the RF pulse waveform. An error is return if either .thetawave or .omegawave are non-empty (complex RF pulses not allowed)
  2. .bw: The bandwidth of the RF pulse [Hz]
  3. .iso2end: Time from the magnetic center of the RF pulse to the end, in [us]
  4. .flip: The flip angle of the RF pulse [degrees]. In this function, .flip will set .rfpulse.nom_fa and make sure .rfpulse.act_fa points to .flip

The RF waveform will be amplitude scaled so that its maximum absolute amplitude is 1.0 before making the calculations. Also the proper links between fields int the .rfpulse (RF_PULSE) struct and the parent fields in KS_RF are set up by calling ks_eval_rf_relink()

Credits: This function has been made largely after the code by Atsushi Takahashi, GE Healthcare.

Parameters
[in,out]rfKS_RF object to calculate the RF_PULSE parameters for (in field .rfpulse)
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1359  {
1360  double standard_pw = 1e-3;
1361 
1362  double nRFenvelope;
1363  int indx;
1364 
1365  double area = 0.0;
1366  double abswidth = 0.0;
1367  double effwidth = 0.0;
1368  double dtycyc = 0.0;
1369  double max_pw = 0.0;
1370  double max_b1 = 0.0;
1371  double max_int_b1_sq = 0.0;
1372  double max_rms_b1 = 0.0;
1373 
1374 
1375  if (rf->thetawave.res > 0 || rf->omegawave.res > 0) {
1376  return ks_error("ks_eval_rfstat(%s): function is not validated for phase/frequency modulated RF-pulses", rf->rfwave.description);
1377  }
1378  /* require fields 'duration', 'isodelay' and 'bw' to be set to realistic values */
1379  if (rf->rfwave.duration < 4 || rf->rfwave.duration > KS_MAXWAVELEN * RF_UPDATE_TIME || rf->rfwave.duration % 2) {
1380  return ks_error("ks_eval_rfstat: 'rf.rfwave.duration' (%d) must be an even number in the range [4,%d] us", rf->rfwave.duration, KS_MAXWAVELEN * RF_UPDATE_TIME);
1381  }
1382  if (rf->bw < 0 || rf->bw > 100000) {
1383  return ks_error("ks_eval_rfstat: 'rf.bw' (%f) must be in the range [0,100000] Hz", rf->bw);
1384  }
1385  if (rf->iso2end < 0 || rf->iso2end > KS_MAXWAVELEN * RF_UPDATE_TIME) {
1386  return ks_error("ks_eval_rfstat: 'rf.iso2end' (%d) must be in the range [0,%d] us", rf->iso2end, KS_MAXWAVELEN * RF_UPDATE_TIME);
1387  }
1388  if (rf->flip < 0.0 || rf->flip > 10000.0) {
1389  return ks_error("ks_eval_rfstat: 'rf.flip' (%.2f) must be in the range [0,3000] deg", rf->flip);
1390  }
1391  /* for reference, see: /ESE_xxxxx/psd/include/private/sar_pm.h */
1392 
1393  /* normalize RF just in case */
1394  ks_wave_multiplyval(&rf->rfwave, 1.0 / ks_wave_absmax(&rf->rfwave));
1395 
1396 
1397  for (indx = 0; indx < rf->rfwave.res; indx++) {
1398  nRFenvelope = rf->rfwave.waveform[indx];
1399  area += nRFenvelope;
1400  abswidth += fabs(nRFenvelope);
1401  effwidth += (nRFenvelope * nRFenvelope);
1402 
1403  /* dtycyc: % of Pulse Widths above 5% power */
1404  if (fabs(nRFenvelope) > 0.05)
1405  dtycyc++;
1406  }
1407 
1408  area /= rf->rfwave.res;
1409  abswidth /= rf->rfwave.res;
1410  effwidth /= rf->rfwave.res;
1411  dtycyc /= rf->rfwave.res;
1412 
1413  /* max_pw: % of the pulse width whose widest lobe is above 5% power
1414  GE uses max_pw = dtycyc for most pulses (sar_pm.h)
1415  Neither max_pw nor dtycyc seem to match well with the values used in GEs product sequences unlike
1416  the other fields, which seems to agree within a few percent */
1417  max_pw = dtycyc;
1418 
1419  max_b1 = rf->flip / 360.0 / (area * (rf->rfwave.duration) * 1e-6) / GAM;
1420  max_int_b1_sq = max_b1 * max_b1 * effwidth * (rf->rfwave.duration) * 1e-6 / standard_pw;
1421  max_rms_b1 = sqrt(max_int_b1_sq / ((rf->rfwave.duration) * 1e-6) * standard_pw);
1422 
1423 
1424  ks_eval_rf_relink(rf);
1425 
1426  rf->rfpulse.abswidth = abswidth;
1427  rf->rfpulse.effwidth = effwidth;
1428  rf->rfpulse.area = area;
1429  rf->rfpulse.dtycyc = dtycyc;
1430  rf->rfpulse.maxpw = max_pw;
1431  rf->rfpulse.num = 0;
1432  rf->rfpulse.max_b1 = max_b1;
1433  rf->rfpulse.max_int_b1_sq = max_int_b1_sq;
1434  rf->rfpulse.max_rms_b1 = max_rms_b1;
1435  rf->rfpulse.nom_fa = rf->flip; /* nom_fa and act_fa are equal */
1436  rf->rfpulse.nom_pw = rf->rfwave.duration;
1437  rf->rfpulse.nom_bw = rf->bw;
1438  rf->rfpulse.activity = PSD_PULSE_OFF; /* is set to PSD_SCAN_ON by ks_pg_rf() */
1439  rf->rfpulse.reference = 0;
1440  rf->rfpulse.isodelay = rf->iso2end;
1441  rf->rfpulse.scale = 1.0;
1442  if (rf->rfpulse.extgradfile != 1) {
1443  rf->rfpulse.extgradfile = 0; /* Only allow 0 or 1. Disallows RF pulse stretching if 1 */
1444  }
1445 
1446  return SUCCESS;
1447 }

◆ ks_eval_rf()

STATUS ks_eval_rf ( KS_RF *  rf,
const char *const  desc 
)

Sets up a KS_RF object

See documentation for the KS_RF object for details on how to prepare the KS_RF object before calling ks_eval_rf()

This function does not set up a KS_RF object by itself, merely it peforms final validation, naming, makes sure fields and links in KS_RF are properly set up. ks_eval_rf() should be called for non-slice selective RF pulses. For slice-selective RF pulses, use KS_SELRF and call ks_eval_selrf() instead

Parameters
[in,out]rfPointer to the KS_RF object to be set up
[in]descA description (text string) of the KS_RF object. This description is used for pulse sequence generation (seen in the file generated by TimeHist in MGD Sim/WTools)
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1451  {
1452 
1453  if (desc == NULL || desc[0] == ' ') {
1454  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf: description (2nd arg) cannot be NULL or begin with a space");
1455  } else {
1456  strncpy(rf->rfwave.description, desc, KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH / 2); /* truncate after half max # chars to allow for suffixes */
1457  }
1458 
1459  ks_eval_rf_relink(rf);
1460 
1461  if (rf->role <= KS_RF_ROLE_NOTSET || rf->role > KS_RF_ROLE_INV) {
1462  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf(%s): 'rf.role' is not set or is invalid", desc);
1463  }
1464  if (rf->flip <= 0.0 || rf->flip > 10000.0) {
1465  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf(%s): 'rf.flip' (%.2f) must be in the range (0,3000] deg", desc, rf->flip);
1466  }
1467  if (rf->bw < 0 || rf->bw > 100000) {
1468  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf(%s): 'rf.bw' (%.2f) must be in the range [0,100000]", desc, rf->bw);
1469  }
1470  /* check that RF duration is even */
1471  if (rf->rfwave.duration % 2)
1472  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf (%s): RF duration (%d) [us] must be even", rf->rfwave.description, rf->rfwave.duration);
1473 
1474  /* check that RF duration and optional THETA / OMEGA waveforms have same duration */
1475  if (rf->omegawave.res) {
1476  sprintf(rf->omegawave.description, "%s", rf->rfwave.description); /* suffix '.x' is added automatically in ks_pg_wave(), where 'x' is the 1st letter of the board */
1477  if (rf->rfwave.duration != rf->omegawave.duration)
1478  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf (%s): OMEGA duration (%d) [us] must equal RF duration (%d) [us]", rf->rfwave.description, rf->omegawave.duration, rf->rfwave.duration);
1479  }
1480  if (rf->thetawave.res) {
1481  sprintf(rf->thetawave.description, "%s", rf->rfwave.description);
1482  if (rf->rfwave.duration != rf->thetawave.duration)
1483  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf (%s): THETA duration (%d) [us] must equal RF duration (%d) [us]", rf->rfwave.description, rf->thetawave.duration, rf->rfwave.duration);
1484  }
1485 
1486  if (rf->iso2end < 0 || rf->iso2end > rf->rfwave.duration) {
1487  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf (%s): 'rf.iso2end (%d) must in range [0,%d] [us]", rf->rfwave.description, rf->iso2end, rf->rfwave.duration);
1488  }
1489 
1490  /* check that .iso2end is equal to .rfpulse.isodelay */
1491  if (rf->rfpulse.isodelay != rf->iso2end) {
1492  return ks_error("ks_eval_rf (%s): 'rf.rfpulse.isodelay (%d) must be equal to 'rf.iso2end' (%d) [us]", rf->rfwave.description, rf->rfpulse.isodelay, rf->iso2end);
1493  }
1494 
1495  rf->rfpulse.isodelay = RUP_GRD(rf->rfpulse.isodelay); /* Round up using RUP_GRD() to fall on gradient raster (GRAD_UPDATE_TIME = 4us) */
1496  rf->iso2end = rf->rfpulse.isodelay;
1497  rf->start2iso = rf->rfwave.duration - rf->iso2end; /* time from start of RF pulse to its magnetic center */
1498 
1499  /* initialize amplitude to 1 */
1500  rf->amp = 1;
1501 
1502  /* set the usage of the RF PULSE to off until .base.ninst > 0 (see ks_pg_rf() on HOST) */
1503  rf->rfpulse.activity = PSD_PULSE_OFF;
1504 
1505  /* initialize number of occurrences of RF pulse to zero */
1506  rf->rfpulse.num = 0;
1507 
1508 
1509  return SUCCESS;
1510 
1511 } /* ks_eval_rf */
KS_RF::start2iso
int start2iso
Definition: KSFoundation.h:793

◆ ks_eval_rf_relink()

void ks_eval_rf_relink ( KS_RF *  rf)

(Internal use) Relinks pointers between fields in a KS_RF object

This function is used by other RF functions to make sure that the links from pointers in .rfpulse are relinked to other fields inside the KS_RF object. This function does not need to be called manually as long as either ks_eval_rf(), ks_eval_selrf() are called.

If a KS_RF object is copied to another KS_RF object by simple assignment ('=' sign), then these pointers must be updated before the assigned KS_RF object can be used. Best practice is to call ks_eval_rf() or ks_eval_selrf() instead of this function, as more validation is performed and because description of the new KS_RF is also updated

Parameters
[in,out]rfPointer to the KS_RF object to be set up
1515  {
1516 
1517  /* link as required by RF_PULSE */
1518  rf->rfpulse.pw = &(rf->rfwave.duration);
1519  rf->rfpulse.amp = &(rf->amp);
1520  rf->rfpulse.act_fa = &(rf->flip);
1521  rf->rfpulse.res = &(rf->rfwave.res);
1522  rf->rfpulse.exciter = &ks_rhoboard;
1523 }
ks_rhoboard
int ks_rhoboard
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:46

RF_PULSE rfpulse
Definition: KSFoundation.h:797
KS_RF::flip
float flip
Definition: KSFoundation.h:789

KS_RF::amp

◆ ks_eval_stretch_rf()

STATUS ks_eval_stretch_rf ( KS_RF *  rf,
float  stretch_factor 
)

In-place stretching of a KS_RF object

This function takes a KS_RF object already set up, having some resolution (rfwave.res), bandwidth (.bw), duration (rfwave.duration) and waveform (.rfwave.waveform) and performs a linear interpolation of the waveform contained in .rfwave.waveform so its new duration becomes

newDuration = oldDuration * stretch_factor

  • Note that regardless of the input resolution of the waveform, the output resolution will always be newDuration/2.
  • The description of the stretched KS_RF object (.rfwave.description) is updated with a suffix stretched
  • The fields .start2iso, .iso2end and .bw are automatically updated to reflect the new duration
Parameters
[in,out]rfPointer to the KS_RF object to be stretched
[in]stretch_factorStretch factor (float) that widens/shortens the RF pulse if larger/smaller than 1.0. If negative, the RF waveform will be mirrored (in time)
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
2171  {
2172 
2173  STATUS status;
2174  int idx;
2175  int debug = 0;
2176  int mirror_rfpulse = 0;
2177 
2178  if (stretch_factor == 1.0) {
2179  return SUCCESS;
2180  }
2181 
2182  mirror_rfpulse = (stretch_factor < 0); /* we are going to mirror the RF pulse after stretching */
2183  stretch_factor = fabsf(stretch_factor);
2184 
2185  if (stretch_factor < FLT_EPSILON) {
2186  return ks_error("%s: can not stretch by %f", __FUNCTION__, stretch_factor);
2187  }
2188 
2189  /* get original duration/resolution and calculate new duration/resolution */
2190  int orgDur = rf->rfwave.duration;
2191  int newDur = RUP_GRD((int)(orgDur * stretch_factor));
2192  int orgRes = rf->rfwave.res;
2193  int newRes = newDur/RF_UPDATE_TIME;
2194 
2195  /* create index for interpolation */
2196  float *orgGrid = alloca(orgRes * sizeof(float));
2197  float *newGrid = alloca(newRes * sizeof(float));
2198  for (idx = 0; idx < orgRes; idx++) {
2199  orgGrid[idx] = (float) idx / (orgRes-1);
2200  }
2201  for (idx = 0; idx < newRes; idx++) {
2202  newGrid[idx] = (float) idx / (newRes-1);
2203  }
2204 
2205  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(rf->rfwave.waveform, "stretch_orgrf.txt", orgRes); }
2206 
2207  /* perform linear interpolation */
2208  ks_eval_linear_interp1(orgGrid, orgRes, rf->rfwave.waveform, newGrid, newRes, rf->rfwave.waveform);
2209 
2210  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(rf->rfwave.waveform, "stretch_newrf.txt", newRes); }
2211 
2212  /* set new duration, resolution and bandwidth */
2213  rf->rfwave.duration = newDur;
2214  rf->rfwave.res = newRes;
2215  rf->bw *= ((float)orgDur/newDur);
2216  rf->rfpulse.isodelay = RUP_FACTOR((int)(rf->rfpulse.isodelay * stretch_factor),RF_UPDATE_TIME);
2217  rf->iso2end = rf->rfpulse.isodelay;
2218  rf->start2iso = rf->rfwave.duration - rf->iso2end;
2219 
2220  if (mirror_rfpulse) {
2221  rf->iso2end = rf->start2iso; /* N.B.: start2iso will be updated again in ks_eval_rf() */
2222  rf->rfpulse.isodelay = rf->start2iso;
2223  ks_eval_mirrorwave(&rf->rfwave);
2224  ks_eval_mirrorwave(&rf->thetawave);
2225  ks_eval_mirrorwave(&rf->omegawave);
2226  }
2227 
2228  char description[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH];
2229  sprintf(description, "%s_stretched", rf->rfwave.description);
2230  status = ks_eval_rf(rf, description);
2231  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
2232 
2233  status = ks_eval_rfstat(rf);
2234  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
2235 
2236  return SUCCESS;
2237 } /* EOF */
ks_print_waveform
void ks_print_waveform(const KS_WAVEFORM waveform, char *filename, int res)
Writes a KS_WAVEFORM to disk with the specified filename

◆ ks_eval_seltrap()

STATUS ks_eval_seltrap ( KS_TRAP *  trap,
const char *const  desc,
float  slewrate,
float  slthick,
float  bw,
int  rfduration 
)

(Internal use) Sets up a trapezoid for RF slice selection

This function is used by ks_eval_selrf_constrained() (and its wrapper functions, e.g. ks_eval_selrf()), and there is no need to use this function directly.

Based on the RF bandwidth and duration, this function will create a trapezoid gradient that with this type of RF pulse creates a slice with the desired thickness, by in turn calling ks_calc_selgradamp().

Parameters
[out]trapPointer to the KS_TRAP object to be set up
[in]descA description (text string) of the KS_PHASER object. This description is used for pulse sequence generation (seen in the file generated by TimeHist in MGD Sim/WTools)
[in]slewrateThe maximum allowed slewrate ([(G/cm) / us]). Value of 0.01 corresponds to 100 mT/m/s
[in]slthickThe desired slice thickness in [mm]. If = 0, the slice selection gradient will have zero amplitude (hard pulses)
[in]bwThe bandwidth of the RF pulse to use with the gradient. If = 0, the slice selection gradient will have zero amplitude (hard pulses)
[in]rfdurationThe duration of the RF pulse to use with the gradient
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1533  {
1534 
1535  /* Reset all fields and waveforms */
1536  ks_init_trap(trap);
1537 
1538  if ((rfduration < GRAD_UPDATE_TIME) || (rfduration % GRAD_UPDATE_TIME)) {
1539  return ks_error("%s: RF duration must be positive and divisible by 4", __FUNCTION__);
1540  }
1541 
1542  if (slthick < 0 || bw < 0) {
1543  /* N.B.: slthick may be exactly 0, in which case a zero amp gradient is created */
1544  return ks_error("%s: slice thickness & bandwidth cannot be negative", __FUNCTION__);
1545  }
1546 
1547  if (desc == NULL || desc[0] == ' ') {
1548  return ks_error("ks_eval_seltrap: trap name (2nd arg) cannot be NULL or begin with a space");
1549  }
1550 
1551  strncpy(trap->description, desc, KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH - 1);
1552 
1553  trap->amp = ks_calc_selgradamp(bw, slthick); /* amp [G/cm] */
1554 
1555  trap->ramptime = RUP_GRD((int) (trap->amp / slewrate)); /* ramp time [us] */
1556 
1557  if (trap->ramptime <= 0) {
1558  trap->ramptime = 4;
1559  }
1560 
1561  trap->plateautime = rfduration; /* plateau time [us] */
1562  trap->duration = trap->plateautime + 2 * trap->ramptime; /* total duration [us] */
1563  trap->area = (trap->plateautime + trap->ramptime) * trap->amp;
1564 
1565 
1566  return SUCCESS;
1567 
1568 }
KS_TRAP::plateautime
int plateautime
Definition: KSFoundation.h:436
ks_error
STATUS ks_error(const char *format,...) __attribute__((format(printf
Common error message function for HOST and TGT
ks_init_trap
void ks_init_trap(KS_TRAP *trap)
Resets a KS_TRAP sequence object to its default value (KS_INIT_TRAP)
Definition: KSFoundation_host.c:45
KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH
#define KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH
Definition: KSFoundation.h:112
KS_TRAP::area
float area
Definition: KSFoundation.h:434
KS_TRAP::amp
float amp
Definition: KSFoundation.h:433
KS_TRAP::description
KS_DESCRIPTION description
Definition: KSFoundation.h:432
ks_calc_selgradamp
float ks_calc_selgradamp(float rfbw, float slthick)
Returns the gradient amplitude in [G/cm] necessary for slice selection (internal use)
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:242
KS_TRAP::duration
int duration
Definition: KSFoundation.h:437
KS_TRAP::ramptime
int ramptime
Definition: KSFoundation.h:435

◆ ks_eval_selrf_constrained()

STATUS ks_eval_selrf_constrained ( KS_SELRF *  selrf,
const char *const  desc,
float  ampmax,
float  slewrate 
)

Sets up a KS_SELRF object for RF slice selection, subject to gradients constraints specified as input arguments

This function does not set up the KS_RF field in KS_SELRF itself, see KS_RF and ks_eval_rf() for more details on how to prepare the .rf field in KS_SELRF before calling ks_eval_selrf_constrained()

The following fields in the KS_SELRF object must be set up before calling this function:

  1. A ready KS_RF object, with a proper .rf.role (see below for details)
  2. .slthick: Slice thickness in [mm]. Note that the slice thickness often needs to be made larger to compensate from slice narrowing due to multiple RF pulses. GE uses usually gscale_rfX CVs with values often between 0.8-0.9. Dividing with this number gives a thicker slice in the calculations. NOTE: .slthick = 0 is accepted and results in zero gradient amplitude with minimal 4us ramps and a plateautime = .rf.rfwave.duration (cf. ks_eval_seltrap()->ks_calc_selgradamp())

ks_eval_selrf_constrained() checks .rf.role to decide on how to set up its gradient objects. The following values of .rf.role are allowed:

  • KS_RF_ROLE_EXC, indicating an RF excitation role. ks_eval_selrf_constrained() will in this case:
    • disable .pregrad
    • make .grad.plateautime equal to the RF duration (.rf.rfwave.duration) and the gradient amplitude (.grad.amp [G/cm]) will be set to the proper value depending on the BW (.rf.bw) and slice thickness (.slthick). The field .grad.description will have a ".trap" suffix added to it
    • make .postgrad to have a gradient area that rephases the slice. This is dependent on the isodelay of the RF pulse (.rf.iso2end) and the slice select gradient amplitude (.grad.amp). The field .postgrad.description will have a ".reph" suffix added to it
  • KS_RF_ROLE_REF, indicating an RF refocusing role. ks_eval_selrf_constrained() will in this case:
    • use .pregrad to make the left crusher (never bridged with slice selection). The size of the crusher can be controlled by .crusherscale. The field .pregrad.description will have a ".LC" suffix added to it
    • do the same with .grad as done for KS_RF_ROLE_EXC
    • use .postgrad to make the right crusher (never bridged with slice selection). The size of the crusher can be controlled by .crusherscale. The field .postgrad.description will have a ".RC" suffix added to it
  • KS_RF_ROLE_INV, indicating an RF inversion role. ks_eval_selrf_constrained() will in this case:
    • disable .pregrad
    • do the same with .grad as done for KS_RF_ROLE_EXC
    • disable .postgrad
  • KS_RF_ROLE_SPSAT, indicating a spatial RF saturation. ks_eval_selrf_constrained() will in this case:
    • disable .pregrad
    • do the same with .grad as done for KS_RF_ROLE_EXC
    • use .postgrad to make a gradient spoiler (never bridged with slice selection). The size of the spoiler can be controlled by .crusherscale. The field .postgrad.description will have a ".spoiler" suffix added to it

The role KS_RF_ROLE_CHEMSAT, indicates a non-slice selective, chemically selective, RF (usually fat-sat). ks_eval_selrf_constrained() will in this case throw an error since no gradients should be used

There are three wrapper functions to this function (ks_eval_selrf(), ks_eval_selrf1(), ks_eval_selrf2()) that have reduced number of input arguments, and calls ks_eval_selrf_constrained() with different preset gradient constraints. ks_eval_selrf() makes fewest assumptions, making it the most general choice.

Using a custom gradient wave for slice selection (.gradwave)

To support e.g. VERSEd RF excitations, a custom gradient wave can be used. If .gradwave.res > 0, ks_eval_selrf_constrained() will disable .grad and use .gradwave instead. When .rf.role = KS_RF_ROLE_EXC, the rephasing gradient area (in .postgrad) will be calculated by integrating the gradient waveform from the RF isocenter to the end. .gradwave must be created before calling ks_eval_selrf_constrained() using either ks_eval_wave() or ks_eval_wave_file(), and the units must be in [G/cm]. To further scale the amplitude of .gradwave before calling ks_eval_selrf_constrained(), consider e.g. ks_wave_multiplyval(), ks_wave_absmax(), and possibly ks_wave_addval()

Parameters
[in,out]selrfPointer to the KS_SELRF object to be set up
[in]descA description (text string) of the KS_SELRF object. This description is used for pulse sequence generation (seen in the file generated by TimeHist in MGD Sim/WTools)
[in]ampmaxThe maximum allowed gradient amplitude ([G/cm])
[in]slewrateThe maximum allowed slewrate ([(G/cm) / us]). Value of 0.01 corresponds to 100 mT/m/s
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1571  {
1572  char selname[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH], preselname[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH], postselname[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH];
1573  float minthick;
1574  float standard_crusherarea = 2000.0;
1575  STATUS status;
1576 
1577  if (desc == NULL || desc[0] == ' ') {
1578  return ks_error("%s: description (2nd arg) cannot be NULL or begin with a space", __FUNCTION__);
1579  }
1580 
1581  /* setup the RF pulse */
1582  status = ks_eval_rf(&selrf->rf, desc);
1583  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1584 
1585  /* with slice selection (trap or gradwave), the RF duration must be divisible by GRAD_UPDATE_TIME (4) [us] */
1586  if ((selrf->rf.rfwave.duration < 4) || (selrf->rf.rfwave.duration % 4)) {
1587  return ks_error("%s (%s): RF duration (%d) must be divisible by GRAD_UPDATE_TIME (4)", __FUNCTION__, desc, selrf->rf.rfwave.duration);
1588  }
1589 
1590  /* init members of selrf to their default state */
1591  ks_init_trap(&selrf->pregrad);
1592  ks_init_trap(&selrf->grad);
1593  ks_init_trap(&selrf->postgrad);
1594  ks_init_sms_info(&selrf->sms_info);
1595 
1596  /* Slice thickness */
1597  /* protect against e.g. +/-Inf thicknesses. Note that we do *NOT* complain about slthick = 0. This is OK and means zero amp dummy gradient */
1598  if (selrf->slthick < 0 || selrf->slthick > 600) {
1599  return ks_error("%s (%s): Thickness not in range [0,600] mm", __FUNCTION__, desc);
1600  }
1601 
1602  minthick = selrf->rf.bw / (ampmax * (0.1) * GAM);
1603  if (selrf->slthick > 0 && selrf->slthick < minthick) {
1604  /* N.B.: checking for slthick > 0 above, allows slthick = 0 without leaading to this error (meaning no slice sel amp) */
1605  return ks_error("%s (%s): Minimum thickness (%.1f [mm]) violated", __FUNCTION__, desc, minthick);
1606  }
1607 
1608  /* if we have a gradwave generated, check that it has the same duration as the rfpulse */
1609  if (selrf->gradwave.res) {
1610  if (selrf->gradwave.duration != selrf->rf.rfwave.duration) {
1611  return ks_error("%s (%s): Custom gradient wave duration (%d) must equal the RF duration (%d)", __FUNCTION__, desc, selrf->gradwave.duration, selrf->rf.rfwave.duration);
1612  }
1613  if (selrf->gradwave.duration % selrf->gradwave.res) {
1614  return ks_error("%s (%s): Custom gradient wave duration (%d) must be divisible by res (%d)", __FUNCTION__, desc, selrf->gradwave.duration, selrf->gradwave.res);
1615  }
1616  sprintf(selrf->gradwave.description, "%s.gradwave", selrf->rf.rfwave.description); /* suffix '.x' is added automatically in ks_pg_wave(), where 'x' is the 1st letter of the board */
1617  }
1618 
1619  /* Setup the gradients (trapezoid case) */
1620  sprintf(selname, "%s.trap", selrf->rf.rfwave.description); /* suffix '.x' is added automatically in ks_pg_wave(), where 'x' is the 1st letter of the board */
1621 
1622  /* slice select */
1623  if (selrf->gradwave.res == 0) {
1624  /* slice select using trapezoid (.grad). If selrf->slthick = 0 or selrf->rf.bw = 0, a zero amp gradient will be created to make consistent KS_SELRF
1625  This is facilitated by ks_eval_seltrap()->ks_calc_selgradamp() */
1626  status = ks_eval_seltrap(&selrf->grad, selname, slewrate, selrf->slthick, selrf->rf.bw, selrf->rf.rfwave.duration);
1627  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1628  } else {
1629  if (selrf->gradwave.gradwave_units == KS_GRADWAVE_RELATIVE) {
1630  /* slice select using existing custom waveform (.gradwave) - scaling gradwave amplitude correctly regardless of current amplitude
1631  assumes that the maximum absolute value in gradwave.waveform corresponds to the gradient amplitude intended for the current rf BW and slthick */
1632  float maxval = ks_wave_max(&selrf->gradwave); /* not absmax, but max, to allow for larger negative lobes for e.g. flyback SPSP */
1633  if (maxval <= 0) {
1634  /* a gradwave that is strictly below zero, normalize instead by absmax */
1635  maxval = fabs(ks_wave_min(&selrf->gradwave));
1636  }
1637  ks_wave_multiplyval(&selrf->gradwave, ks_calc_selgradamp(selrf->rf.bw, selrf->slthick) / maxval);
1638 
1639  } else if (selrf->gradwave.gradwave_units == KS_NOTSET) {
1640  return ks_error("%s (%s): Custom gradient wave scaling policy not set", __FUNCTION__, desc);
1641  }
1642  }
1643 
1644 
1645  switch (selrf->rf.role) {
1646 
1647  /********************************************************************************/
1648  /*********************** RF SEL EXCITATION **************************************/
1649  /********************************************************************************/
1650  case KS_RF_ROLE_EXC:
1651 
1652  sprintf(postselname, "%s.reph", selrf->rf.rfwave.description);
1653 
1654  if (selrf->gradwave.res == 0) { /* Slice selection using .grad (KS_TRAP) */
1655 
1656  /* area needed for rephaser */
1657  selrf->postgrad.area = -(selrf->rf.rfpulse.isodelay + selrf->grad.ramptime / 2) * selrf->grad.amp;
1658 
1659  } else { /* Slice selection using .gradwave (KS_WAVE) */
1660 
1661  int i, isostart;
1662  int grad_dwell = selrf->gradwave.duration / selrf->gradwave.res;
1663 
1664  /* rephaser area needed for gradient wave */
1665  selrf->postgrad.area = 0;
1666  if (selrf->rf.iso2end_subpulse != KS_NOTSET) {
1667  /* SPSP's subpulses may be linear, min or max phase pulses, not neccesarily
1668  centered on the plateau of each lobe. For these pulses, the iso2end_subpulse field
1669  is not KS_NOTSET (-1). One can also have self-rephased gradwaves, not needing
1670  a .postgrad. In this case rf.iso2end_subpulse = 0 would disable this, while keeping
1671  rf.iso2end for TE calculations */
1672  isostart = (selrf->gradwave.duration - selrf->rf.iso2end_subpulse) / grad_dwell;
1673  } else {
1674  isostart = (selrf->gradwave.duration - selrf->rf.iso2end) / grad_dwell;
1675  }
1676  for (i = isostart; i < selrf->gradwave.res; i++) {
1677  selrf->postgrad.area -= selrf->gradwave.waveform[i] * grad_dwell;
1678  }
1679 
1680  }
1681 
1682  /* setup rephaser trapezoid */
1683  status = ks_eval_trap_constrained(&selrf->postgrad, postselname, ampmax, slewrate, 0);
1684  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1685 
1686  break;
1687  /********************************************************************************/
1688  /*********************** RF SEL REFOCUSING **************************************/
1689  /********************************************************************************/
1690  case KS_RF_ROLE_REF:
1691 
1692  selrf->pregrad.area = standard_crusherarea * selrf->crusherscale;
1693  selrf->postgrad.area = standard_crusherarea * selrf->crusherscale;
1694 
1695  sprintf(preselname, "%s.LC", selrf->rf.rfwave.description);
1696  sprintf(postselname, "%s.RC", selrf->rf.rfwave.description);
1697 
1698  status = ks_eval_trap_constrained(&selrf->pregrad, preselname, ampmax, slewrate, 0);
1699  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1700  status = ks_eval_trap_constrained(&selrf->postgrad, postselname, ampmax, slewrate, 0);
1701  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1702 
1703  break;
1704  /********************************************************************************/
1705  /*********************** RF SEL INVERSION ***************************************/
1706  /********************************************************************************/
1707  case KS_RF_ROLE_INV:
1708 
1709  /* nothing to do for pregrad or postgrad */
1710 
1711  break;
1712  /********************************************************************************/
1713  /*********************** RF SPATIAL SATURATION **********************************/
1714  /********************************************************************************/
1715  case KS_RF_ROLE_SPSAT:
1716 
1717  selrf->postgrad.area = standard_crusherarea * selrf->crusherscale;
1718 
1719  sprintf(postselname, "%s.spoiler", selrf->rf.rfwave.description);
1720 
1721  status = ks_eval_trap_constrained(&selrf->postgrad, postselname, ampmax, slewrate, 0);
1722  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1723 
1724  break;
1725  /********************************************************************************/
1726  /********************************************************************************/
1727  /********************************************************************************/
1728  default:
1729  return ks_error("ks_eval_selrf(%s): RF role must be one of: KS_RF_ROLE_EXC, KS_RF_ROLE_REF, KS_RF_ROLE_INV, KS_RF_ROLE_SPSAT", desc);
1730  break;
1731 
1732  } /* role */
1733 
1734 
1735 
1736  /********************************************************************************/
1737  /*********************** Validation *********************************************/
1738  /********************************************************************************/
1739 
1740  if (selrf->gradwave.res) { /* custom gradient wave */
1741  float mostfavorable_gradmax = FMax(3, loggrd.tx, loggrd.ty, loggrd.tz);
1742 
1743  if (ks_wave_absmax(&selrf->gradwave) > mostfavorable_gradmax) {
1744  return ks_error("ks_eval_selrf(%s): too large gradient amplitude for 'gradwave'", desc);
1745  }
1746 
1747  } else { /* standard trapezoid */
1748 
1749  /* timing check: grad vs. RF */
1750  if (selrf->grad.duration && selrf->grad.plateautime != selrf->rf.rfwave.duration) {
1751  return ks_error("ks_eval_selrf(%s): grad.plateautime (%d) != rf.rfwave.duration (%d)", desc, selrf->grad.plateautime, selrf->rf.rfwave.duration);
1752  }
1753 
1754  /* gradient duration divisibility check */
1755  if (selrf->grad.duration % GRAD_UPDATE_TIME) {
1756  return ks_error("ks_eval_selrf(%s): grad.duration (%d) must be divisible by 4 [us]", desc, selrf->grad.duration);
1757  }
1758 
1759  }
1760 
1761  return SUCCESS;
1762 
1763 } /* ks_eval_selrf_constrained */
KS_TRAP::plateautime
int plateautime
Definition: KSFoundation.h:436
KS_SELRF::grad
KS_TRAP grad
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1340
KS_RF::iso2end_subpulse
int iso2end_subpulse
Definition: KSFoundation.h:795
KS_NOTSET
#define KS_NOTSET
Definition: KSFoundation.h:60

Definition: KSFoundation.h:797

ks_calc_selgradamp

Returns the gradient amplitude in [G/cm] necessary for slice selection (internal use)

KS_SELRF::slthick

◆ ks_eval_selrf()

STATUS ks_eval_selrf ( KS_SELRF *  selrf,
const char *const  desc 
)

Sets up a KS_SELRF object for RF slice selection with preset gradient constraints

This is a wrapper function to ks_eval_selrf_constrained() with gradient constraints set to allow this KS_SELRF to be played on any axis while other gradients (set up with the same constraints) can be played out on the other two gradient boards, for any slice angulation. This is the generic and safest configuration, but for thin slices and high RF BWs, the gradient limits may be reached, especially for double oblique slices

See ks_eval_selrf_constrained() for details on fields that need to be set before calling this function

Parameters
[in,out]selrfPointer to the KS_SELRF object to be set up
[in]descA description (text string) of the KS_SELRF object. This description is used for pulse sequence generation (seen in the file generated by TimeHist in MGD Sim/WTools)
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1767  {
1768 
1769  return ks_eval_selrf_constrained(selrf, desc, ks_syslimits_ampmax(loggrd), ks_syslimits_slewrate(loggrd));
1770 
1771 }
ks_syslimits_ampmax
float ks_syslimits_ampmax(LOG_GRAD loggrd)
Returns the maximum gradient amplitude that can be used on all gradient boards simultaneously
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:163
ks_eval_selrf_constrained
STATUS ks_eval_selrf_constrained(KS_SELRF *selrf, const char *const desc, float ampmax, float slewrate)
Sets up a KS_SELRF object for RF slice selection, subject to gradients constraints specified as input...
Definition: KSFoundation_host.c:1571
loggrd
LOG_GRAD loggrd
ks_syslimits_slewrate
float ks_syslimits_slewrate(LOG_GRAD loggrd)
Returns the maximum slewrate that can be used on all gradient boards simultaneously
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:196

◆ ks_eval_selrf2()

STATUS ks_eval_selrf2 ( KS_SELRF *  selrf,
const char *const  desc 
)

Sets up a KS_SELRF object for RF slice selection with preset gradient constraints

This is a wrapper function to ks_eval_selrf_constrained() with gradient constraints set to allow this KS_SELRF to be played on any axis while one more gradient (set up with the same constraints) can be played out on another gradient board, for any slice angulation. For double oblique slice angulations, this function will allow for thinner slices and higher RF BWs than ks_eval_selrf()

See ks_eval_selrf_constrained() for details on fields that need to be set before calling this function

Parameters
[in,out]selrfPointer to the KS_SELRF object to be set up
[in]descA description (text string) of the KS_SELRF object. This description is used for pulse sequence generation (seen in the file generated by TimeHist in MGD Sim/WTools)
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1773  {
1774 
1775  return ks_eval_selrf_constrained(selrf, desc, ks_syslimits_ampmax2(loggrd), ks_syslimits_slewrate2(loggrd));
1776 
1777 }
ks_eval_selrf_constrained
STATUS ks_eval_selrf_constrained(KS_SELRF *selrf, const char *const desc, float ampmax, float slewrate)
Sets up a KS_SELRF object for RF slice selection, subject to gradients constraints specified as input...
Definition: KSFoundation_host.c:1571
loggrd
LOG_GRAD loggrd
ks_syslimits_ampmax2
float ks_syslimits_ampmax2(LOG_GRAD loggrd)
Returns the maximum gradient amplitude that can be used on two gradient boards simultaneously
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:167
ks_syslimits_slewrate2
float ks_syslimits_slewrate2(LOG_GRAD loggrd)
Returns the maximum slewrate that can be used on two gradient boards simultaneously
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:200

◆ ks_eval_selrf1()

STATUS ks_eval_selrf1 ( KS_SELRF *  selrf,
const char *const  desc 
)

Sets up a KS_SELRF object for RF slice selection with preset gradient constraints

This is a wrapper function to ks_eval_selrf_constrained() with gradient constraints set to allow this KS_SELRF to be played on any axis, as long as no other gradients are be played out simultaneously. For double oblique slice angulations, this function will allow for thinner slices and higher RF BWs than ks_eval_selrf() and ks_eval_selrf2()

See ks_eval_selrf_constrained() for details on fields that need to be set before calling this function

Parameters
[in,out]selrfPointer to the KS_SELRF object to be set up
[in]descA description (text string) of the KS_SELRF object. This description is used for pulse sequence generation (seen in the file generated by TimeHist in MGD Sim/WTools)
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1779  {
1780 
1781  return ks_eval_selrf_constrained(selrf, desc, ks_syslimits_ampmax1(loggrd), ks_syslimits_slewrate1(loggrd));
1782 
1783 }
ks_eval_selrf_constrained
STATUS ks_eval_selrf_constrained(KS_SELRF *selrf, const char *const desc, float ampmax, float slewrate)
Sets up a KS_SELRF object for RF slice selection, subject to gradients constraints specified as input...
Definition: KSFoundation_host.c:1571
ks_syslimits_slewrate1
float ks_syslimits_slewrate1(LOG_GRAD loggrd)
Returns the maximum slewrate that can be used on one gradient board at a time
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:204
loggrd
LOG_GRAD loggrd
ks_syslimits_ampmax1
float ks_syslimits_ampmax1(LOG_GRAD loggrd)
Returns the maximum gradient amplitude that can be used on all gradient boards simultaneously
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:171

◆ ks_eval_sms_get_phase_modulation()

STATUS ks_eval_sms_get_phase_modulation ( float *  sms_phase_modulation,
const int  sms_multiband_factor,
const int  sms_phase_modulation_mode 
)

Sets up an array with values for phase modulation between slices in a multi-band (MB) RF

Parameters
[out]sms_phase_modulationArray with phase modulation between slices in a MB RF
[in]sms_multiband_factorThe multi-band acceleration factor
[in]sms_phase_modulation_modeSee ks_enum_smstype for options
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
2054  {
2055  /*
2056  % Return optimal phases for phase-modulated or amplitude-modulated low-peak power multiband pulses.
2057  %
2058  % sms_phase_modulation: Optimal phases
2059  % sms_multiband_factor: Number of bands
2060  % sms_phase_modulation_mode: phasmod, amplmod, or quadmod
2061  %
2062  % Adopted for EPIC from Will Grissom's (Vanderbilt University, 2015) MATLAB code by Ola Norbeck (Karolinska Unviversity Hospital, 2015).
2063  */
2064 
2065  int jdx;
2066 
2067  if (sms_phase_modulation_mode == KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_PHAS) {
2068 
2069  /* Wong's sms_phase_modulation: From E C Wong, ISMRM 2012, p. 2209 */
2070 
2071  if ((sms_multiband_factor < 2) || (sms_multiband_factor > 16)) {
2072  return ks_error("ks_eval_sms_get_phase_modulation: multiband factor (%d, 2nd arg) must be in range [2,16] for Wong's sms_phase_modulation", sms_multiband_factor);
2073  }
2074 
2075  float P[15][16] = {
2076  /* mbf = 2 */ {0.0, 0.0}, /* alt.{0.0, 3.142} */
2077  /* mbf = 3 */ {0.0, 0.730, 4.602},
2078  /* mbf = 4 */ {0.0, 3.875, 5.940, 6.197},
2079  /* mbf = 5 */ {0.0, 3.778, 5.335, 0.872, 0.471},
2080  /* mbf = 6 */ {0.0, 2.005, 1.674, 5.012, 5.736, 4.123},
2081  /* mbf = 7 */ {0.0, 3.002, 5.998, 5.909, 2.624, 2.528, 2.440},
2082  /* mbf = 8 */ {0.0, 1.036, 3.414, 3.778, 3.215, 1.756, 4.555, 2.467},
2083  /* mbf = 9 */ {0.0, 1.250, 1.783, 3.558, 0.739, 3.319, 1.296, 0.521, 5.332},
2084  /* mbf = 10 */ {0.0, 4.418, 2.360, 0.677, 2.253, 3.472, 3.040, 3.974, 1.192, 2.510},
2085  /* mbf = 11 */ {0.0, 5.041, 4.285, 3.001, 5.765, 4.295, 0.056, 4.213, 6.040, 1.078, 2.759},
2086  /* mbf = 12 */ {0.0, 2.755, 5.491, 4.447, 0.231, 2.499, 3.539, 2.931, 2.759, 5.376, 4.554, 3.479},
2087  /* mbf = 13 */ {0.0, 0.603, 0.009, 4.179, 4.361, 4.837, 0.816, 5.995, 4.150, 0.417, 1.520, 4.517, 1.729},
2088  /* mbf = 14 */ {0.0, 3.997, 0.830, 5.712, 3.838, 0.084, 1.685, 5.328, 0.237, 0.506, 1.356, 4.025, 4.483, 4.084},
2089  /* mbf = 15 */ {0.0, 4.126, 2.266, 0.957, 4.603, 0.815, 3.475, 0.977, 1.449, 1.192, 0.148, 0.939, 2.531, 3.612, 4.801},
2090  /* mbf = 16 */ {0.0, 4.359, 3.510, 4.410, 1.750, 3.357, 2.061, 5.948, 3.000, 2.822, 0.627, 2.768, 3.875, 4.173, 4.224, 5.941}
2091  };
2092 
2093  for (jdx = 0; jdx < sms_multiband_factor; jdx++ ) {
2094  sms_phase_modulation[jdx] = P[sms_multiband_factor - 2][jdx];
2095  }
2096 
2097  } else if (sms_phase_modulation_mode == KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_AMPL) {
2098 
2099  /* Seada's Hermitian sms_phase_modulation: From Seada et. al. Optimized Amplitude Modulated Multiband RF Pulse Design. MRM 2017 */
2100 
2101  if ((sms_multiband_factor < 3) || (sms_multiband_factor > 12)) {
2102  return ks_error("ks_eval_sms_get_phase_modulation: multiband factor (%d, 2nd arg) must be in range [3,12] for Seada's Hermitian sms_phase_modulation", sms_multiband_factor);
2103  }
2104 
2105  float P[10][12] = {
2106  /* mbf = 3 */ {1.2846, 0.0000, -1.2846},
2107  /* mbf = 4 */ {0.9739, 1.3718, -1.3718, -0.9739},
2108  /* mbf = 5 */ {1.1572, -0.9931, 0.0000, 0.9931, -1.1572},
2109  /* mbf = 6 */ {1.6912, 2.8117, 1.1572, -1.1572, -2.8117, -1.6912},
2110  /* mbf = 7 */ {2.5813, -0.5620, 0.1030, 0.0000, -0.1030, 0.5620, -2.5813},
2111  /* mbf = 8 */ {2.1118, 0.2199, 1.4643, 1.9914, -1.9914, -1.4643, -0.2199, -2.1118},
2112  /* mbf = 9 */ {0.4800, -2.6669, -0.6458, -0.4189, 0.0000, 0.4189, 0.6458, 2.6669, -0.4800},
2113  /* mbf = 10 */ {1.6825, -2.3946, 2.9130, 0.3037, 0.7365, -0.7365, -0.3037, -2.9130, 2.3946, -1.6825},
2114  /* mbf = 11 */ {1.4050, 0.8866, -1.8535, 0.0698, -1.4940, 0.0000, 1.4940, -0.0698, 1.8535, -0.8866, -1.4050},
2115  /* mbf = 12 */ {1.7296, 0.4433, 0.7208, 2.1904, -2.1956, 0.9844, -0.9844, 2.1956, -2.1904, -0.7208, -0.4433, -1.7296}
2116  };
2117 
2118  for (jdx = 0; jdx < sms_multiband_factor; jdx++ ) {
2119  sms_phase_modulation[jdx] = P[sms_multiband_factor - 3][jdx];
2120  }
2121 
2122 
2123  } else if (sms_phase_modulation_mode == KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_QUAD) {
2124 
2125  /* Grissom's quadratic sms_phase_modulation (unpublished) */
2126 
2127  for (jdx = 0; jdx < sms_multiband_factor; jdx++) {
2128  sms_phase_modulation[jdx] = pow( (3.4 / sms_multiband_factor) * (float)(1.0 + (float)jdx - ((float)sms_multiband_factor / 2.0) - 0.5), 2.0); /* sms_phase_modulation for each band */
2129  }
2130 
2131  } else {
2132 
2133  return ks_error("ks_eval_sms_get_phase_modulation: sms_phase_modulation_mode (%d, 3rd arg) is of unrecognized type. Choose phasmod = 1, amplmod = 2, or quadmod = 3", sms_phase_modulation_mode);
2134 
2135  }; /* end of if */
2136 
2137  return SUCCESS;
2138 
2139 } /* EOF */
KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_PHAS
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1766
ks_error
STATUS ks_error(const char *format,...) __attribute__((format(printf
Common error message function for HOST and TGT
KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_AMPL
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1767
KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_QUAD
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1768

◆ ks_eval_findb1()

float ks_eval_findb1 ( KS_SELRF *  selrf,
float  max_b1,
double  scaleFactor,
int  sms_multiband_factor,
int  sms_phase_modulation_mode,
float  sms_slice_gap 
)

Finds a stretch factor leading to the specified peak B1

Parameters
[in]selrfrf object KS_SELRF
[in]max_b1peak B1
[in]scaleFactorinitial stretch factor
[in]sms_multiband_factorSMS factor
[in]sms_phase_modulation_modeSMS phase modulation mode
[in]sms_slice_gapSMS slice gap
Returns
float stretch factor
1787  {
1788 
1789  STATUS status;
1790  float curr_b1 = 0.0;
1791  int debug = 0;
1792  double stepDown = 1.01;
1793  double stepUp = 1.05;
1794 
1795  /* Init tmp rf object */
1796  KS_SELRF selrftmp;
1797  ks_init_selrf(&selrftmp);
1798 
1799  /* Make the RF-pulse longer until its B1 peak is under its target */
1800  do {
1801  selrftmp = *selrf;
1802  ks_eval_stretch_rf(&selrftmp.rf, scaleFactor);
1803  status = ks_eval_selrf(&selrftmp, "tmp+");
1804  if (status == FAILURE) {continue;}
1805  if (sms_multiband_factor > 1) {
1806  status = ks_eval_sms_make_multiband(&selrftmp, &selrftmp, sms_multiband_factor, sms_phase_modulation_mode, sms_slice_gap, 0);
1807  } else {
1808  status = ks_eval_rfstat(&selrftmp.rf);
1809  }
1810  if (status == FAILURE) {continue;}
1811  curr_b1 = selrftmp.rf.rfpulse.max_b1;
1812  scaleFactor *= stepUp;
1813  if (debug) {ks_dbg("+ scaleFactor=%f, currB1=%f, maxB1=%f", scaleFactor, curr_b1, max_b1);}
1814  }
1815  while (fabs(curr_b1) > max_b1);
1816  scaleFactor /= stepUp;
1817 
1818  /* Make the RF-pulse shorter until its B1 peak hits its target */
1819  while ((fabs(curr_b1) < max_b1) && (scaleFactor > 0)) {
1820  selrftmp = *selrf;
1821  ks_eval_stretch_rf(&selrftmp.rf, scaleFactor);
1822  status = ks_eval_selrf(&selrftmp, "tmp-");
1823  if (status == FAILURE) {break;}
1824  if (sms_multiband_factor > 1) {
1825  status = ks_eval_sms_make_multiband(&selrftmp, &selrftmp, sms_multiband_factor, sms_phase_modulation_mode, sms_slice_gap, 0);
1826  } else {
1827  status = ks_eval_rfstat(&selrftmp.rf);
1828  }
1829  if (status == FAILURE) {break;}
1830  curr_b1 = selrftmp.rf.rfpulse.max_b1;
1831  scaleFactor /= stepDown;
1832  if (debug) {ks_dbg("- scaleFactor=%f, currB1=%f, maxB1=%f", scaleFactor, curr_b1, max_b1);}
1833  }
1834  scaleFactor *= stepDown;
1835 
1836  return scaleFactor;
1837 }
ks_init_selrf
void ks_init_selrf(KS_SELRF *selrf)
Resets a KS_SELRF sequence object to its default value (KS_INIT_SELRF)

Sets up the RF_PULSE structure of a KS_RF object

ks_eval_sms_make_multiband

In-place stretching of a KS_RF object

◆ ks_eval_sms_make_multiband()

STATUS ks_eval_sms_make_multiband ( KS_SELRF *  selrfMB,
const KS_SELRF *  selrf,
const int  sms_multiband_factor,
const int  sms_phase_modulation_mode,
const float  sms_slice_gap,
int  debug 
)

Creates a SMS (simultaneous-multi-slice) version of a KS_SELRF object

Parameters
[out]selrfMBPointer to multiband (SMS) KS_SELRF object
[in]selrfThe original (single-band) KS_SELRF object (set up using ks_eval_selrf())
[in]sms_multiband_factorThe multi-band acceleration factor
[in]sms_phase_modulation_modeSee ks_enum_smstype for options
[in]sms_slice_gapSlice gap in [mm] for the selrfMB pulse
[in]debugDebug flag for writing out text files (SIM: in current dir HW:/usr/g/mrraw/kstmp)
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1841  {
1842 /*
1843 %
1844 */
1845  int jdx, idx, kdx;
1846  float sms_phase_modulation[16] = KS_INITZEROS(16);
1847  STATUS status;
1848 
1849  /* Debug stuff */
1850  int single_band_mode = -1;
1851  char fname[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 14];
1852  char outputdir_uid[250];
1853  FILE *asciiWaveReal;
1854  FILE *asciiWaveImag;
1855  FILE *asciiWaveRealMB;
1856  FILE *asciiWaveImagMB;
1857  FILE *asciiWaveRealMod;
1858  FILE *asciiWaveImagMod;
1859  FILE *asciiWaveParams;
1860 
1861  if (debug) {
1862 
1863 #ifdef SIM
1864  sprintf(outputdir_uid, "./");
1865 #else
1866  char cmd[250];
1867  sprintf(outputdir_uid, "/usr/g/mrraw/kstmp/%010d/", rhkacq_uid);
1868  sprintf(cmd, "mkdir -p %s > /dev/null", outputdir_uid);
1869  system(cmd);
1870 #endif
1871 
1872  sprintf(fname, "%s%s_mb_rf_Real.txt", outputdir_uid, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description);
1873  asciiWaveReal = fopen(fname,"w");
1874  sprintf(fname, "%s%s_mb_rf_Imag.txt", outputdir_uid, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description);
1875  asciiWaveImag = fopen(fname,"w");
1876  sprintf(fname, "%s%s_mb_rfMB_Real.txt", outputdir_uid, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description);
1877  asciiWaveRealMB = fopen(fname,"w");
1878  sprintf(fname, "%s%s_mb_rfMB_Imag.txt", outputdir_uid, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description);
1879  asciiWaveImagMB = fopen(fname,"w");
1880  sprintf(fname, "%s%s_mod_rfMB_Real.txt", outputdir_uid, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description);
1881  asciiWaveRealMod = fopen(fname,"w");
1882  sprintf(fname, "%s%s_mod_rfMB_Imag.txt", outputdir_uid, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description);
1883  asciiWaveImagMod = fopen(fname,"w");
1884  }
1885 
1886  /* Check if gradient is present */
1887  if (selrf->grad.amp == 0){
1888  return ks_error("ks_eval_sms_make_multiband: Need a pre calculated gradient amp (2nd arg. selrf->grad.amp = %g)", selrf->grad.amp);
1889  }
1890 
1891  /* Duplicate the selRF structure */
1892  if (selrfMB != selrf ) {
1893  *selrfMB = *selrf;
1894  }
1895 
1896  /* Set info struct */
1897  selrfMB->sms_info.mb_factor = sms_multiband_factor;
1898  selrfMB->sms_info.slice_gap = sms_slice_gap;
1899  selrfMB->sms_info.pulse_type = KS_SELRF_SMS_MB;
1900 
1901  /* Save max b1 to make sure it does not get overwritten */
1902  double base_rf_max_amp = ks_waveform_absmax(selrf->rf.rfwave.waveform, ks_wave_res(&selrf->rf.rfwave));
1903 
1904  /* Get phase modulation to lower peak B1 */
1905  if (sms_phase_modulation_mode != KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_OFF) {
1906  status = ks_eval_sms_get_phase_modulation(sms_phase_modulation, sms_multiband_factor, sms_phase_modulation_mode);
1907  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1908  }
1909 
1910  /* initialize thetawave */
1911  if (selrfMB->rf.thetawave.res == 0) {
1912  ks_init_wave(&selrfMB->rf.thetawave);
1913  strncpy(selrfMB->rf.thetawave.description, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description, KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH);
1914  selrfMB->rf.thetawave.res = selrfMB->rf.rfwave.res;
1915  selrfMB->rf.thetawave.duration = selrfMB->rf.rfwave.duration;
1916  }
1917 
1918  if (debug) {sprintf(fname, "%s%s_mb_rf_base.txt", outputdir_uid, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description); ks_print_waveform(selrf->rf.rfwave.waveform, fname, selrf->rf.rfwave.res); }
1919 
1920  /* Figure out a new resolution, since many pulses are of low resolution */
1921  int newRes = selrf->rf.rfwave.duration/RF_UPDATE_TIME;
1922  int nPoints = newRes/selrf->rf.rfwave.res;
1923 
1924  /* Calc and apply sms modulation to base pulse */
1925  float *sms_wave_real = alloca(newRes*sizeof(float));
1926  float *sms_wave_imag = alloca(newRes*sizeof(float));
1927 
1928  kdx = 0;
1929  for (idx=0; idx < newRes; idx++) {
1930 
1931  double wave_real, wave_imag, sms_modulation_real = 0, sms_modulation_imag = 0, p, slice_offset;
1932 
1933  /* Convert base pulse from polar to cartesian */
1934  wave_real = selrf->rf.rfwave.waveform[kdx] * cos(selrf->rf.thetawave.waveform[kdx]*(PI/180.0));
1935  wave_imag = selrf->rf.rfwave.waveform[kdx] * sin(selrf->rf.thetawave.waveform[kdx]*(PI/180.0));
1936  if (debug) {
1937  fprintf(asciiWaveReal, "%d %f\n", idx, wave_real); fflush(asciiWaveReal);
1938  fprintf(asciiWaveImag, "%d %f\n", idx, wave_imag); fflush(asciiWaveImag);
1939  }
1940 
1941  if (idx % nPoints == 0 && idx > 0) {
1942  kdx++;
1943  }
1944 
1945  /* Calc sms modulation */
1946  double centeredIndex = idx - (newRes-1) * 0.5;
1947  for (jdx = 0; jdx < sms_multiband_factor; jdx++) {
1948 
1949  slice_offset = (sms_slice_gap / 10) * (1.0 + jdx - (sms_multiband_factor / 2.0) - 0.5);
1950  p = 2.0 * PI * GAM * slice_offset * selrf->grad.amp * centeredIndex * RF_UPDATE_TIME * 1e-6 + sms_phase_modulation[jdx];
1951 
1952  if (single_band_mode >= 0) {
1953  if (jdx == single_band_mode) {
1954  sms_modulation_real += cos(p);
1955  sms_modulation_imag += sin(p);
1956  }
1957  } else {
1958  sms_modulation_real += cos(p);
1959  sms_modulation_imag += sin(p);
1960  }
1961  }
1962 
1963  /* Apply sms modulation via complex multiplication */
1964  sms_wave_real[idx] = wave_real * sms_modulation_real - wave_imag * sms_modulation_imag;
1965  sms_wave_imag[idx] = wave_real * sms_modulation_imag + wave_imag * sms_modulation_real;
1966 
1967  if (debug) {
1968  fprintf(asciiWaveRealMB, "%d %f\n", idx, sms_wave_real[idx]); fflush(asciiWaveRealMB);
1969  fprintf(asciiWaveImagMB, "%d %f\n", idx, sms_wave_imag[idx]); fflush(asciiWaveImagMB);
1970  fprintf(asciiWaveRealMod, "%d %f\n", idx, sms_modulation_real); fflush(asciiWaveRealMod);
1971  fprintf(asciiWaveImagMod, "%d %f\n", idx, sms_modulation_imag); fflush(asciiWaveImagMod);
1972  }
1973 
1974  }
1975 
1976  if (debug) {
1977  fclose(asciiWaveReal);
1978  fclose(asciiWaveImag);
1979  fclose(asciiWaveRealMB);
1980  fclose(asciiWaveImagMB);
1981  /*ks_error("GAM=%g, PI=%g, grad.amp=%g, slice_gap=%g, dt=%d", GAM, PI, selrf->grad.amp, sms_slice_gap, RF_UPDATE_TIME);*/
1982  }
1983 
1984  kdx = 0;
1985  for (idx=0; idx < newRes; idx++) {
1986 
1987  if (sms_phase_modulation_mode == KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_OFF || sms_phase_modulation_mode == KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_AMPL) {
1988 
1989  /* Use real part and place waves in selrfMB */
1990  selrfMB->rf.rfwave.waveform[idx] = sms_wave_real[idx];
1991 
1992  } else {
1993 
1994  /* Convert from polar to cartesian and place waves in selrfMB */
1995  selrfMB->rf.rfwave.waveform[idx] = sqrt(pow(sms_wave_real[idx], 2.0) + pow(sms_wave_imag[idx], 2.0));
1996  selrfMB->rf.thetawave.waveform[idx] = atan2(sms_wave_imag[idx], sms_wave_real[idx]) * (180.0/PI);
1997 
1998  }
1999 
2000  if (idx % nPoints == 0 && idx > 0) {
2001  kdx++;
2002  }
2003  }
2004 
2005  /* Update resolution fields */
2006  selrfMB->rf.rfwave.res = newRes;
2007  if (sms_phase_modulation_mode == KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_OFF || sms_phase_modulation_mode == KS_SELRF_SMS_PHAS_MOD_AMPL) {
2008  selrfMB->rf.thetawave.res = 0;
2009  selrfMB->rf.thetawave.duration = 0;
2010  } else {
2011  selrfMB->rf.thetawave.res = newRes;
2012  }
2013 
2014  if (debug) {sprintf(fname, "%s%s_mb_rf.txt", outputdir_uid, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description); ks_print_waveform(selrfMB->rf.rfwave.waveform, fname, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.res); }
2015  if (debug) {sprintf(fname, "%s%s_mb_theta.txt", outputdir_uid, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description); ks_print_waveform(selrfMB->rf.thetawave.waveform, fname, selrfMB->rf.thetawave.res); }
2016 
2017  /* Modify rfpulse structure */
2018  double standard_pw = 1e-3;
2019  double b1_scale_factor = ks_waveform_absmax(selrfMB->rf.rfwave.waveform, newRes) / base_rf_max_amp;
2020  selrfMB->rf.rfpulse.max_b1 *= b1_scale_factor;
2021  selrfMB->rf.rfpulse.area /= b1_scale_factor;
2022  selrfMB->rf.rfpulse.effwidth /= b1_scale_factor;
2023  selrfMB->rf.rfpulse.max_int_b1_sq = selrfMB->rf.rfpulse.max_b1 * selrfMB->rf.rfpulse.max_b1 * selrfMB->rf.rfpulse.effwidth * (selrfMB->rf.rfwave.duration) * 1e-6 / standard_pw;
2024  selrfMB->rf.rfpulse.max_rms_b1 = sqrt(selrfMB->rf.rfpulse.max_int_b1_sq / ((selrfMB->rf.rfwave.duration) * 1e-6) * standard_pw);
2025 
2026 
2027  /* Normalize to 1 */
2028  ks_wave_multiplyval(&selrfMB->rf.rfwave, 1.0 / ks_wave_absmax(&selrfMB->rf.rfwave));
2029 
2030  /* register the RF for later heat calcs and RF scaling */
2031  char description[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 4];
2032  sprintf(description, "%s_sms", selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description);
2033  status = ks_eval_rf(&selrfMB->rf, description);
2034  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
2035 
2036  if (debug) {
2037  sprintf(fname, "%s%s_mb_params.txt", outputdir_uid, selrfMB->rf.rfwave.description);
2038  asciiWaveParams = fopen(fname,"w");
2039  fprintf(asciiWaveParams, "%f\n", (float)selrfMB->rf.flip);
2040  fprintf(asciiWaveParams, "%f\n", (float)selrfMB->grad.amp);
2041  fprintf(asciiWaveParams, "%f\n", (float)selrfMB->rf.rfpulse.max_b1);
2042  fprintf(asciiWaveParams, "%f\n", (float)selrfMB->slthick);
2043  fprintf(asciiWaveParams, "%f\n", (float)sms_slice_gap);
2044  fprintf(asciiWaveParams, "%f\n", (float)sms_multiband_factor);
2045  fprintf(asciiWaveParams, "%f\n", (float)b1_scale_factor);
2046  fflush(asciiWaveParams); fclose(asciiWaveParams);
2047  }
2048 
2049  return SUCCESS;
2050 
2051 } /* EOF */

◆ ks_eval_sms_calc_slice_gap()

float ks_eval_sms_calc_slice_gap ( int  sms_multiband_factor,
const SCAN_INFO *  org_slice_positions,
int  nslices,
float  slthick,
float  slspace 
)

Calculates the resulting slice gap in [mm] for SMS RF

Parameters
[in]sms_multiband_factorThe multi-band acceleration factor
[in]org_slice_positionsSCAN_INFO struct holding the original slice information
[in]nslicesPrescribed number of slices
[in]slthickPrescribed slice thickness
[in]slspacePrescribed slice spacing
Return values
slicegapSMS slice gap in [mm]
2141  {
2142 
2143  float gap;
2144 
2145  if (nslices % sms_multiband_factor) {
2146  ks_error("ks_eval_sms_calc_slice_gap: Number of slices (%d, 3rd arg) must be divisible with the MB factor (%d, 1st arg)", nslices, sms_multiband_factor);
2147  }
2148 
2149  /* gap between MB slices mm */
2150  /*gap = org_slice_positions[nslices/sms_multiband_factor].optloc - org_slice_positions[0].optloc;*/
2151  gap = (float)((nslices + sms_multiband_factor - 1) / sms_multiband_factor) * (float)(slthick + slspace);
2152 
2153  return gap;
2154 
2155 } /* EOF */
ks_error
STATUS ks_error(const char *format,...) __attribute__((format(printf
Common error message function for HOST and TGT

◆ ks_eval_sms_calc_caipi_area()

float ks_eval_sms_calc_caipi_area ( int  caipi_fov_shift,
float  sms_slice_gap 
)

Calculates the CAIPI blip area

Parameters
[in]caipi_fov_shiftThe FOV shift in units of faction of FOV (e.g. 2 means shift of FOV/2)
[in]sms_slice_gapSlice gap in [mm] for the selrfMB pulse
Return values
caipi_blip_areaThe area of the CAIPIRINHA blip in [(G/cm) * us]
2158  {
2159 
2160  if (sms_slice_gap <= 0) {
2161  return 0.0;
2162  }
2163 
2164  /* Calculate CAIPI-blip area in us*G/cm */
2165  return ((caipi_fov_shift-1)*(float)PI/(float)caipi_fov_shift) / (2.0*PI*GAM*1e-6 * (sms_slice_gap/10.0));
2166 
2167 } /* EOF */
GAM
float GAM

◆ ks_eval_sms_make_pins()

STATUS ks_eval_sms_make_pins ( KS_SELRF *  selrfPINS,
const KS_SELRF *  selrf,
float  sms_slice_gap 
)

Creates a PINS RF pulse (KS_SELRF) based on a KS_SELRF object

Parameters
[out]selrfPINSPINS RF pulse (KS_SELRF object)
[in]selrfThe original (single-band) KS_SELRF object (set up using ks_eval_selrf())
[in]sms_slice_gapSlice gap in [mm] for the selrfMB pulse
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
2243  {
2244 
2245  STATUS status;
2246  int jdx, idx, kdx = 0, gdx = 0, debug = 0;
2247  int orgDur = selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.duration;
2248  KS_TRAP gzblip = KS_INIT_TRAP;
2249 
2250  /* Duplicate the selRF structure */
2251  if (selrfPINS != selrf ) {
2252  *selrfPINS = *selrf;
2253  }
2254 
2255  /* Set info struct */
2256  selrfPINS->sms_info.slice_gap = sms_slice_gap;
2257  selrfPINS->sms_info.pulse_type = KS_SELRF_SMS_PINS;
2258 
2259  ks_init_trap(&selrfPINS->grad);
2260 
2261  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(selrf->rf.rfwave.waveform, "pins_rfMB_base.txt", selrf->rf.rfwave.res); }
2262 
2263  double kzw = (selrf->rf.bw * selrf->rf.rfwave.duration * 1e-6) / (selrf->slthick / 10); /* 1/cm, width in kz-space we must go */
2264  int NPulses = (floor(ceil(kzw / (1 / (sms_slice_gap / 10))) / 2) * 2) + 1; /* number of subpulses (odd) */
2265 
2266  /* Init waves */
2267  KS_WAVEFORM rfLowRes = KS_INIT_WAVEFORM;
2268  KS_WAVE gzBlipWave = KS_INIT_WAVE;
2269  float *lowResGrid = alloca(NPulses * sizeof(float));
2270  float *baseGrid = alloca(selrf->rf.rfwave.res * sizeof(float));
2271 
2272  /* create index for interpolation */
2273  for (idx = 0; idx < selrf->rf.rfwave.res; idx++) {
2274  baseGrid[idx] = (float) idx / (selrf->rf.rfwave.res - 1);
2275  }
2276  for (idx = 0; idx < NPulses; idx++) {
2277  lowResGrid[idx] = (float) idx / (NPulses - 1);
2278  }
2279 
2280  /* Interpolate the base rf to get PINS sub pulse amplitudes and high res for MB pulse */
2281  ks_eval_linear_interp1(baseGrid, selrf->rf.rfwave.res, selrf->rf.rfwave.waveform, lowResGrid, NPulses, rfLowRes);
2282 
2283  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(rfLowRes, "pins_rfLowRes.txt", NPulses); }
2284 
2285  /* Create blip */
2286  double gArea = 1 / (sms_slice_gap / 10) / (GAM); /* (g sec)/cm, k-area of each blip */
2287  gzblip.area = gArea * 1e6; /* (G/cm)*us */
2288  status = ks_eval_trap1(&gzblip, "PINSblip"); if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
2289  status = ks_eval_trap2wave(&gzBlipWave, &gzblip); if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
2290  ks_init_trap(&gzblip);
2291 
2292  /* Matched-duration RF subpulses */
2293  float maxB1 = 0.24; /* temp. */
2294  float dt = GRAD_UPDATE_TIME / 1000000.0; /* sec */
2295  float pulseArea = (float) selrf->rf.flip * (PI / 180.0); /* radians or Hz (depending on how you look at it) */
2296  float subArea = (ks_waveform_absmax(rfLowRes, NPulses) * pulseArea) / (ks_waveform_sum(rfLowRes, NPulses) * 2.0 * PI * GAM); /* Gauss * sec */
2297  int hpw = ceil(subArea / (maxB1 * dt)); /* number of time points in sub pulse */
2298  float scaleFactor = 1.0;
2299 
2300  /* kludge :( */
2301  for (idx = 0; idx < NPulses; idx++) {
2302  if (rfLowRes[idx] == 0) {
2303  rfLowRes[idx] = rfLowRes[idx] + 0.01;
2304  }
2305  }
2306 
2307  /* Loop to concatenate the sub pulses and gradient blips */
2308  for (idx = 0; idx < NPulses; idx++) {
2309  for (jdx = 0; jdx < hpw; jdx++) {
2310  selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform[kdx] = rfLowRes[idx] / scaleFactor;
2311  selrfPINS->gradwave.waveform[kdx] = 0.0;
2312  kdx++;
2313  }
2314  if (idx != NPulses - 1) {
2315  for (jdx = 0; jdx < gzBlipWave.res; jdx++) {
2316  selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform[kdx] = 0.0;
2317  selrfPINS->gradwave.waveform[kdx] = gzBlipWave.waveform[jdx];
2318  kdx++; gdx++;
2319  }
2320  }
2321  }
2322 
2323  /* Set duration and resolution */
2324  selrfPINS->gradwave.gradwave_units = KS_GRADWAVE_ABSOLUTE;
2325  selrfPINS->gradwave.res = RUP_FACTOR(kdx, GRAD_UPDATE_TIME);
2326  selrfPINS->gradwave.duration = selrfPINS->gradwave.res * GRAD_UPDATE_TIME;
2327  selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.res = selrfPINS->gradwave.res;
2328  selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.duration = selrfPINS->gradwave.duration;
2329  selrfPINS->rf.rfpulse.isodelay = RUP_FACTOR(ceil((float)selrfPINS->rf.rfpulse.isodelay * ((float)selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.duration/(float)orgDur)), GRAD_UPDATE_TIME);
2330  selrfPINS->rf.iso2end = selrfPINS->rf.rfpulse.isodelay;
2331  selrfPINS->rf.bw = 1e3 * (NPulses+1) * selrf->slthick / sms_slice_gap;
2332 
2333  /* If the resolution has been rounded up, place zeros at the end */
2334  for (idx = kdx; idx < selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.res; idx++) {
2335  selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform[idx] = 0.0;
2336  selrfPINS->gradwave.waveform[idx] = 0.0;
2337  }
2338 
2339  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform, "pins_RF.txt", selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.res); }
2340  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(selrfPINS->gradwave.waveform, "pins_GRAD.txt", selrfPINS->gradwave.res); }
2341 
2342  /* Normalize to 1 */
2343  ks_waveform_multiplyval(selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform, 1.0 / ks_waveform_absmax(selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform, selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.res), selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.res);
2344 
2345  /* rfStat */
2346  status = ks_eval_rfstat(&selrfPINS->rf); if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
2347 
2348  /* init theta wave */
2349  ks_init_wave(&selrfPINS->rf.thetawave);
2350  selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.duration = selrfPINS->gradwave.duration;
2351  selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.res = selrfPINS->gradwave.res;
2352  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.waveform, "pins_TH.txt", selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.res); }
2353 
2354  /* Register the RF */
2355  char description[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 4];
2356  sprintf(description, "%s_PINS", selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.description);
2357  sprintf(selrfPINS->gradwave.description, "%s_PINS", selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.description);
2358  if (debug == 1) {fprintf(stderr, "---------- PINS %s rfstat ---------\n", selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.description);}
2359  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_rfpulse(selrfPINS->rf.rfpulse, stderr);}
2360  return ks_eval_rf(&selrfPINS->rf, description);
2361 
2362 }

KS_SELRF_SMS_PINS

◆ ks_eval_sms_make_pins_dante()

STATUS ks_eval_sms_make_pins_dante ( KS_SELRF *  selrfPINS,
const KS_SELRF *  selrf,
float  sms_slice_gap 
)
2365  {
2366  STATUS status;
2367  int jdx, idx, kdx = 0, gdx = 0, debug = 1;
2368  int orgDur = selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.duration;
2369  KS_TRAP gzblip = KS_INIT_TRAP;
2370 
2371  /* Duplicate the selRF structure */
2372  if (selrfPINS != selrf ) {
2373  *selrfPINS = *selrf;
2374  }
2375 
2376  /* Set info struct */
2377  selrfPINS->sms_info.slice_gap = sms_slice_gap;
2378  selrfPINS->sms_info.pulse_type = KS_SELRF_SMS_PINS_DANTE;
2379 
2380  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(selrf->rf.rfwave.waveform, "dpins_rfMB_base.txt", selrf->rf.rfwave.res); }
2381  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(selrf->rf.thetawave.waveform, "dpins_phMB_base.txt", selrf->rf.thetawave.res); }
2382 
2383  /* Create blip */
2384  KS_WAVE gzBlipWave = KS_INIT_WAVE;
2385  double gArea = 1 / (sms_slice_gap / 10) / (GAM); /* (g sec)/cm, k-area of each blip */
2386  gzblip.area = gArea * 1e6; /* (G/cm)*us */
2387  status = ks_eval_trap1(&gzblip, "PINSblip"); if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
2388  status = ks_eval_trap2wave(&gzBlipWave, &gzblip); if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
2389  ks_init_trap(&gzblip);
2390 
2391  /* Calcualte PINS parameters */
2392  double kzw = (selrf->rf.bw * selrf->rf.rfwave.duration * 1e-6) / (selrf->slthick / 10); /* 1/cm, width in kz-space we must go */
2393  int NPulses = (floor(ceil(kzw / (1 / (sms_slice_gap / 10))) / 2) * 2) + 1; /* number of subpulses (odd) */
2394  int hpw = ceil((float)selrf->rf.rfwave.res / (float)NPulses); /* number of time points in sub pulse */
2395  int interpolRes = hpw * NPulses;
2396 
2397  /* Create index for interpolation */
2398  float *newGrid = alloca(interpolRes * sizeof(float));
2399  float *baseGrid = alloca(selrf->rf.rfwave.res * sizeof(float));
2400  for (idx = 0; idx < selrf->rf.rfwave.res; idx++) {
2401  baseGrid[idx] = (float) idx / (selrf->rf.rfwave.res - 1);
2402  }
2403  for (idx = 0; idx < interpolRes; idx++) {
2404  newGrid[idx] = (float) idx / (interpolRes - 1);
2405  }
2406 
2407  /* Interpolate the base rf & phase to make their resolution divideble by NPulses */
2408  KS_WAVEFORM rfNewRes = KS_INIT_WAVEFORM;
2409  KS_WAVEFORM phNewRes = KS_INIT_WAVEFORM;
2410  ks_eval_linear_interp1(baseGrid, selrf->rf.rfwave.res, selrf->rf.rfwave.waveform, newGrid, interpolRes, rfNewRes);
2411  ks_eval_linear_interp1(baseGrid, selrf->rf.thetawave.res, selrf->rf.thetawave.waveform, newGrid, interpolRes, phNewRes);
2412 
2413  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(rfNewRes, "rfNewRes.txt", interpolRes); }
2414  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(phNewRes, "phNewRes.txt", interpolRes); }
2415 
2416  /* Loop to concatenate the sub pulses and gradient blips */
2417  for (idx = 0; idx < NPulses; idx++) {
2418  for (jdx = 0; jdx < hpw; jdx++) {
2419  selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform[kdx] = rfNewRes[(idx * hpw) + jdx];
2420  selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.waveform[kdx] = phNewRes[(idx * hpw) + jdx];
2421  selrfPINS->gradwave.waveform[kdx] = 0.0;
2422  kdx++;
2423  }
2424  if (idx != NPulses - 1) {
2425  for (jdx = 0; jdx < gzBlipWave.res; jdx++) {
2426  selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform[kdx] = 0.0;
2427  selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.waveform[kdx] = 0.0;
2428  selrfPINS->gradwave.waveform[kdx] = gzBlipWave.waveform[jdx];
2429  kdx++; gdx++;
2430  }
2431  }
2432  }
2433 
2434  /* Set duration and resolution */
2435  selrfPINS->grad.duration = 0;
2436  selrfPINS->gradwave.gradwave_units = KS_GRADWAVE_ABSOLUTE;
2437  selrfPINS->gradwave.res = RUP_FACTOR(kdx, GRAD_UPDATE_TIME);
2438  selrfPINS->gradwave.duration = selrfPINS->gradwave.res * GRAD_UPDATE_TIME;
2439  selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.res = selrfPINS->gradwave.res;
2440  selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.duration = selrfPINS->gradwave.duration;
2441  selrfPINS->rf.rfpulse.isodelay = RUP_FACTOR((int)(selrfPINS->rf.rfpulse.isodelay * ((float)selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.duration/(float)orgDur)),RF_UPDATE_TIME);
2442  selrfPINS->rf.iso2end = selrfPINS->rf.rfpulse.isodelay;
2443  selrfPINS->rf.bw = 1e3 * (NPulses+1) * selrf->slthick / sms_slice_gap;
2444 
2445  /* If the resolution has been rounded up, place zeros at the end */
2446  for (idx = kdx; idx < selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.res; idx++) {
2447  selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform[idx] = 0.0;
2448  selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.waveform[idx] = selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.waveform[kdx];
2449  selrfPINS->gradwave.waveform[idx] = 0.0;
2450  }
2451 
2452  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform, "dpins_RF.txt", selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.res); }
2453  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(selrfPINS->gradwave.waveform, "dpins_GRAD.txt", selrfPINS->gradwave.res); }
2454 
2455  /* Normalize to 1 */
2456  ks_waveform_multiplyval(selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform, 1.0 / ks_waveform_absmax(selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.waveform, selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.res), selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.res);
2457 
2458  /* rfStat */
2459  float orgMaxB1 = selrfPINS->rf.rfpulse.max_b1;
2460  selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.res = 0;
2461  status = ks_eval_rfstat(&selrfPINS->rf); if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
2462  selrfPINS->rf.rfpulse.max_b1 = orgMaxB1;
2463 
2464  /* Theta wave */
2465  selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.duration = selrfPINS->gradwave.duration;
2466  selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.res = selrfPINS->gradwave.res;
2467 
2468  for (idx = 0; idx < selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.res; idx++) {
2469  if (fabs(selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.waveform[idx]) > 180.0) {
2470  double angle = selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.waveform[idx];
2471  double revolutions = floor((angle + 180.0) / 360.0);
2472  selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.waveform[idx] = (float) (angle - revolutions * 360.0);
2473  }
2474  }
2475 
2476  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_waveform(selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.waveform, "dpins_TH.txt", selrfPINS->rf.thetawave.res); }
2477 
2478  /* Register the RF */
2479  char description[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 4];
2480  sprintf(description, "%s_PINSDANTE", selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.description);
2481  sprintf(selrfPINS->gradwave.description, "%s_PINSDANTE", selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.description);
2482  if (debug == 1) {fprintf(stderr, "---------- PINS DANTE %s rfstat ---------\n", selrfPINS->rf.rfwave.description);}
2483  if (debug == 1) {ks_print_rfpulse(selrfPINS->rf.rfpulse, stderr);}
2484  return ks_eval_rf(&selrfPINS->rf, description);
2485 
2486 }
KS_GRADWAVE_ABSOLUTE
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1772
KS_SELRF::grad
KS_TRAP grad
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1340
ks_print_waveform
void ks_print_waveform(const KS_WAVEFORM waveform, char *filename, int res)

ks_eval_trap1
STATUS ks_eval_trap1(KS_TRAP *trap, const char *const desc)
Sets up a trapezoid using a KS_TRAP sequence object with preset gradient constraints
Definition: KSFoundation_host.c:403
KS_TRAP
Core sequence object for making trapezoids on X,Y,Z, and OMEGA boards

KS_WAVE
Core sequence object making arbitrary waveforms on any board (using float data format)

debug
