KS_PHASER * phaser
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1591

◆ ks_fse_calcecho()

STATUS ks_fse_calcecho ( double *  bestecho,
double *  optecho,
KS_PHASER *  pe,
int  TE,
int  etl,
int  esp 
)

Calculates the ETL index corresponding the desired TE given a KS_PHASER object and echo spacing

Given the KS_PHASER object used in the FSE train (containing res and partial ky Fourier info), the desired effective echo time (TE [us]), the echo train length (etl) and the echo spacing between consecutive echoes (esp [us]), this function calculates two echo indices:

  • bestecho: is the 0-based index corresponding to the echo in the FSE train that should be placed in the center of k-space, i.e. the echo that most closely matches the desired TE. If bestecho is an integer value (although it is in double format), the data acquired for this echo should straddle the k-space center. bestecho can also be an interger + 0.5, indicating that there are two echo indices that should be placed around the k-space center. For example, floor(bestecho) corresponds to the echo index that should be placed just below the k-space center and ceil(bestecho) corresponds to the echo index that should be placed just above the k-space center. I.e. when bestecho = *.5, no single echo index will straddle the k-space center, and the k-space line located at ky position +0.5 will come from data acquired from echo #[floor(bestecho)] and ky position -0.5 correspondingly from echo #[ceil(bestecho)].
  • optecho: is the 0-based index corresponding to an ideal TE choice that would allow the data from the echoes in the FSE train to be placed out linearly each time. Doing so will reduce ghosting and T2 blurring. Hence, optecho ignores the input TE value here, but the calling function can use this information to determine k-space acquisition order, but also to suggest a TE (optecho * esp) that would result in optimal image quality for the chosen ETL.
Parameters
[out]bestechoPointer to the echo number in the train that should be placed at the center of k-space given the current ETL and ESP
[out]optechoPointer to the optimal echo number in the train that would allow k-space to be sampled linearly (to reduce T2-blurring and ghosting)
[in]pePointer to a KS_PHASER
[in]TE(Echo Time in [us])
[in]etl(EchoTrain Length)
[in]esp(Echo Spacing in [us])
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
513  {
514  int numshots, i;
515  int nacqlines_earlyside;
516 
517  if (etl < 1) {
518  return ks_error("ksfse_calc_echo: ETL (arg 5) must be at least 1");
519  }
520  if (pe->numlinestoacq < 1) {
521  return ks_error("ksfse_calc_echo: field '.numlinestoacq' in 3rd arg must be at least 1");
522  }
523  if (etl > pe->numlinestoacq) {
524  return ks_error("ksfse_calc_echo: ETL (arg 5) cannot exceed number of lines to acquire");
525  }
526  if (esp <= 0) {
527  return ks_error("ksfse_calc_echo: ESP (arg 6) must be larger than 1");
528  }
529 
530  /* Number of shots */
531  numshots = CEIL_DIV(pe->numlinestoacq, etl);
532 
533  /* index 'i' will stop incrementing as we pass the center of k-space */
534  for (i = 0; i < pe->numlinestoacq - 1; i++) {
535  if (((pe->res - 1) / 2.0 - pe->linetoacq[i]) < 0)
536  break;
537  }
538  if (pe->nover >= 0) {
539  /* bottom-up (i.e. early echoes are below k-space center) */
540  nacqlines_earlyside = pe->numlinestoacq - i;
541  } else {
542  /* top-down (i.e. early echoes are above k-space center) */
543  nacqlines_earlyside = i;
544  }
545 
546  if (etl % 2) {
547  /* etl is odd. The optimal echo will straddle around the center of k-space */
548 
549  if (optecho != NULL)
550  *optecho = (double) CEIL_DIV((nacqlines_earlyside + numshots / 2), numshots); /* integer value since ETL is odd */
551 
552  if (bestecho != NULL) {
553  *bestecho = floor((double) TE / (double) esp + 0.5); /* integer */
554  if (*bestecho < 1)
555  *bestecho = 1;
556  if (*bestecho > etl)
557  *bestecho = etl;
558  }
559 
560  } else {
561  /* etl is even. The optimal two echoes will be placed above and below k-space center, respectively */
562 
563  if (optecho != NULL)
564  *optecho = (double) CEIL_DIV(nacqlines_earlyside, numshots) + 0.5; /* half-integer value since ETL is even */
565 
566  if (bestecho != NULL) {
567  if (etl == 2) {
568  /* special case for ETL = 2 */
569  if (TE < 1.25 * esp)
570  *bestecho = 1; /* 1st echo straddling around k-space center */
571  else if (TE < 1.75 * esp)
572  *bestecho = 1.5; /* 1st/end echo below/above k-space center */
573  else
574  *bestecho = 2; /* 2nd echo straddling around k-space center */
575  } else {
576  *bestecho = floor((double) TE / (double) esp) + 0.5; /* half-integer */
577  if (*bestecho <= 1.5)
578  *bestecho = 1; /* minTE, back to integer 'bestecho' for center-out encoding */
579  if (*bestecho >= (etl - 0.5))
580  *bestecho = etl; /* max TE, back to integer 'bestecho' for out-center encoding */
581  }
582  }
583 
584  }
585 
586  if (optecho != NULL) {
587  /* Partial Fourier MinTE case, regardless if ETL is even or odd */
588  if ((pe->nover > 0) && (nacqlines_earlyside <= numshots / 2))
589  *optecho = 1;
590 
591  /* Partial Fourier MaxTE case, regardless if ETL is even or odd */
592  if ((pe->nover < 0) && (nacqlines_earlyside >= (pe->linetoacq[i] - numshots / 2)))
593  *optecho = etl;
594  }
595 
596  return SUCCESS;
597 
598 } /* ks_fse_calcecho() */
KS_PHASER::res
int res
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1527
KS_PHASER::numlinestoacq
int numlinestoacq
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1532
ks_error
STATUS ks_error(const char *format,...)
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:49
KS_PHASER::linetoacq
int linetoacq[KS_MAX_PHASEDYN]
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1533
KS_PHASER::nover
int nover
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1528

◆ ks_phaseencoding_generate_2Dfse()

STATUS ks_phaseencoding_generate_2Dfse ( KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN *  phaseenc_plan_ptr,
const char *const  desc,
KS_PHASER *  phaser,
KS_PHASER *  zphaser,
int  TE,
int  etl,
int  esp 
)

2DFSE: Makes a KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN depending on etl, desired TE, and echo spacing (esp)

This function is only executed on TGT and will return early when called on HOST.

The phase encoding sorting is depending on many factors. First, the desired TE will dictate which one (or two) of the echoes in the FSE train (of length etl) that should be placed in the center. This is determined based on the properties of the KS_PHASER object (phase encoding gradients in the FSE train), TE and esp by calling ksfse_calc_echo().

Second, the sorting of the echoes will first of all depend on whether bestecho is equal to optecho. If it is, then the etl echoes can be placed out linearly in k-space (from the bottom->top of k-space, or vice versa). This will produce the best image quality with minimal T2-blurring and FSE ghosting.

As partial ky Fourier is allowed, this function first checks on which side (top or bottom half) of k-space that has more room for the echo indices that are either before or after the bestecho index corresponding to the desired TE. The goal with this is to try to sweep k-space as linearly as possible in as much of the center portion of k-space as possible when bestecho != optecho.

When bestecho != optecho, there will be data from either the first or last echo indices that won't fit in k-space if placed next to a neighboring index. If this data would be placed on the other size of k-space (that still needs lines to be filled in), where e.g. echo index #0 would be placed next to echo index #(etl-1), strong ghosting will occur due to the much strong signal from echo #0 compared to #(etl-1). With an echo train length of etl, k-space is filled in numshots = ceil(numlinestoacq / etl. Using half of the numshots lines for each echo index a linear sweep of the center half of k-space can is layed out. To avoid FSE ghosting, the numshots/2 remaining lines for each early or late echo index are placed such as neighboring ky lines will never have a change in echo index by more than one. For example if etl = 8, esp = 10 ms and TE = 25, then bestecho = 1.5 and optecho = 4.5. We avoid to sort the echoes in the following k-space order for ghosting reasons: 7-6-0-1*2-3-4-5 (* = k-space center) since there will be a strong discontinuity between 6 and 0. Instead we use groups of numshots/2 per echo index (and get two groups per echo index in k-space): 5-4-3-2-1-0-0-1*2-3-4-5-6-7-6-5

Parameters
[out]phaseenc_plan_ptrPointer to KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN
[in]descA description (text string) of the KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN object. This description is used in the psd plot.
[in]phaserPointer to a KS_PHASER
[in]zphaserPointer to a KS_PHASER (3D) or NULL (2D)
[in]TE(Echo Time in [us])
[in]etl(EchoTrain Length)
[in]esp(Echo Spacing in [us])
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE

Grouping shots for each of the ETL echoes in k-space: We don't place all shots for each echo together in k-space since we need to make a z-shaped pattern to avoid ghosting. Instead we let half of the shots be one group (of size 'cgroupsize') that we place in the central ~50% of k-space, which allows us to get a linear sweep in this central half of k-space using all 'etl' echoes, regardless of the chosen effective TE. The actual center-ness depends on TE, and the remaining of k-space is filled using the echoes belonging to the latter 'numshots-cgroupsize' number of shots. At the edges of k-space, numshots*etl seldom match up to the chosen opyres, but numshots*etl is always >= opyres thanks to the CEIL_DIV at the beginning of this function. The surplus echoes we don't need are numshots*etl - opyres (for full Fourier and no ARC), and as they are already tagged as -1 = KS_NOTSET in the beginning of this function, they will be placed in baseline view (0) in the ksfse_scan_acqloop()

602  {
603  int i, j, ky, kz;
604  int numshots, numkz;
605  double bestecho, optecho;
606  int nacqlines_earlyside;
607  int cgroupsize, halfgroupsize;
608  int bottomup = KS_NOTSET;
609  int cstart, cshift;
610  STATUS status;
611 
612  strncpy(phaseenc_plan_ptr->description, desc, KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH - 1);
613  phaseenc_plan_ptr->description[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH - 1] = 0;
614 
615  /* don't allow empty description or a description with leading space */
616  if (phaseenc_plan_ptr->description == NULL || phaseenc_plan_ptr->description[0] == ' ') {
617  return ks_error("%s: description of phase encoding plan (2nd arg) cannot be NULL or leading space", __FUNCTION__);
618  }
619 
620  if (etl < 1) {
621  return SUCCESS; /* we haven't set it up yet */
622  }
623  if (phaser->numlinestoacq < 2) {
624  return ks_error("%s: field '.numlinestoacq' in 2nd arg must be at least 2", __FUNCTION__);
625  }
626  if (etl > phaser->numlinestoacq) {
627  return ks_error("%s: ETL cannot exceed number of lines to acquire", __FUNCTION__);
628  }
629 
630 
631  /* Number of shots (2D) */
632  numshots = CEIL_DIV(phaser->numlinestoacq, etl);
633 
634  /* Number of kz */
635  numkz = (zphaser != NULL) ? zphaser->numlinestoacq : 1;
636 
637  /* allocate KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN table (all entries will be initialized to KS_NOTSET) */
638  status = ks_phaseencoding_resize(phaseenc_plan_ptr, etl, numshots * numkz);
639 
640  phaseenc_plan_ptr->phaser = phaser;
641  phaseenc_plan_ptr->zphaser = zphaser;
642 
643  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
644 
645 
646  for (kz = 0; kz < numkz; kz++) {
647 
648  if (etl == 1) {
649 
650  /* Special case for ETL = 1. Just acquire the data in order */
651  for (ky = 0; ky < phaser->numlinestoacq; ky++) {
652  ks_phaseencoding_set(phaseenc_plan_ptr,
653  0, ky + kz * phaser->numlinestoacq,
654  phaser->linetoacq[ky], (zphaser != NULL) ? zphaser->linetoacq[kz] : KS_NOTSET);
655  }
656 
657  } else {
658 
659  /* ETL > 1 (this is a long else-statement) */
660 
661  /* index 'i' will stop incrementing as we pass the center of k-space */
662  for (i = 0; i < phaser->numlinestoacq - 1; i++) {
663  if (((phaser->res - 1) / 2.0 - phaser->linetoacq[i]) < 0)
664  break;
665  }
666  if (phaser->nover >= 0) {
667  /* bottom-up (i.e. early echoes are below k-space center) */
668  nacqlines_earlyside = phaser->numlinestoacq - i;
669  bottomup = TRUE;
670  } else {
671  /* top-down (i.e. early echoes are above k-space center) */
672  nacqlines_earlyside = i;
673  bottomup = FALSE;
674  }
675 
676  /* get the best echo number for the given TE/ETL/ESP, and also the optimal echo number that would allow for a linear k-space sweep */
677  status = ks_fse_calcecho(&bestecho, &optecho, phaser, TE, etl, esp);
678  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
679 
680 
681  if (bestecho == optecho) {
682  /* we can place the echoes linearly in k-space in groups of 'numshots' per echo given the current combination of TE, ETL and ESP */
683  cgroupsize = numshots;
684  halfgroupsize = floor((float) phaser->numlinestoacq / (etl * 2.0) + 0.5);
685  } else {
695  cgroupsize = (int) ceil((float) phaser->numlinestoacq / (etl * 2.0)); /* ~numshots/2 lines per etl in the central 50% of k-space */
696  halfgroupsize = floor((float) phaser->numlinestoacq / (etl * 4.0) + 0.5);
697  }
698 
699  /* if bestecho == optecho: Place out all echoes
700  if bestecho != optecho: Place out the center half of lines */
701  if (bestecho == 1) /* minTE */
702  cshift = cgroupsize;
703  else if (bestecho == etl) /* maxTE */
704  cshift = 0;
705  else
706  cshift = halfgroupsize; /* non-extreme TE */
707  cstart = (nacqlines_earlyside + cshift) - cgroupsize * bestecho;
708  if (bottomup == TRUE)
709  cstart = phaser->numlinestoacq - cstart - 1;
710  ky = cstart;
711  for (i = 0; i < etl; i++) {
712  for (j = 0; j < cgroupsize; j++) {
713  if (ky >= 0 && ky < phaser->numlinestoacq) {
714  ks_phaseencoding_set(phaseenc_plan_ptr, i, j + kz * numshots, phaser->linetoacq[ky], (zphaser != NULL) ? zphaser->linetoacq[kz] : KS_NOTSET);
715  }
716  if (bottomup == TRUE)
717  ky--;
718  else
719  ky++;
720  }
721  }
722 
723  if (bestecho != optecho) {
724  /* remaining 'numshots-cgroupsize' number of shots for late echoes */
725  i = etl - 1;
726  while (i >= 0) {
727  for (j = cgroupsize; j < numshots; j++) {
728  if (ky >= 0 && ky < phaser->numlinestoacq) {
729  ks_phaseencoding_set(phaseenc_plan_ptr, i, j + kz * numshots, phaser->linetoacq[ky], (zphaser != NULL) ? zphaser->linetoacq[kz] : KS_NOTSET);
730  }
731  if (bottomup == TRUE)
732  ky--;
733  else
734  ky++;
735  } /* for j */
736  i--;
737  }
738 
739  /* remaining 'numshots-cgroupsize' number of shots for early echoes */
740  if (bottomup == TRUE)
741  ky = cstart + 1;
742  else
743  ky = cstart - 1;
744  i = 0;
745  while (i < etl) {
746  for (j = cgroupsize; j < numshots; j++) {
747  if (ky >= 0 && ky < phaser->numlinestoacq) {
748  ks_phaseencoding_set(phaseenc_plan_ptr, i, j + kz * numshots, phaser->linetoacq[ky], (zphaser != NULL) ? zphaser->linetoacq[kz] : KS_NOTSET);
749  }
750  if (bottomup == TRUE)
751  ky++;
752  else
753  ky--;
754  } /* for j */
755  i++;
756  }
757  } /* bestecho != optecho */
758 
759  } /* etl > 1 */
760 
761  } /* numkz */
762 
763 
764  return SUCCESS;
765 
766 
767 } /* ks_phaseencoding_generate_2Dfse() */
ks_phaseencoding_set
void ks_phaseencoding_set(KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN *phaseenc_plan_ptr, int echo, int shot, int ky, int kz)
Set [ky,kz] coordinate from KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN for given echo and shot

ks_phaseencoding_resize
STATUS ks_phaseencoding_resize(KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN *phaseenc_plan_ptr, int etl, int num_shots)

KS_PHASER::res
int res
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1527
KS_NOTSET
#define KS_NOTSET

KS_PHASER::numlinestoacq
int numlinestoacq
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1532
ks_error
STATUS ks_error(const char *format,...)
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:49
KS_PHASER::linetoacq
int linetoacq[KS_MAX_PHASEDYN]
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1533
ks_fse_calcecho
STATUS ks_fse_calcecho(double *bestecho, double *optecho, KS_PHASER *pe, int TE, int etl, int esp)
Calculates the ETL index corresponding the desired TE given a KS_PHASER object and echo spacing...
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:513
KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH
#define KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH
Definition: KSFoundation.h:112
KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN::description
KS_DESCRIPTION description
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1589
KS_PHASER::nover
int nover
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1528
KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN::zphaser
KS_PHASER * zphaser
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1592
KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN::phaser
KS_PHASER * phaser
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1591

◆ ks_phaseencoding_generate_epi()

STATUS ks_phaseencoding_generate_epi ( KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN *  phaseenc_plan_ptr,
const char *const  desc,
KS_EPI *  epitrain,
int  blipsign,
int  numkyshots,
int  numsegments,
int  caipi 
)

EPI: Makes a KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN suitable for 2D or 3D epi

The etl is the number of readouts in the EPI train, derived from the phaser. The number of ky shots is also given by the phaser, while the number of kz shots is given by zphaser. Any partial fourier is handled by the phasers, and acceleration and acs lines in the z direction is handled by zphaser. For 3D EPI, the number of shots in the phase encoding plan will be the product of the number of shots in the ky direction and the number of kz lines to acquire.

Each shot will be played out in a single kz plane. The shot order will be linear in ky and kz. The ky shots will be in the inner loop, unless kzshotsfirst is TRUE.

Parameters
[out]phaseenc_plan_ptrPointer to the phase encoding plan
[in]descA description (text string) of the KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN object. This description is used in the psd plot.
[in]epitrainPointer to a KS_EPI
[in]blipsignShould be either KS_EPI_POSBLIPS or KS_EPI_NEGBLIPS
[in]numkyshotsNumber of ky shots to play. Must be within 1-R and evenly divisble with R. Set =1 for single-shot EPI. Set to phaser.R for full multi-shot EPI.
[in]numsegmentsNumber of kz encodes to play
[in]caipiUse CAIPIRINHA sampling pattern (affects 3D epi only)
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
771  {
772 
773  if (epitrain->blipphaser.numlinestoacq < 2 && (epitrain->blipphaser.R != epitrain->blipphaser.res)) {
774  return ks_error("%s: field '.numlinestoacq' of epitrain->blipphaser must be at least 2, not %d", __FUNCTION__, epitrain->blipphaser.numlinestoacq);
775  }
776 
777  strncpy(phaseenc_plan_ptr->description, desc, KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH - 1);
778  phaseenc_plan_ptr->description[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH - 1] = 0;
779 
780  /* don't allow empty description or a description with leading space */
781  if (phaseenc_plan_ptr->description == NULL || phaseenc_plan_ptr->description[0] == ' ') {
782  return ks_error("%s: description of phase encoding plan (2nd arg) cannot be NULL or leading space", __FUNCTION__);
783  }
784 
785  int readout, shot, kyshot, kyview, kzview, kzind;
786  int etl, numfullsegments, numshots, totalnumshots;
787  int shift;
788  STATUS status;
789 
790  /* Number of shots (2D) */
791  if (numkyshots < 1 || numkyshots > epitrain->blipphaser.R || (epitrain->blipphaser.R % numkyshots != 0)) {
792  return ks_error("%s: numkyshots (=%d) must be in range 1-R and evenly divisible with R (=%d)", __FUNCTION__, numkyshots, epitrain->blipphaser.R);
793  }
794 
795  /* Number of segments (3D) */
796  if (epitrain->zphaser.res != KS_NOTSET && (numsegments < 1 || numsegments > epitrain->zphaser.numlinestoacq)) {
797  return ks_error("%s: numsegments (=%d) must be in range 1-zphaser.numlinestoacq (=%d)", __FUNCTION__, numsegments, epitrain->zphaser.numlinestoacq);
798  }
799 
800  /* Number of readouts per EPI train (etl) */
801  etl = epitrain->blipphaser.numlinestoacq;
802 
803  /* Check number of kz segments and how many should be fully sampled (controlled by zphaser.nacslines) */
804  if (epitrain->zphaser.res == KS_NOTSET) { /* 2D epi */
805  numsegments = 1;
806  numfullsegments = (numkyshots == epitrain->blipphaser.R);
807  } else { /* 3D epi */
808  if (epitrain->zphaser.R == 1) {
809  numfullsegments = epitrain->zphaser.nacslines; /* special interpretation for zR=1 */
810  } else { /* zR > 1 */
811  if (epitrain->zphaser.nacslines > 0) {
812  numfullsegments = 1; /* initialize */
813  for (kzind = 1; kzind < numsegments; kzind++) {
814  if (abs(epitrain->zphaser.linetoacq[kzind]-epitrain->zphaser.linetoacq[kzind-1])==1) {
815  numfullsegments++;
816  }
817  }
818  } else { /* no kz "acs lines" */
819  numfullsegments = 0;
820  }
821  }
822  }
823 
824  /* allocate KS_PHASEENCODING_PLAN table (all entries will be initialized to KS_NOTSET) */
825  totalnumshots = numfullsegments * epitrain->blipphaser.R + (numsegments-numfullsegments) * numkyshots;
826  status = ks_phaseencoding_resize(phaseenc_plan_ptr, etl, totalnumshots);
827 
828  phaseenc_plan_ptr->phaser = &epitrain->blipphaser;
829  phaseenc_plan_ptr->zphaser = &epitrain->zphaser;
830 
831  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
832 
833  shot = 0; /* initialize */
834  for (kzind = 0; kzind < numsegments; kzind++) {
835  kzview = (epitrain->zphaser.numlinestoacq > 0) ? epitrain->zphaser.linetoacq[kzind] : KS_NOTSET;
836 
837  if (kzview != KS_NOTSET && abs(kzview*2 - (epitrain->zphaser.res-1)) <= numfullsegments) {
838  numshots = epitrain->blipphaser.R;
839  } else {
840  numshots = numkyshots;
841  }
842  for (kyshot = 0; kyshot < numshots; kyshot++) {
843  for (readout = 0; readout < etl; readout++) {
844  shift = kyshot * (epitrain->blipphaser.R / numshots); /* ky shot shift */
845  shift = (shift + (kzview/epitrain->zphaser.R) * caipi_delta) % epitrain->blipphaser.R; /* CAIPIRINHA shift */
846  if (blipsign == KS_EPI_NEGBLIPS) {
847  kyview = epitrain->blipphaser.linetoacq[readout] + shift;
848  } else if (blipsign == KS_EPI_POSBLIPS) {
849  kyview = epitrain->blipphaser.linetoacq[(etl - 1) - readout] + shift;
850  } else {
851  return ks_error("%s: blipsign must be KS_EPI_POSBLIPS or KS_EPI_NEGBLIPS, not %d", __FUNCTION__, blipsign);
852  }
853  ks_phaseencoding_set(phaseenc_plan_ptr, readout, shot, kyview, kzview);
854  } /* readout */
855  shot++;
856  } /* kyshot */
857  } /* kzind */
858 
859  return SUCCESS;
860 
861 } /* ks_phaseencoding_generate_epi() */
ks_phaseencoding_set

◆ ks_calc_sliceplan()

STATUS ks_calc_sliceplan ( KS_SLICE_PLAN *  slice_plan,
int  nslices,
int  slperpass 
)

Calculates the data acquisition order for a standard interleaved 2D scans using one or more passes

This function calls ks_calc_slice_acquisition_order_interleaved() with the last argument being 2, indicating an interleave factor of 2. This will make odd slices in each pass to be acquired first, followed by the even slices.

Parameters
[out]slice_planThe slice plan (KS_SLICE_PLAN) set up earlier using ks_calc_sliceplan() or similar
[in]nslicesTotal number of slices (usually opslquant)
[in]slperpassNumber of slices per pass (i.e. per TR)
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
3429  {
3430 
3431  return ks_calc_sliceplan_interleaved(slice_plan, nslices, slperpass, 2);
3432 
3433 }
ks_calc_sliceplan_interleaved
STATUS ks_calc_sliceplan_interleaved(KS_SLICE_PLAN *slice_plan, int nslices, int slperpass, int inpass_interleaves)
Calculates the data acquisition order for custom interleaved 2D scans using one or more passes...
Definition: KSFoundation_host.c:3435

◆ ks_calc_sliceplan_interleaved()

STATUS ks_calc_sliceplan_interleaved ( KS_SLICE_PLAN *  slice_plan,
int  nslices,
int  slperpass,
int  inpass_interleaves 
)

Calculates the data acquisition order for custom interleaved 2D scans using one or more passes

The last argument to this function indicates the interleave factor of slices within each pass. If this value is

  • 1: The slices will be acquired in spatial order (within each pass)
  • 2: The odd slices will be acquired first, followed by the even slices in each pass (standard practice)
  • 3: etc.
Parameters
[out]slice_planPointer to the slice plan (KS_SLICE_PLAN) set up earlier using ks_calc_sliceplan() or similar
[in]nslicesTotal number of slices (usually opslquant)
[in]slperpassNumber of slices per pass (i.e. per TR)
[in]inpass_interleavesInterleave factor of slices in a pass
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
3435  {
3436 
3437  if (!slice_plan) {
3438  return ks_error("%s: invalid input, slice_plan is NULL", __FUNCTION__);
3439  }
3440 
3441  if (nslices <= 0 || slperpass <= 0 || inpass_interleaves <= 0) {
3442  return ks_error("%s: invalid input (nslices: %d, slperpass: %d, inpass_interleaves: %d)",
3443  __FUNCTION__, nslices, slperpass, inpass_interleaves);
3444  }
3445 
3446  slice_plan->nslices = nslices;
3447  slice_plan->nslices_per_pass = slperpass;
3448  slice_plan->npasses = CEIL_DIV(nslices, slperpass);
3449 
3450  int nslicesthispass[slice_plan->npasses];
3451  int sllocthispass[slice_plan->npasses][slperpass];
3452  int i, p, s, k, t, intleaves;
3453  /*
3454  - slice_plan->npasses: a.k.a. number of acquisitions (standard GE CV is: `acqs`)
3455  - slperpass: maximum number of slices in a pass (some passes may have fewer slices)
3456  - nslicesthispass[slice_plan->npasses]: Array where each element indicates how many slices to acquired in this pass
3457  - sllocthispass[slice_plan->npasses][slperpass]: Spatial location index into the prescribed slice stack, i.e. all slices
3458  for current pass and pass_sliceindx (spatially sorted)
3459  */
3460  for (p = 0; p < slice_plan->npasses; p++) {
3461  nslicesthispass[p] = 0;
3462  for (s = 0; s < slperpass; s++) {
3463  sllocthispass[p][s] = -1;
3464  if (s * slice_plan->npasses + p < nslices) {
3465  nslicesthispass[p]++;
3466  sllocthispass[p][s] = p + (s * slice_plan->npasses);
3467  }
3468  }
3469  }
3470 
3471  for (p = 0; p < slice_plan->npasses; p++) {
3472  t = 0; /* linearly increasing time index in current pass */
3473  for (intleaves = 0; intleaves < inpass_interleaves; intleaves++) {
3474  /* intleaves: slice interleaves *within* each pass */
3475  for (i = 0; i < CEIL_DIV(nslicesthispass[p], inpass_interleaves); i++) {
3476  k = intleaves + i * inpass_interleaves; /* pass_sliceindx */
3477  if (k < nslicesthispass[p]) {
3478  slice_plan->acq_order[sllocthispass[p][k]].slloc = sllocthispass[p][k]; /* Spatial location index into the prescribed slice stack */
3479  slice_plan->acq_order[sllocthispass[p][k]].slpass = p; /* pass index */
3480  slice_plan->acq_order[sllocthispass[p][k]].sltime = t++; /* time index in current pass. 0->nslicesthispass[p] */
3481  }
3482  }
3483  }
3484  }
3485 
3486  return SUCCESS;
3487 }
KS_SLICE_PLAN::acq_order
DATA_ACQ_ORDER acq_order[SLICE_FACTOR *DATA_ACQ_MAX]
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1203

◆ ks_calc_sliceplan_sms()

STATUS ks_calc_sliceplan_sms ( KS_SLICE_PLAN *  slice_plan,
int  nslices,
int  slperpass,
int  multiband_factor 
)

Calculates the data acquisition order for simulaneous-multi-slice (SMS)2D scans

Parameters
[out]slice_planThe slice plan (KS_SLICE_PLAN) set up earlier using ks_calc_sliceplan() or similar
[in]nslicesTotal number of slices (usually opslquant)
[in]slperpassNumber of slices per pass (i.e. per TR)
[in]multiband_factorNumber of SMS slices
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
3491  {
3492  int slices_per_stack, passes_per_stack;
3493  int i;
3494  STATUS status;
3495 
3496  /* sanitize the input */
3497  multiband_factor = multiband_factor < 1 ? 1 : multiband_factor;
3498  nslices = nslices < 0 ? 1 : nslices;
3499  slperpass = slperpass < 0 ? 1 : slperpass;
3500 
3501  if (slperpass > nslices)
3502  slperpass = nslices;
3503 
3504  /* no SMS?, fall back to standard slice plan */
3505  if (multiband_factor == 1) {
3506  status = ks_calc_sliceplan(slice_plan, nslices, slperpass);
3507  return status;
3508  }
3509 
3510  /* a 'stack' is a group of slices out of the prescribed slices (opslquant), where the #slices in the stack is equal to
3511  opslquant / multiband_factor. The stack does only cover 1/multiband_factor of the entire slice FOV (i.e. not interleaved).
3512  The exact number of slices in each stack is ceil(opslquant/multiband_factor), which may often lead to that more slices than
3513  prescribed need to be acquired for divisibility */
3514  slices_per_stack = CEIL_DIV(nslices, multiband_factor);
3515 
3516  /* number of passes per TR for one slice stack */
3517  passes_per_stack = CEIL_DIV(slices_per_stack, slperpass);
3518 
3519  if (passes_per_stack == 1) {
3520  /* we can fit all slices in the stack in 1 pass (acquisition), i.e. one TR. Do SMS-specific slice interleaving */
3521  ks_calc_slice_acquisition_order_smssingleacq(slice_plan->acq_order, slices_per_stack);
3522  } else {
3523  /* need 2+ acqs to acquire the 'slices_per_stack' slices. Do standard slice interleaving */
3524  ks_calc_sliceplan(slice_plan, slices_per_stack, slperpass);
3525  }
3526 
3527  /* copy to stacks 2->multiband_factor */
3528  slice_plan->nslices = slices_per_stack * multiband_factor;
3529  slice_plan->npasses = passes_per_stack * multiband_factor;
3530 
3531  for (i = slices_per_stack; i < slice_plan->nslices; i++) {
3532  int slice_in_stack = i % slices_per_stack;
3533  int stack = i / slices_per_stack;
3534  slice_plan->acq_order[i].slloc = i;
3535  slice_plan->acq_order[i].slpass = slice_plan->acq_order[slice_in_stack].slpass + stack * passes_per_stack;
3536  slice_plan->acq_order[i].sltime = slice_plan->acq_order[slice_in_stack].sltime;
3537  }
3538 
3539  return SUCCESS;
3540 }
KS_SLICE_PLAN::acq_order
DATA_ACQ_ORDER acq_order[SLICE_FACTOR *DATA_ACQ_MAX]
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1203
KS_SLICE_PLAN::npasses
int npasses
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1201

Calculates the data acquisition order for a standard interleaved 2D scans using one or more passes...
Definition: KSFoundation_host.c:3429

3607 
3608  return nslices % 2 ?
3609  ks_calc_slice_acquisition_order_smssingleacq_impl(dacq, nslices, 2) :
3610  ks_calc_slice_acquisition_order_smssingleacq_impl(dacq, nslices, 3);
3611 }

◆ ks_calc_sms_min_gap()

int ks_calc_sms_min_gap ( DATA_ACQ_ORDER *  dacq,
int  nslices 
)

Calculates the minimum time gap between adjacent slices in a SMS acquisition

Parameters
[out]dacqData acquisition order array (local)
[in]nslicesTotal number of slices prescribed
Return values
intThe minimum time gap between adjacent slices
3547  {
3548  int min_gap = nslices;
3549  int min_index = -1;
3550 
3551  int i;
3552  for (i=1; i<nslices; i++) {
3553  int gap = abs(dacq[i-1].sltime - dacq[i].sltime);
3554  if (gap < min_gap) {
3555  min_gap = gap;
3556  min_index = i-1;
3557  }
3558  }
3559 
3560  int last_to_first = nslices - dacq[nslices-1].sltime;
3561  if (last_to_first < min_gap) {
3562  min_gap = last_to_first;
3563  min_index = nslices-1;
3564  }
3565 
3566  return min_gap;
3567 }

3652  }

Writes a KS_WAVEFORM to disk with the specified filename

void
3658  {
3659 
3660  int i;
3661  FILE *asciiWaveFile;
3662  asciiWaveFile = fopen(filename, "w");
3663 
3664  if (asciiWaveFile == NULL) {
3665  return;
3666  }
3667

3669  fprintf(asciiWaveFile, "%d %f\n", i, waveform[i]); fflush(asciiWaveFile);

3671

3673 }

◆ ks_print_read()

void ks_print_read ( KS_READ  read,
FILE *  fp 
)

Writes out the contents of a KS_READ sequence object for debugging

If 2nd argument is stderr or stdout, the printed result will be seen in WTools for simulation. On the MR system, stderr will show up in one of the mgd_term windows. A file pointer (opened with e.g. fp = fopen("/usr/g/mrraw/myname.txt","w")) saves a text file to disk

Parameters
[in]readA KS_READ object to be printed
[in]fpA file pointer (or stderr)
Returns
void
3676  {
3677  if (a.description == NULL || a.duration == 0)
3678  return;
3679  fprintf(fp, "%s.duration: %d\n", a.description, a.duration);
3680  fprintf(fp, "%s.rbw: %g\n", a.description, a.rbw);
3681  fprintf(fp, "%s.filt.decimation: %g\n", a.description, a.filt.decimation);
3682  fprintf(fp, "%s.filt.tdaq: %d\n", a.description, a.filt.tdaq);
3683  fprintf(fp, "%s.filt.bw: %g\n", a.description , a.filt.bw);
3684  fprintf(fp, "%s.filt.tsp: %g\n", a.description, a.filt.tsp);
3685  fprintf(fp, "%s.filt.outputs: %d\n", a.description, a.filt.outputs);
3686  fprintf(fp, "%s.filt.prefills: %d\n", a.description, a.filt.prefills);
3687  fprintf(fp, "%s.filt.taps: %d\n", a.description, a.filt.taps);
3688  fflush(fp);
3689 }

◆ ks_print_selrf()

void ks_print_selrf ( KS_SELRF  selrf,

◆ ks_print_gradrfctrl()

void ks_print_gradrfctrl ( KS_GRADRFCTRL  gradrfctrl,
FILE *  fp 
)

Writes out the contents of KS_GRADRFCTRL for debugging

If 2nd argument is stderr or stdout, the printed result will be seen in WTools for simulation. On the MR system, stderr will show up in one of the mgd_term windows. A file pointer (opened with e.g. fp = fopen("/usr/g/mrraw/myname.txt","w")) saves a text file to disk

Parameters
[in]gradrfctrlA KS_GRADRFCTRL object to be printed
[in]fpA file pointer (or stderr)
Returns
void
3736  {
3737  int i;
3738 
3739  for (i = 0; i < gradrfctrl.numrf; i++) {
3740  fprintf(fp, "RF[%d] '%s': %d times\n", i, gradrfctrl.rfptr[i]->rfwave.description, gradrfctrl.rfptr[i]->rfwave.base.ninst);
3741  }
3742  for (i = 0; i < gradrfctrl.numtrap; i++) {
3743  fprintf(fp, "TRAP[%d] '%s': [%d, %d, %d] times on [X,Y,Z]\n", i, gradrfctrl.trapptr[i]->description, gradrfctrl.trapptr[i]->gradnum[XGRAD], gradrfctrl.trapptr[i]->gradnum[YGRAD], gradrfctrl.trapptr[i]->gradnum[ZGRAD]);
3744  }
3745  for (i = 0; i < gradrfctrl.numwave; i++) {
3746  fprintf(fp, "WAVE[%d] '%s': [%d, %d, %d] times on [X,Y,Z]\n", i, gradrfctrl.waveptr[i]->description, gradrfctrl.waveptr[i]->gradnum[XGRAD], gradrfctrl.waveptr[i]->gradnum[YGRAD], gradrfctrl.waveptr[i]->gradnum[ZGRAD]);

◆ ks_error()

STATUS ks_error ( const char *  format,
  ... 
)

Common error message function for HOST and TGT

  • On the MR-scanner, this function will append error messages with a timestamp to the file /usr/g/mrraw/ksf_errors.txt in addition to sending an epic_error(), which will show the error at the bottom of the UI
  • In simluation, the error message will be seen both in Evaltool and in the main WTools window
Parameters
[in]formatStandard C printf input arguments
Return values
STATUSReturns FAILURE

◆ ks_syslimits_ampmax()

float ks_syslimits_ampmax ( LOG_GRAD  loggrd)

Returns the maximum gradient amplitude that can be used on all gradient boards simultaneously

Since the waveform design (using ks_eval_***() functions) is separated from the placement of waveforms (using ks_pg_***() functions), the maximum gradient limit to use for gradient design must account for the least capable gradient board given the current slice angulation. ks_syslimits_ampmax() assumes that all gradients may be on simultaneously

The return value from this function can be passed in as ampmax to all ks_eval***_constrained() functions

Parameters
[in]loggrdGE's LOG_GRAD struct, dependent on the gradient system and current slice angulation
Return values
gradmaxMaximum gradient amplitude ([G/cm]) that can be used on all boards simultaneously
163  {
164  return (FMin(3, loggrd.tx_xyz, loggrd.ty_xyz, loggrd.tz_xyz));
165 }
loggrd
LOG_GRAD loggrd

◆ ks_syslimits_ampmax2()

float ks_syslimits_ampmax2 ( LOG_GRAD  loggrd)

Returns the maximum gradient amplitude that can be used on two gradient boards simultaneously

Since the waveform design (using ks_eval_***() functions) is separated from the placement of waveforms (using ks_pg_***() functions), the maximum gradient limit to use for gradient design must account for the least capable gradient board given the current slice angulation. ks_syslimits_ampmax2() assumes that gradients are played out on at most one more board at the same time as the current trapezoid

The return value from this function can be passed in as ampmax to all ks_eval***_constrained() functions

Parameters
[in]loggrdGE's LOG_GRAD struct, dependent on the gradient system and current slice angulation
Return values
gradmaxMaximum gradient amplitude ([G/cm]) that can be used on 2 boards simultaneously
167  {
168  return (FMin(6, loggrd.tx_xy, loggrd.tx_xz, loggrd.ty_xy, loggrd.ty_yz, loggrd.tz_xz, loggrd.tz_yz));
169 }
loggrd
LOG_GRAD loggrd

◆ ks_syslimits_ampmax1()

float ks_syslimits_ampmax1 ( LOG_GRAD  loggrd)

Returns the maximum gradient amplitude that can be used on all gradient boards simultaneously

Since the waveform design (using ks_eval_***() functions) is separated from the placement of waveforms (using ks_pg_***() functions), the maximum gradient limit to use for gradient design must account for the least capable gradient board given the current slice angulation. ks_syslimits_ampmax1() assumes that no other gradient is played out on another board at the same time as the current trapezoid

The return value from this function can be passed in as ampmax to all ks_eval***_constrained() functions

Parameters
[in]loggrdGE's LOG_GRAD struct, dependent on the gradient system and current slice angulation
Return values
gradmaxMaximum gradient amplitude ([G/cm]) that can be used on 2 boards simultaneously
171  {
172  return (FMin(3, loggrd.tx, loggrd.ty, loggrd.tz));
173 }
loggrd
LOG_GRAD loggrd

◆ ks_syslimits_slewrate()

float ks_syslimits_slewrate ( LOG_GRAD  loggrd)

Returns the maximum slewrate that can be used on all gradient boards simultaneously

The return value from this function is the ratio of ks_syslimits_ampmax() and ks_syslimits_ramptimemax() and can be passed in as slewrate to all ks_eval***_constrained() functions

Parameters
[in]loggrdGE's LOG_GRAD struct, dependent on the gradient system and current slice angulation
Return values
slewrateMaximum slewrate ([(G/cm) / us]) that can be used on all boards simultaneously
196  {
197  return (ks_syslimits_ampmax(loggrd) / ks_syslimits_ramptimemax(loggrd));
198 }
loggrd

◆ ks_syslimits_gradtarget()

float ks_syslimits_gradtarget ( LOG_GRAD  loggrd,
WF_PROCESSOR  board 
)

Returns the maximum target amplitude for a board (internal use)

For gradient boards, the field .tx, .ty or .tz is returned. For non-gradient boards, 1.0 is returned. This function is used internally by ks_pg_***() functions and there should be no need to call it directly.

Parameters
[in]loggrdGE's LOG_GRAD struct, dependent on the gradient system and current slice angulation
[in]boardThe board on which the current trapezoid or waveform is to be played out on
Return values
gradampMaximum target amplitude for a board
176  {
177  switch (board) {
178  case XGRAD:
179  return loggrd.tx;
180  case YGRAD:
181  return loggrd.ty;
182  case ZGRAD:
183  return loggrd.tz;
184  default:
185  return 1.0;
186  }
187 }
loggrd
LOG_GRAD loggrd

◆ ks_phase_radians2hw()

short ks_phase_radians2hw ( float  radphase)

Returns the integer phase (not in use)

All phase values in KSFoundation are in [degrees], including flip angles, RF/receive phases and THETA waveforms. This function is therefore currently not used. See instead ks_phase_degrees2hw()

Parameters
[in]radphasePhase in radians
Return values
intphaseInteger phase to use on THETA board on hardware
209  {
210  short iphase;
211  UINT uiphase;
212  double dphase = (double) phase;
213  double twopi = (double) 2.0 * PI;
214 
215  /* Resolve angle to lie within range ( -2*pi <= dphase < 2*pi ) */
216  dphase = fmod(dphase, twopi);
217 
218  /* Find the equivalent positive angle */
219  if (dphase < 0.0)
220  dphase = twopi + dphase;
221 
222  /* Convert the angle to exciter DDS phase representation where only the
223  upper 14 bits of 16 are used */
224  uiphase = (UINT) (dphase * 16384.0 / twopi + 0.5);
225  if (uiphase == 16384)
226  uiphase = 0;
227 
228  /* left shift the result by 2 bits */
229  iphase = (short) (uiphase << 2);
230 
231  return iphase;
232 }

◆ ks_phase_degrees2hw()

short ks_phase_degrees2hw ( float  degphase)

Returns the integer phase (internal use)

All phase values in KSFoundation are in [degrees], including flip angles, RF/receive phases and THETA waveforms. This function is used internally by another internal function ks_wave2iwave(), which is in turn called by ks_pg_wave()

Parameters
[in]degphasePhase in degrees
Return values
intphaseInteger phase to use on THETA board on hardware
234  {
235 
236  return ks_phase_radians2hw(phase * PI / 180.0);
237 }
ks_phase_radians2hw
short ks_phase_radians2hw(float phase)
Returns the integer phase (not in use)
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:209

◆ ks_calc_selgradamp()

float ks_calc_selgradamp ( float  rfbw,
float  slthick 
)

Returns the gradient amplitude in [G/cm] necessary for slice selection (internal use)

Given an RF bandwidth in [Hz] and a slice thickness in [mm], this function calculates the gradient strength in [G/cm] necessary to produce a slice with the given slice thickness

This function is used by ks_eval_seltrap(), ks_eval_selrf_constrained() and ks_scan_selrf_setfreqphase()

Parameters
[in]rfbwThe bandwidth of the RF pulse to use with the gradient
[in]slthickThe desired slice thickness in [mm]
Return values
gradampGradient amplitude to use [G/cm]
242  {
243 
244  if (slthick > 0 && rfbw > 0)
245  return (rfbw / (GAM * slthick / 10.0));
246  else
247  return 0.0; /* return zero amp if requested slice thickness is <= 0 */
248 }
GAM
float GAM

◆ ks_wave_res()

int ks_wave_res ( const KS_WAVE *  wave)

Returns the number of samples in a KS_WAVE sequence object

Parameters
[in]waveKS_WAVE object
Return values
resResolution (i.e. number of samples) in the KS_WAVE object
869  {
870 
871  if (wave == NULL) {
872  ks_error("ks_wave_res: wave is NULL");
873  return KS_NOTSET;
874  }
875  if (wave->description == NULL || wave->description[0] == ' ') {
876  ks_error("ks_wave_res: wave description not initialized or has leading space");
877  return KS_NOTSET;
878  }
879  if (wave->res < 2 || wave->res > KS_MAXWAVELEN) {
880  ks_error("ks_wave_res(%s): 'res' (%d) is out of valid range [2, %d]", wave->description, wave->res, KS_MAXWAVELEN);
881  return KS_NOTSET;
882  }
883  if (wave->res % 2) {
884  ks_error("ks_wave_res(%s): 'res' (%d) must be even", wave->description, wave->res);
885  return KS_NOTSET;
886  }
887 
888  return wave->res;
889 }
KS_NOTSET
#define KS_NOTSET

◆ ks_waveform_max()

float ks_waveform_max ( const KS_WAVEFORM  waveform,
int  res 
)

Returns the maximum value in a KS_WAVEFORM

Parameters
[in]waveformKS_WAVEFORM (float array)
[in]resResolution (i.e. number of samples) in the KS_WAVEFORM
Return values
maxvalMaximum value
892  {
893  float maxv = -1.0e38;
894  int i;
895 
896  if (waveform == NULL) {
897  ks_error("ks_waveform_max: wave is NULL");
898  return maxv;
899  }
900  if (res <= 0) {
901  return maxv;
902  }
903 
904  for (i = 0; i < res; i++) {
905  if (waveform[i] > maxv)
906  maxv = waveform[i];
907  }
908 
909  return maxv;
910 }

◆ ks_waveform_area()

float ks_waveform_area ( const KS_WAVEFORM  waveform,
int  start,
int  end,
int  dwelltime 
)

Returns the area of a KS_WAVEFORM over a specified interval given in [us]

Parameters
[in]waveformKS_WAVEFORM (float array)
[in]start[us] Start position of area calculation in [us] (0 = start of waveform)
[in]end[us] End position of area calculation in [us] (res * dwelltime = end of waveform)
[in]dwelltime[us] of each waveform point (duration/res)
Return values
areaThe area of the KS_WAVEFORM over the specified interval in [(G/cm) * us]
991  {
992  int i;
993  double area = 0;
994  int start_indx = CEIL_DIV(start, dwelltime);
995  int end_indx = end / dwelltime;
996 
997  if (waveform == NULL) {
998  ks_error("%s: wave is NULL", __FUNCTION__);
999  }
1000  if (start_indx < 0) {
1001  ks_error("%s: start must be >= 0", __FUNCTION__);
1002  }
1003  if (end_indx > KS_MAXWAVELEN) {
1004  ks_error("%s: end cannot exceed %d", __FUNCTION__, KS_MAXWAVELEN);
1005  }
1006 
1007  for (i = start_indx; i < end_indx; i++) {
1008  area += waveform[i] * dwelltime;
1009  }
1010 
1011  /* add potential partial dwell time due to CEIL_DIV, when start [us] is not divisible by dwelltime */
1012  if ((start_indx * dwelltime) > start && start_indx > 0) {
1013  area += waveform[start_indx - 1] * (((double) start_indx * dwelltime) - (double) start);
1014  }
1015 
1016  /* add potential partial dwell time due to (floor) integer division, when end [us] is not divisible by dwelltime */
1017  if ((end_indx * dwelltime) < end && (end_indx < (KS_MAXWAVELEN - 1))) {
1018  area += waveform[end_indx + 1] * ((double) end - ((double) end_indx * dwelltime));
1019  }
1020 
1021  return ((float) area);
1022 }
ks_error
STATUS ks_error(const char *format,...)
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:49
KS_MAXWAVELEN
#define KS_MAXWAVELEN
Definition: KSFoundation.h:113

◆ ks_wave_area()

float ks_wave_area ( const KS_WAVE *  wave,
int  start,
int  end 
)

Returns the area of a KS_WAVE object over a specified interval given in [us]

Parameters
[in]waveKS_WAVE object
[in]start[us] Start position of area calculation in [us] (0 = start of waveform)
[in]end[us] End position of area calculation in us
Return values
areaThe area of the KS_WAVE object over the specified interval in [(G/cm) * us]
1024  {
1025  int dwelltime = wave->duration / wave->res;
1026  return ks_waveform_area(wave->waveform, start, end, dwelltime);
1027 }

1032  double sum = 0;
1033 
1034  if (waveform == NULL) {
1035  ks_error("ks_waveform_sum: wave is NULL");
1036  }
1037  if (res <= 0) {
1038  ks_error("ks_waveform_sum: res must be positive");
1039  }
1040

1042  sum += waveform[i];
1043  }

◆ ks_waveform_norm()

float ks_waveform_norm ( const KS_WAVEFORM  waveform,
int  res 
)

Returns the 2-norm of a KS_WAVEFORM

Parameters
[in]waveformKS_WAVEFORM (float array)
[in]resResolution (i.e. number of samples) in the KS_WAVEFORM
Return values
norm2The 2-norm of a KS_WAVEFORM
1053  {
1054  int i;
1055  double sum = 0;
1056 
1057  if (waveform == NULL) {
1058  ks_error("ks_waveform_norm: wave is NULL");
1059  }
1060  if (res <= 0) {
1061  ks_error("ks_waveform_norm: res must be positive");
1062  }
1063 
1064  for (i = 0; i < res; i++) {
1065  sum += pow(fabs(waveform[i]), 2.0);
1066  }
1067 
1068  return (float)sqrt(sum);
1069 }

void ks_waveform_cumsum ( KS_WAVEFORM  cumsumwaveform,

)

1080

1084  }

◆ ks_waveform2iwave()

STATUS ks_waveform2iwave ( KS_IWAVE  iwave,
const KS_WAVEFORM  waveform,
int  res,
int  board 
)

(Internal use) Conversion of a KS_WAVEFORM to a short int array for use on hardware

This function is used internally by ks_pg_wave() and there should be no need to call this function directly.

For all boards except THETA, this function auto-scales the (float) values in KS_WAVEFORM so that the maximum absolute value becomes +/- 32766. The output short int (KS_IWAVE) array is to be copied to hardware. For a KS_WAVEFORM on the THETA board, the necessary phase wraps and scaling to short int format is performed using ks_phase_degrees2hw(). GE's requirement of only having even numbers in the waveform except for a final odd value (end-of-waveform) is also taken care of here

Note that the preservation of the physical units are done in ks_pg_wave() by setting the correct instruction amplitude to multiply this auto-scaled waveform with in the sequence's hardware memory

Parameters
[out]iwaveKS_IWAVE (short int array)
[in]waveformKS_WAVEFORM
[in]resResolution (i.e. number of samples) in the KS_WAVEFORM
[in]boardOne of XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD, RHO, THETA, OMEGA
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1155  {
1156  int i;
1157 
1158  if (board != THETA) {
1159  float absmax = ks_waveform_absmax(waveform, res);
1160  for (i = 0; i < res; i++) {
1161  iwave[i] = ((short) (max_pg_wamp * waveform[i] / absmax)) & ~WEOS_BIT;
1162  }
1163  } else {
1164  for (i = 0; i < res; i++) {
1165  iwave[i] = ((short) ks_phase_degrees2hw(waveform[i])) & ~WEOS_BIT;
1166  }
1167  }
1168 
1169  /* set end-of-waveform flag */
1170  iwave[res - 1] |= WEOS_BIT;
1171 
1172  return SUCCESS;
1173 
1174 } /* ks_wave2iwave() */
ks_waveform_absmax
float ks_waveform_absmax(const KS_WAVEFORM waveform, int res)
Returns the maximum absolute value in a KS_WAVEFORM
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:965
ks_phase_degrees2hw
short ks_phase_degrees2hw(float phase)
Returns the integer phase (internal use)
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:234

◆ ks_wave2iwave()

STATUS ks_wave2iwave ( KS_IWAVE  iwave,
const KS_WAVE *  wave,
int  board 
)

(Internal use) Conversion of waveform content in a KS_WAVE sequence object to a short int array for use on hardware

This function is used internally by ks_pg_wave() and there should be no need to call this function directly.

For all boards except THETA, this function auto-scales the (float) values in the .waveform[] field so that the maximum absolute value becomes +/- 32766. The output short int (KS_IWAVE) array is to be copied to hardware. For a KS_WAVE on the THETA board, the necessary phase wraps and scaling to short int format is performed using ks_phase_degrees2hw(). GE's requirement of only having even numbers in the waveform except for a final odd value (end-of-waveform) is also taken care of here

Note that the preservation of the physical units are done in ks_pg_wave() by setting the correct instruction amplitude to multiply this auto-scaled waveform with in the sequence's hardware memory

Parameters
[out]iwaveKS_IWAVE (short int array)
[in]waveKS_WAVE
[in]boardOne of XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD, RHO, THETA, OMEGA
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1177  {
1178  return ks_waveform2iwave(iwave, wave->waveform, wave->res, board);
1179 }

Return values
wfptrPointer to a WF_PULSE
1195  {
1196 
1197  if (!strcmp(suffix, "xtr")) {
1198  return echo->assoc_pulse;
1199  } else if (!strcmp(suffix, "rba")) {
1200  return echo->assoc_pulse->assoc_pulse;
1201  } else {
1202  return echo;
1203  }
1204 
1205 }

◆ ks_pg_trap()

STATUS ks_pg_trap ( KS_TRAP *  trap,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places a KS_TRAP sequence object on a board at some position in the pulse sequence

This function should be called in the @pg section to place out a KS_TRAP sequence object that creates a static trapezoid in the pulse sequence. The same KS_TRAP object can be freely placed on XGRAD, YGRAD and ZGRAD as many times as desired, by only changing the second argument each time (to avoid waveform overlaps). The second argument is a KS_SEQLOC struct with three fields:

  • .board: Choose between XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD (or OMEGA)
  • .pos: Absolute time in [us] of the start of the attack ramp of the trapezoid
  • .ampscale: A factor that must be in range [-1.0,1.0] that is multiplied with .amp to yield a per-instance (i.e. per-placement) amplitude ([G/cm]). The simplest is to use 1.0, which makes the KS_TRAP object to be placed out on the board as initially designed using ks_eval_trap(). For the OMEGA board, this factor must be 1.0.

Regardless of the order placed out in the @pg section, and on which boards (XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD) the KS_TRAP object is placed, the instance number of the KS_TRAP is automatically sorted in time. If two instances of one KS_TRAP occur at the same time (.pos) on different boards, XGRAD comes before YGRAD, which comes before ZGRAD. These abstract, sorted, instance numbers are used by ks_scan_***() functions in scan() to refer to a specific instance of a KS_TRAP object in the sequence

If the .duration field in the KS_TRAP object is 0, ks_pg_trap() will return SUCCESS and quietly ignore placing it out. This is a part of the mechanism that setting the .duration field to 0 in cveval() should eliminate its existance in both timing calulations and in the pulse sequence generation in @pg

When a trapezoid is placed on OMEGA, neither the designed amplitude (the .amp field in KS_TRAP) nor the .ampscale (in KS_SEQLOC) has an effect on the final frequency modulation. Instead the run-time amplitude of a KS_TRAP object on the OMEGA board is controlled in scan() via a function called ks_scan_omegatrap_hz()

GENERAL NOTE: It is a requirement that the function in the @pg section containing all ks_pg_***() calls is also called exactly once in cveval() after the calls to the corresponding ks_eval_***() functions that design the KS_*** sequence objects. Each ks_pg_***() will throw an error if this has not been done.

Parameters
[in,out]trapPointer to a KS_TRAP sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when and where to place the KS_TRAP
[in,out]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_TRAP
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1212  {
1213  float boardmax;
1214  char boardc[7] = "xyz---o";
1215 
1216  boardmax = ks_syslimits_gradtarget(loggrd, loc.board); /* returns 1.0 for OMEGA board */
1217 
1218  /* checking for NULL pointers */
1219  if (trap == NULL) {
1220  return ks_error("ks_pg_trap: First argument is NULL");
1221  }
1222  /* duration of 0 should not throw an error as this is a sign of that it has not been set up
1223  or has manually been disabled this way */
1224  if (trap->duration == 0) {
1225  return SUCCESS;
1226  }
1227 
1228  if (trap->description == NULL || trap->description[0] == 0 || trap->description[0] == ' ') {
1229  return ks_error("ks_pg_trap: Invalid description ('%s')", trap->description);
1230  }
1231 
1232 #ifdef IPG
1233  /* TGT: Don't place anything on hardware if ctrl->duration = 0.
1234  This is in concert with:
1235  - not performing createseq() in KS_SEQLENGTH if seqctrl.duration = 0
1236  - not playing sequence modules in scan() using ks_scan_playsequence() if seqctrl.duration = 0
1237  */
1238  if (ctrl->duration == 0) {
1239  return ks_error("%s(%s): Refusing to place trap since seqctrl.duration = 0 (indicating `%s` not to be played in scan())", __FUNCTION__, trap->description, ctrl->description);
1240  }
1241 #endif
1242 
1243  /* input validation */
1244  if ((trap->ramptime % 4) || (trap->plateautime % 4) || (trap->duration % 4)) {
1245  ks_error("ks_pg_trap(%s): All timing parameters must be divisible by 4", trap->description);
1246  return FAILURE;
1247  }
1248 
1249  if ((trap->ramptime < 4) || (trap->plateautime < 4) || (trap->duration < 4)) {
1250  ks_error("ks_pg_trap(%s): All timing parameters must be at least 4 us", trap->description);
1251  return FAILURE;
1252  }
1253 
1254  if (loc.ampscale != loc.ampscale) {
1255  return ks_error("ks_pg_trap(%s): loc.ampscale NaN", trap->description);
1256  }
1257  if (loc.pos != loc.pos) {
1258  return ks_error("ks_pg_trap(%s): loc.pos NaN", trap->description);
1259  }
1260  if (loc.board != loc.board) {
1261  return ks_error("ks_pg_trap(%s): loc.board NaN", trap->description);
1262  }
1263 
1264  if (loc.pos < GRAD_UPDATE_TIME || loc.pos > 4e6) {
1265  ks_error("ks_pg_trap(%s): Invalid position %d, it must be between 4us and 4s", trap->description, loc.pos);
1266  return FAILURE;
1267  }
1268 
1269  if (loc.board == OMEGA && loc.ampscale != 1.0) {
1270  return ks_error("ks_pg_trap(%s): ampscale must be +1.0 for OMEGA", trap->description);
1271  }
1272 
1273  if (loc.ampscale < -1.0 || loc.ampscale > 1.0) {
1274  ks_error("ks_pg_trap(%s): Invalid ampscale %g, it must be between -1.0 and 1.0", trap->description, loc.ampscale);
1275  return FAILURE;
1276  }
1277 
1278  if (loc.board != XGRAD && loc.board != YGRAD && loc.board != ZGRAD && loc.board != OMEGA) {
1279  ks_error("ks_pg_trap(%s): Invalid board code %d, it must be %d (XGRAD), %d (YGRAD), %d (ZGRAD) or %d (OMEGA)", trap->description, loc.board, XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD, OMEGA);
1280  return FAILURE;
1281  }
1282 
1283  if (fabs(trap->amp * loc.ampscale) > boardmax) {
1284  ks_error("ks_pg_trap(%s): trapezoid amplitude %g exceeds maximum (%g) for board %c", trap->description, trap->amp * loc.ampscale, boardmax, boardc[loc.board]);
1285  return FAILURE;
1286  }
1287 
1288  loc.pos = RUP_GRD(loc.pos);
1289 
1290 #ifdef IPG
1291  {
1292 
1293  int i;
1294 
1295  char tmpstr[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 7];
1296  tmpstr[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 7 - 1] = 0;
1297 
1298  if (trap->base.ngenerated >= trap->base.ninst) {
1299  ks_error("ks_pg_trap @tgt(%s): the number of instances generated on the target exceeds the number of ones generated on the host", trap->description);
1300  return FAILURE;
1301  }
1302 
1303  if (!ctrl->gradrf.is_cleared_on_tgt) /* Reset gradrfctrl on tgt to remove dead pointers copied from host. */
1304  {
1305  ks_tgt_reset_gradrfctrl(&ctrl->gradrf);
1306  }
1307 
1308  /* TODO: consider freeing memory if ngenerated is zero -- EA */
1309 
1310  if (trap->wfpulse == NULL) {
1311  WF_PULSE wfInit = INITPULSE;
1312 
1313  trap->wfpulse = (WF_PULSE **) AllocNode(8 * sizeof(WF_PULSE *)); /* X, Y, Z, (OMEGA = 6). Not applicable to other boards */
1314 
1315  for (i = XGRAD; i <= OMEGA; i++) {
1316 
1317  if (i == XGRAD || i == YGRAD || i == ZGRAD || i == OMEGA) {
1318 
1319  trap->wfpulse[i] = (WF_PULSE *) AllocNode(3 * sizeof(WF_PULSE)); /* attack, plateau, decay */
1320 
1321  /* init pulse structure */
1322  trap->wfpulse[i][G_ATTACK] = wfInit;
1323  trap->wfpulse[i][G_PLATEAU] = wfInit;
1324  trap->wfpulse[i][G_DECAY] = wfInit;
1325 
1326  /* Name for WF_PULSEs */
1327  sprintf(tmpstr, "%s.%ca", trap->description, boardc[i]); pulsename(&(trap->wfpulse[i][G_ATTACK]), tmpstr);
1328  sprintf(tmpstr, "%s.%c", trap->description, boardc[i]); pulsename(&(trap->wfpulse[i][G_PLATEAU]), tmpstr);
1329  sprintf(tmpstr, "%s.%cd", trap->description, boardc[i]); pulsename(&(trap->wfpulse[i][G_DECAY]), tmpstr);
1330 
1331  createramp(&(trap->wfpulse[i][G_ATTACK]), i, trap->ramptime, 0, max_pg_wamp,
1332  maxGradRes * (trap->ramptime / GRAD_UPDATE_TIME), 1.0);
1333  createconst(&(trap->wfpulse[i][G_PLATEAU]), i, trap->plateautime, max_pg_wamp);
1334  createramp(&(trap->wfpulse[i][G_DECAY]), i, trap->ramptime, max_pg_wamp, 0,
1335  maxGradRes * (trap->ramptime / GRAD_UPDATE_TIME), 1.0);
1336 
1337  linkpulses(3, &(trap->wfpulse[i][G_PLATEAU]), &(trap->wfpulse[i][G_ATTACK]), &(trap->wfpulse[i][G_DECAY]));
1338 
1339  } else {
1340 
1341  trap->wfpulse[i] = NULL;
1342 
1343  }
1344 
1345  } /* per board */
1346 
1347  } /* wfpulse == NULL */
1348 
1349 
1350  /* allocate the array of WFINSTANCE's if needed */
1351  if (!trap->wfi) {
1352  trap->wfi = (KS_WFINSTANCE *) AllocNode(trap->base.ninst * sizeof(KS_WFINSTANCE));
1353  }
1354 
1355  /* Set instruction amplitudes at the proper position and board */
1356  {
1357  const int corrected_pos = loc.pos + (loc.board == OMEGA)*psd_rf_wait;
1358  /* creating new instructions */
1359  createinstr(&(trap->wfpulse[loc.board][G_ATTACK]),
1360  corrected_pos,
1361  trap->ramptime,
1362  trap->amp * loc.ampscale * MAX_PG_IAMP / boardmax);
1363  createinstr(&(trap->wfpulse[loc.board][G_PLATEAU]),
1364  corrected_pos + trap->ramptime,
1365  trap->plateautime,
1366  trap->amp * loc.ampscale * MAX_PG_IAMP / boardmax);
1367  createinstr(&(trap->wfpulse[loc.board][G_DECAY]),
1368  corrected_pos + trap->ramptime + trap->plateautime,
1369  trap->ramptime,
1370  trap->amp * loc.ampscale * MAX_PG_IAMP / boardmax);
1371  }
1372 
1373  /* initializing the corresponding KS_WFINSTANCE */
1374  trap->wfi[trap->base.ngenerated].boardinstance = trap->wfpulse[loc.board][G_PLATEAU].ninsts - 1; /* zero based */
1375  trap->wfi[trap->base.ngenerated].wf = &(trap->wfpulse[loc.board][G_PLATEAU]);
1376  trap->wfi[trap->base.ngenerated].loc = loc;
1377 
1378  trap->base.ngenerated++;
1379 
1380  /* sort after the last instance is generated */
1381  if (trap->base.ngenerated == trap->base.ninst) {
1382  ks_sort_wfi_by_timeboard(trap->wfi, trap->base.ninst);
1383  }
1384  }
1385 #else /* TGT(IPG) or HOST */
1386  {
1387  /* HOST */
1388 
1389  trap->locs[trap->base.ninst] = loc;
1390 
1391  /* update instance counter on host only. This counter is used to allocate the right amount of WFINSTANCEs on IPG */
1392  trap->base.ninst++;
1393 
1394  /* for trap, we also need to keep track of #instances per X, Y, Z for gradient heating calculations.
1395  As this needs to be done in HOST before the IPG (target), we can't use the wfi[...].boardinstance or .loc information above for this */
1396  if (loc.board == XGRAD || loc.board == YGRAD || loc.board == ZGRAD)
1397  trap->gradnum[loc.board]++;
1398  }
1399 
1400 #endif /* IPG */
1401  /* register this KS_TRAP for later heating calculations */
1402  {
1403  STATUS status = ks_eval_addtraptogradrfctrl(&ctrl->gradrf, trap);
1404  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1405  }
1406  return SUCCESS;
1407 
1408 } /* ks_pg_trap */
ks_eval_addtraptogradrfctrl
STATUS ks_eval_addtraptogradrfctrl(KS_GRADRFCTRL *gradrfctrl, KS_TRAP *trap)
*Internal use*. Adds a trapezoid (KS_TRAP) to the KS_GRADRFCTRL struct for later gradient heating cal...
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:3437

KS_TRAP::gradnum

Definition: KSFoundation.h:435

◆ ks_pg_read()

STATUS ks_pg_read ( KS_READ *  read,
int  pos,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places a KS_READ sequence object at some position in the pulse sequence

This function should be called in the @pg section to place out a KS_READ sequence object that creates an acquisition window in the pulse sequence. The same KS_READ object can be freely placed as many times as desired, by only changing the second argument each time (to avoid overlaps). The second argument is an integer with the absolute time in [us] of the start of the acquisition. System gradient delays are accounted for in ks_pg_read() by internally adjusting the position by adding the system variable psd_grd_wait to the position value. This assures the gradients boards and acquisition window are in sync on the MR system.

Regardless of the order the acquisition windows are placed out in the @pg section, the instance number of the KS_READ is automatically sorted in time

If the .duration field in the KS_READ object is 0, ks_pg_read() will return SUCCESS and quietly ignore placing it out. This is a part of the mechanism that setting the .duration field to 0 in cveval() should eliminate its existance in both timing calulations and in the pulse sequence generation in @pg

GENERAL NOTE: It is a requirement that the function in the @pg section containing all ks_pg_***() calls is also called exactly once in cveval() after the calls to the corresponding ks_eval_***() functions that design the KS_*** sequence objects. Each ks_pg_***() will throw an error if this has not been done.

Parameters
[in,out]readPointer to a KS_READ sequence object
[in]posAbsolute time in [us] when to start data acquisition
[in,out]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_READ
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1431  {
1432 #ifdef IPG
1433  int acqwin_start;
1434  int placementindx;
1435  long dab_pos;
1436  char tmpstr[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 7];
1437 #endif
1438  STATUS status;
1439 
1440  /* duration of 0 should not throw an error as this is a sign of that it has not been set up or has manually been disabled this way */
1441  if (read->duration == 0) {
1442  return SUCCESS;
1443  }
1444 
1445 #ifdef IPG
1446  {
1447  tmpstr[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 7 - 1] = 0;
1448 
1449  if (read->base.ngenerated >= read->base.ninst) {
1450  ks_error("ks_pg_read @tgt(%s): the number of instances generated on the target exceeds the number of ones generated on the host", read->description);
1451  return FAILURE;
1452  }
1453 
1454  if (!ctrl->gradrf.is_cleared_on_tgt) { /* Reset gradrfctrl on tgt to remove dead pointers copied from host. */
1455  ks_tgt_reset_gradrfctrl(&ctrl->gradrf);
1456  }
1457 
1458  if (read->echo == NULL) {
1459  /* this relies on that we have run the sequence in cveval() (i.e. on host) before to get proper grad.ninst */
1460  read->echo = (WF_PULSE *) AllocNode(read->base.ninst * sizeof(WF_PULSE));
1461  }
1462 
1463  placementindx = read->base.ngenerated; /* not sorted in time, but in placement order */
1464 
1465  acqwin_start = pos + psd_grd_wait;
1466 
1467  if (placementindx == 0 || read->filt.tdaq > 200) {
1468  dab_pos = DEFAULTPOS; /* results in 200 us before RBA (DEFAULTPOS is defined as 0. See: /ESE_.../psd/include/private/pulsegen.h) */
1469  } else {
1470  /* For small matrix sizes, the acq window is so short that the DAB packet
1471  for current lobe may collide with the RBA belonging to the previous lobe.
1472  We are not allowed to decrease the DAB-RBA distance below 200us. Instead,
1473  let's put it right after the end of the previous XTR pulse.
1474  With the default XTR-RBA offset of 143us, and since the RBA-RBA distance
1475  is equal to read->grad.duration, we will get a DAB-RBA offset of
1476  acqwin_duration + 143us - 17us (XTR duration)
1477  */
1478  dab_pos = pbegallssp(ks_pg_echossp(&read->echo[placementindx - 1], "xtr"), 0) + 17;
1479  if (dab_pos + 200 > acqwin_start)
1480  dab_pos = DEFAULTPOS; /* fallback to default pos. Perhaps the readouts were not placed out in time order in the PSD ? */
1481  }
1482 
1483  /* name the ACQ pulse */
1484  sprintf(tmpstr, "%s%03d", read->description, placementindx); pulsename(&(read->echo[placementindx]), tmpstr);
1485 
1486  if (read->filt.fslot == KS_NOTSET) {
1487  /* add 'return' before ks_error once we've got an answer from GE regarding acqq and setrfltrs() */
1488  ks_error("ks_pg_read @tgt(%s): WARNING no filter slot assigned. First run setfilter(&read.filt)", read->description);
1489  }
1490 
1491  /* place the ACQ pulse */
1492  acqq(&(read->echo[placementindx]),
1493  (long) acqwin_start,
1494  (long) dab_pos, /* DAB */
1495  (long) DEFAULTPOS, /* XTR */
1496  read->filt.fslot, /* filter slot */
1497  (TYPDAB_PACKETS) DABNORM);
1498 
1499  read->base.ngenerated++;
1500 
1501  /* sort after the last instance is generated */
1502  if (read->base.ngenerated == read->base.ninst) {
1503  ks_sort_wfp_by_time(read->echo, read->base.ninst);
1504  }
1505 
1506  /* Associate this echo with a global filter slot number
1507  This number is generated by the GE function setfilter() in e.g. predownload(), before this function is called.
1508  For main sequences, there is also the wrapper function GEReq_predownload_setfilter() */
1509  if (read->filt.fslot >= 0 && read->filt.fslot <= MAX_FILTER_SLOT) {
1510  setrfltrs((int) read->filt.fslot, &(read->echo[placementindx]));
1511  }
1512 
1513  }
1514 #else /* IPG */
1515  {
1516  read->pos[read->base.ninst] = pos;
1517  read->base.ninst++; /* update acq counter on host */
1518  }
1519 #endif /* IPG */
1520 
1521  status = ks_eval_addreadtogradrfctrl(&ctrl->gradrf, read);
1522  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1523  return SUCCESS;
1524 }
KS_READ::echo
WF_PULSE * echo
Definition: KSFoundation.h:587

Sort WF_PULSEs in time

KS_NOTSET
#define KS_NOTSET

int ninst

*Internal use*. Adds an acquisition to the KS_GRADRFCTRL struct. Used for plotting
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:3521

◆ ks_pg_phaser()

STATUS ks_pg_phaser ( KS_PHASER *  phaser,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places a KS_PHASER sequence object on a board at some position in the pulse sequence

This function should be called in the @pg section to place out a KS_PHASER sequence object that creates a dynamic trapezoid for phase encoding. For 3D applications, two different KS_PHASER objects should have been designed by calling ks_eval_phaser() on each KS_PHASER as FOV and resolution typically differ for the two phase encoding directions. The same KS_PHASER object can be freely placed on XGRAD, YGRAD and ZGRAD as many times as desired, by only changing the second argument each time (to avoid waveform overlaps). For Cartesian applications, phase encoding gradients such as KS_PHASER are typically placed out on YGRAD (phase encoding axis), for 3D also on ZGRAD. For 3D, the KS_PHASER object may embed a slice rephaser (static trapezoid) by setting .areaoffset to a non-zero value (see ks_eval_phaser()). The second argument is a KS_SEQLOC struct with three fields:

  • .board: Choose between XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD
  • .pos: Absolute time in [us] of the start of the attack ramp of the phase encoding trapezoid
  • .ampscale: For KS_PHASER objects, this must be 1.0. If not, ks_pg_phaser() will throw an error. Amplitude control should solely be done in scan using ks_scan_phaser_toline() and ks_scan_phaser_fromline().

Regardless of the order placed out in the @pg section, and on which boards (XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD) the KS_PHASER object is placed, the instance number of the KS_PHASER is automatically sorted in time. If two instances of one KS_PHASER occur at the same time (.pos) on different boards, XGRAD comes before YGRAD, which comes before ZGRAD. These abstract, sorted, instance numbers are used by ks_scan_***() functions in scan() to refer to a specific instance of a KS_PHASER object in the sequence

If the .duration field in the KS_PHASER object is 0, ks_pg_phaser() will return SUCCESS and quietly ignore placing it out. This is a part of the mechanism that setting the .duration field to 0 in cveval() should eliminate its existance in both timing calulations and in the pulse sequence generation in @pg

GENERAL NOTE: It is a requirement that the function in the @pg section containing all ks_pg_***() calls is also called exactly once in cveval() after the calls to the corresponding ks_eval_***() functions that design the KS_*** sequence objects. Each ks_pg_***() will throw an error if this has not been done.

Parameters
[in,out]phaserPointer to a KS_PHASER sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when and where to place the KS_PHASER
[in,out]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_PHASER
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1412  {
1413 
1414 
1415  /* loc.ampscale != 1.0 is not allowed */
1416  if (loc.ampscale != 1.0) {
1417  return ks_error("ks_pg_phaser(%s): field 'ampscale' in 2nd arg must be 1.0", phaser->grad.description);
1418  }
1419 
1420  /* loc.board must be one of XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD */
1421  if (loc.board != XGRAD && loc.board != YGRAD && loc.board != ZGRAD) {
1422  return ks_error("ks_pg_phaser(%s): field 'board' in 2nd arg must be XGRAD, YGRAD, or ZGRAD", phaser->grad.description);
1423  }
1424 
1425  return ks_pg_trap(&phaser->grad, loc, ctrl);
1426 
1427 }
KS_PHASER::grad
KS_TRAP grad
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1525
ks_error
STATUS ks_error(const char *format,...)
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:49
KS_SEQLOC::board
int board
Definition: KSFoundation.h:241
KS_SEQLOC::ampscale
float ampscale
Definition: KSFoundation.h:243
KS_TRAP::description
KS_DESCRIPTION description
Definition: KSFoundation.h:432
ks_pg_trap
STATUS ks_pg_trap(KS_TRAP *trap, KS_SEQLOC loc, KS_SEQ_CONTROL *ctrl)
Places a KS_TRAP sequence object on a board at some position in the pulse sequence
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:1212

◆ ks_pg_readtrap()

STATUS ks_pg_readtrap ( KS_READTRAP *  readtrap,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places a KS_READTRAP sequence object on a board at some position in the pulse sequence

This function should be called in the @pg section to place out a KS_READTRAP sequence object consisting of a trapezoid (KS_TRAP) and an acquisition window (KS_READ). The same KS_READTRAP object can be freely placed on XGRAD, YGRAD and ZGRAD as many times as desired, by only changing the second argument each time (to avoid waveform overlaps). For Cartesian applications, readouts such as KS_READTRAP are typically placed on XGRAD (frequency encoding axis). The second argument is a KS_SEQLOC struct with three fields:

  • .board: Choose between XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD
  • .pos: Absolute time in [us] of the start of the attack ramp of the readout trapezoid
  • .ampscale: For KS_READTRAP objects, this must be either +1.0 or -1.0 so that the FOV is not altered. Negative amplitudes will automatically be taken into account in ks_scan_offsetfov() to create the necessary frequency offset

Regardless of the order placed out in the @pg section, and on which boards (XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD) the KS_READTRAP object is placed, the instance number of the KS_READTRAP is automatically sorted in time. If two instances of one KS_READTRAP occur at the same time (.pos) on different boards, XGRAD comes before YGRAD, which comes before ZGRAD. These abstract, sorted, instance numbers are used by ks_scan_***() functions in scan() to refer to a specific instance of a KS_READTRAP object in the sequence.

If the .duration field in the KS_READTRAP object is 0, ks_pg_readtrap() will return SUCCESS and quietly ignore placing it out. This is a part of the mechanism that setting the .duration field to 0 in cveval() should eliminate its existance in both timing calulations and in the pulse sequence generation in @pg

GENERAL NOTE: It is a requirement that the function in the @pg section containing all ks_pg_***() calls is also called exactly once in cveval() after the calls to the corresponding ks_eval_***() functions that design the KS_*** sequence objects. Each ks_pg_***() will throw an error if this has not been done.

Parameters
[in,out]readtrapPointer to a KS_READTRAP sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when and where to place the KS_READTRAP
[in,out]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_READTRAP
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1529  {
1530  KS_SEQLOC omegaloc;
1531 
1532  /* checking for NULL pointers */
1533  if (readtrap == NULL) {
1534  return ks_error("%s: First argument is NULL", __FUNCTION__);
1535  }
1536  /* duration of 0 should not throw an error as this is a sign of that it has not been set up
1537  or has manually been disabled this way */
1538  if (readtrap->grad.duration == 0) {
1539  return SUCCESS;
1540  }
1541  if (readtrap->grad.description == NULL || readtrap->grad.description[0] == 0 || readtrap->grad.description[0] == ' ') {
1542  return ks_error("%s: Invalid description ('%s')", __FUNCTION__, readtrap->grad.description);
1543  }
1544 
1545 #ifdef IPG
1546  /* TGT (IPG): Don't place anything on hardware if ctrl->duration = 0.
1547  This is in concert with:
1548  - not performing createseq() in KS_SEQLENGTH if seqctrl.duration = 0
1549  - not playing sequence modules in scan() using ks_scan_playsequence() if seqctrl.duration = 0
1550  */
1551  if (ctrl->duration == 0) {
1552  return ks_error("%s(%s): Refusing to place readtrap since seqctrl.duration = 0 (indicating `%s` not to be played in scan())", __FUNCTION__, readtrap->grad.description, ctrl->description);
1553  }
1554 #endif
1555 
1556  if (loc.ampscale != 1.0 && loc.ampscale != -1.0) {
1557  ks_error("%s(%s): .ampscale %g must be exactly +1 or -1 for readout gradients", __FUNCTION__, readtrap->grad.description, loc.ampscale);
1558  return FAILURE;
1559  }
1560 
1561  /*** acq ***/
1562  if (ks_pg_read(&readtrap->acq, loc.pos + readtrap->acqdelay, ctrl) == FAILURE)
1563  return FAILURE;
1564 
1565 
1566  /*** trapezoid ***/
1567  if (ks_pg_trap(&readtrap->grad, loc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
1568  return FAILURE;
1569 
1570  /* also place the omega wave form for rampsampled cases */
1571  if (readtrap->omega.duration > 0) {
1572  /* omega trapezoid matching the readout lobe to allow for FOV offsets in freq dir. with ramp sampling */
1573  omegaloc.board = OMEGA;
1574  omegaloc.pos = loc.pos;
1575  omegaloc.ampscale = 1.0; /* just unity value for conformance. It does not matter during scanning, since ks_scan_omegahz() ignores this value */
1576  if (ks_pg_trap(&readtrap->omega, omegaloc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
1577  return FAILURE;
1578  }
1579 
1580 
1581  return SUCCESS;
1582 
1583 
1584 } /* ks_pg_readtrap */
ks_pg_read
