◆ ks_pg_wave()

STATUS ks_pg_wave ( KS_WAVE *  wave,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places a KS_WAVE sequence object on a board at some position in the pulse sequence

This function should be called in the @pg section to place out a KS_WAVE sequence object that creates an arbitrary waveform in the pulse sequence. The same KS_WAVE object can be placed on any board as many times as desired, by only changing the second argument each time (to avoid waveform overlaps). However, the RHO (RF) board should be avoided as this bypasses RF scaling and SAR calculations, providing no control over the flip angle. For RF waveforms, always use KS_RF (or KS_SELRF). The second argument is a KS_SEQLOC struct with three fields:

  • .board: Choose between XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD, OMEGA, THETA
  • .pos: Absolute time in [us] of the start of the waveform. For RF, OMEGA and THETA, pos_rf_wait will be added to this time to take system delays into account
  • .ampscale: For gradient boards, this factor must be in range [-1.0,1.0] that is multiplied with the waveform to yield a per-instance (i.e. per-placement) amplitude ([G/cm]). For THETA, only values of +1.0 and -1.0 is allowed, and for OMEGA only 1.0 is allowed

The KS_WAVE sequence object contains a KS_WAVEFORM (float[KS_MAXWAVELEN]) to hold the waveform. The physical unit of the waveform in the KS_WAVE object depends the board on which it is placed using ks_pg_wave(). For the

  • gradient boards (XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD), the unit is [G/cm]
  • THETA board, the unit is [degrees]
  • RF (RHO) and OMEGA boards, the units are arbitrary (c.f. ks_eval_rf() and ks_eval_wave()). Don't call ks_pg_wave() directly to place a KS_WAVE on the RF board

When a waveform is placed on OMEGA, neither the waveform amplitude nor the .ampscale (in KS_SEQLOC) affects the final frequency modulation. Instead the run-time amplitude of a KS_WAVE object on the OMEGA board is controlled in scan() via a function called ks_scan_omegawave_hz(), where the largest value in the field .waveform[] in the KS_WAVE will correspond to the value in [Hz] provided.

If the .duration field in the KS_WAVE object is 0, ks_pg_wave() will return SUCCESS and quietly ignore placing it out. This is a part of the mechanism that setting the .duration field to 0 in cveval() should eliminate its existance in both timing calulations and in the pulse sequence generation in @pg

All KS_WAVE objects are double buffered in ks_pg_wave() so that waveforms can be replaced in run-time (scan()) using ks_scan_wave2hardware()

Regardless of the order placed out in the @pg section, and on which boards (XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD) the KS_WAVE object is placed, the instance number of the KS_WAVE is automatically sorted in time. If two instances of one KS_WAVE occur at the same time (.pos) on different boards, XGRAD comes before YGRAD, which comes before ZGRAD. These abstract, sorted, instance numbers are used by ks_scan_***() functions in scan() to refer to a specific instance of a KS_WAVE object in the sequence.

GENERAL NOTE: It is a requirement that the function in the @pg section containing all ks_pg_***() calls is also called exactly once in cveval() after the calls to the corresponding ks_eval_***() functions that design the KS_*** sequence objects. Each ks_pg_***() will throw an error if this has not been done.

Parameters
[in,out]wavePointer to a KS_WAVE sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when and where to place the KS_WAVE
[in,out]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_WAVE
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1593  {
1594  float boardmax;
1595  char boardc[7] = "xyzrrto"; /* x,y,z,rho1,rho2,theta,omega */
1596  float waveamp = ks_wave_absmax(wave); /* maximum amplitude in wave (in its own units, like e.g. [G/cm] or [degrees]) */
1597 
1598  boardmax = ks_syslimits_gradtarget(loggrd, loc.board); /* returns 1.0 for non-gradients boards */
1599 
1600  /* checking for NULL pointers */
1601  if (wave == NULL) {
1602  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave: First argument is NULL");
1603  }
1604  /* duration of 0 should not throw an error as this is a sign of that it has not been set up
1605  or has manually been disabled this way */
1606  if (wave->duration == 0) {
1607  return SUCCESS;
1608  }
1609  if (wave->description == NULL || wave->description[0] == 0 || wave->description[0] == ' ') {
1610  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave: Invalid description ('%s')", wave->description);
1611  }
1612 
1613 #ifdef IPG
1614  /* TGT: Don't place anything on hardware if ctrl->duration = 0.
1615  This is in concert with:
1616  - not performing createseq() in KS_SEQLENGTH if seqctrl.duration = 0
1617  - not playing sequence modules in scan() using ks_scan_playsequence() if seqctrl.duration = 0
1618  */
1619  if (ctrl->duration == 0) {
1620  return ks_error("%s(%s): Refusing to place wave since seqctrl.duration = 0 (indicating `%s` not to be played in scan())", __FUNCTION__, wave->description, ctrl->description);
1621  }
1622 
1623  if (!ctrl->gradrf.is_cleared_on_tgt) /* Reset gradrfctrl on tgt to remove dead pointers copied from host. */
1624  {
1625  ks_tgt_reset_gradrfctrl(&ctrl->gradrf);
1626  }
1627 
1628 #endif
1629 
1630  /* input validation */
1631  if (wave->duration % 4) {
1632  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): field 'duration' (%d) must be divisible by 4", wave->description, wave->duration);
1633  }
1634  if (wave->res == 0) {
1635  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): field 'res' cannot be 0", wave->description);
1636  }
1637  if (wave->res % 2) {
1638  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): field 'res' (%d) must be even ", wave->description, wave->res);
1639  }
1640  if (wave->duration % wave->res) {
1641  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): field 'duration' (%d) must be divisible by 'res' %d", wave->description, wave->duration, wave->res);
1642  }
1643  if (loc.board == XGRAD || loc.board == YGRAD || loc.board == ZGRAD) {
1644  if ((wave->duration / wave->res) % GRAD_UPDATE_TIME) {
1645  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): field 'duration' (%d) must a multiple of 4 times 'res' (%d) for gradient boards", wave->description, wave->duration, wave->res);
1646  }
1647  if (wave->gradwave_units == KS_GRADWAVE_ABSOLUTE && loc.ampscale != 1.0) {
1648  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): ampscale must be +1.0 for gradwave with absolute units", wave->description);
1649  }
1650  } else {
1651  if ((wave->duration / wave->res) % RF_UPDATE_TIME) {
1652  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): field 'duration' (%d) must a multiple of 2 times 'res' (%d) for non-gradient boards", wave->description, wave->duration, wave->res);
1653  }
1654  }
1655 
1656  if (loc.ampscale != loc.ampscale) {
1657  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): loc.ampscale NaN", wave->description);
1658  }
1659  if (loc.pos != loc.pos) {
1660  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): loc.pos NaN", wave->description);
1661  }
1662  if (loc.board != loc.board) {
1663  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): loc.board NaN", wave->description);
1664  }
1665  if (loc.pos < GRAD_UPDATE_TIME || loc.pos > 4e6) {
1666  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): Invalid position %d, it must be between 4us and 4s", wave->description, loc.pos);
1667  }
1668  if (loc.board == OMEGA && loc.ampscale != 1.0) {
1669  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): ampscale must be +1.0 for OMEGA", wave->description);
1670  }
1671  if (loc.board == THETA && loc.ampscale != 1.0 && loc.ampscale != -1.0) {
1672  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): ampscale must be +1.0 or -1.0 for THETA", wave->description);
1673  }
1674  if (loc.ampscale < -1.0 || loc.ampscale > 1.0) {
1675  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): Invalid ampscale %g, it must be between -1.0 and 1.0", wave->description, loc.ampscale);
1676  }
1677  if (fabs(waveamp * loc.ampscale) > boardmax && loc.board != THETA) {
1678  return ks_error("ks_pg_wave(%s): wave amplitude (%.2f) exceeds maximum (%g) for board %c", wave->description, waveamp * loc.ampscale, boardmax, boardc[loc.board]);
1679  }
1680 
1681  loc.pos = RUP_GRD(loc.pos);
1682 
1683 
1684 #ifdef HOST_TGT
1685 
1686  /* HOST */
1687 
1688  wave->locs[wave->base.ninst] = loc;
1689 
1690  /* update instance counter on host only. This counter is used to allocate the right amount of WFINSTANCEs on IPG */
1691  wave->base.ninst++;
1692 
1693  /* for wave, we also need to keep track of #instances per X, Y, Z for gradient heating calculations.
1694  As this needs to be done in HOST before the IPG (target), we can't use the wfi[...].boardinstance or .loc information above for this */
1695  if (loc.board == XGRAD || loc.board == YGRAD || loc.board == ZGRAD) {
1696  wave->gradnum[loc.board]++;
1697  }
1698 
1699 #else
1700 
1701  {
1702 
1703  int i;
1704  int wave_ptr, isrf, iamp;
1705  char tmpstr[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 7];
1706 
1707  if (wave->base.ngenerated >= wave->base.ninst) {
1708  ks_error("ks_pg_wave @tgt(%s): the number of instances generated on the target exceeds the number of ones generated on the host", wave->description);
1709  return FAILURE;
1710  }
1711 
1712  /* first call on TGT, allocate WF_PULSE * array where each element corresponds to one board */
1713  if (wave->wfpulse == NULL) {
1714  wave->wfpulse = (WF_PULSE **) AllocNode(7 * sizeof(WF_PULSE *)); /* WF pointers for all boards (XGRAD->OMEGA) */
1715  } /* wfpulse == NULL */
1716 
1717 
1718  /* first call on TGT using this loc.board, make waveform memory (double buffered) */
1719  if (wave->wfpulse[loc.board] == NULL) {
1720  WF_PULSE wfInit = INITPULSE;
1721  KS_IWAVE iwave;
1722 
1723  wave->wfpulse[loc.board] = (WF_PULSE *) AllocNode(KS_WF_SIZE * sizeof(WF_PULSE)); /* KS_WF_SIZE (3) to allow for double buffering */
1724 
1725  for (i = KS_WF_MAIN; i < KS_WF_SIZE; i++)
1726  wave->wfpulse[loc.board][i] = wfInit;
1727 
1728  sprintf(tmpstr, "%s.%c", wave->description, boardc[loc.board]); pulsename(&(wave->wfpulse[loc.board][KS_WF_MAIN]), tmpstr);
1729  sprintf(tmpstr, "%s_buf1.%c", wave->description, boardc[loc.board]); pulsename(&(wave->wfpulse[loc.board][KS_WF_BUF1]), tmpstr);
1730  sprintf(tmpstr, "%s_buf2.%c", wave->description, boardc[loc.board]); pulsename(&(wave->wfpulse[loc.board][KS_WF_BUF2]), tmpstr);
1731 
1732  /* wave -> short int wave for hardware use. All waveforms but THETA are autoscaled to +/- max_pg_wamp (32766)*/
1733  if (ks_wave2iwave(iwave, wave, loc.board) == FAILURE)
1734  return FAILURE;
1735 
1736  /* reserve hardware memory to allow for double buffering */
1737  for (i = KS_WF_MAIN; i <= KS_WF_BUF2; i++) {
1738  createreserve(&wave->wfpulse[loc.board][i], loc.board, wave->res);
1739  wave->wfpulse[loc.board][i].type = TYPEXTERNAL;
1740  movewaveimm(iwave, &wave->wfpulse[loc.board][i], (int) 0, wave->res, TOHARDWARE);
1741  }
1742 
1743  } /* wfpulse[loc.board] == NULL */
1744 
1745 
1746  /* create instruction at the current position */
1747  isrf = loc.board == RHO || loc.board == RHO2 || loc.board == THETA || loc.board == OMEGA;
1748 
1749  if (loc.board == THETA)
1750  iamp = loc.ampscale * MAX_PG_IAMP;
1751  else
1752  iamp = (waveamp * loc.ampscale / boardmax) * MAX_PG_IAMP;
1753 
1754  createinstr(&wave->wfpulse[loc.board][KS_WF_MAIN],
1755  (long) (loc.pos + (psd_rf_wait * isrf)),
1756  (long) wave->duration,
1757  (long) iamp);
1758 
1759  /* WF instance bookkeeping */
1760  if (wave->wfi == NULL) {
1761  wave->wfi = (KS_WFINSTANCE *) AllocNode(wave->base.ninst * sizeof(KS_WFINSTANCE));
1762  }
1763  wave->wfi[wave->base.ngenerated].boardinstance = wave->wfpulse[loc.board][KS_WF_MAIN].ninsts - 1;
1764  wave->wfi[wave->base.ngenerated].wf = wave->wfpulse[loc.board];
1765  wave->wfi[wave->base.ngenerated].loc = loc;
1766 
1767  /* After instructions have been set, set the wfpulse[KS_WF_MAIN] to the first waveform buffer (_BUF1) */
1768  getwave(&wave_ptr, &(wave->wfpulse[loc.board][KS_WF_BUF1]));
1769  setwave(wave_ptr, &(wave->wfpulse[loc.board][KS_WF_MAIN]), wave->wfi[wave->base.ngenerated].boardinstance);
1770 
1771  wave->base.ngenerated++;
1772 
1773  /* sort after the last instance is generated */
1774  if (wave->base.ngenerated == wave->base.ninst) {
1775  ks_sort_wfi_by_timeboard(wave->wfi, wave->base.ninst);
1776  }
1777 
1778  }
1779 
1780 #endif /* IPG or HOST */
1781 
1782  /* register this KS_WAVE for later heating calculations */
1783  {
1784  STATUS status = ks_eval_addwavetogradrfctrl(&ctrl->gradrf, wave);
1785  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1786  }
1787 
1788  return SUCCESS;
1789 
1790 } /* ks_pg_wave */
KS_GRADWAVE_ABSOLUTE

◆ ks_pg_rf()

STATUS ks_pg_rf ( KS_RF *  rf,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places a KS_RF sequence object on a board at some position in the pulse sequence

This function should be called in the @pg section to place out a KS_RF sequence object that creates an RF pulse in the pulse sequence. The same KS_RF object can be placed out as many times as desired, by only changing the second argument each time (to avoid waveform overlaps). The second argument is a KS_SEQLOC struct with three fields:

  • .board: Ignored. .rfwave will always be placed on RHO. If the resolution of .omegawave is non-zero it will be placed on OMEGA, and correspondingly for .thetawave on THETA
  • .pos: Absolute time in [us] of the start of the waveform
  • .ampscale: A factor that must be in range [-1.0,1.0] that is multiplied with .amp to yield a per-instance (i.e. per-placement) amplitude. For KS_RF objects this will cause the flip angle to be reduced on a per-instance basis. This can be used to generate a variable flip-angle train of RF pulses using a single KS_RF object. An .ampscale of -1.0 is equivalent to adding a 180 degree RF phase shift to the RF pulse

If the rfwave.duration field in the KS_RF object is 0, ks_pg_rf() will return SUCCESS and quietly ignore placing it out. This is a part of the mechanism that setting the .duration field to 0 in cveval() should eliminate its existance in both timing calulations and in the pulse sequence generation in @pg

As ks_pg_rf() internally calls ks_pg_wave() for its KS_WAVEs, double buffering will be used for all hardware waveforms, allowing waveforms to be replaced in run-time (scan()) using ks_scan_wave2hardware()

Regardless of the order placed out in the @pg section the KS_RF object is placed, the instance number of the KS_RF is automatically sorted in time. These abstract, sorted, instance numbers are used by ks_scan_***() functions in scan() to refer to a specific instance of a KS_RF object in the sequence.

GENERAL NOTE: It is a requirement that the function in the @pg section containing all ks_pg_***() calls is also called exactly once in cveval() after the calls to the corresponding ks_eval_***() functions that design the KS_*** sequence objects. Each ks_pg_***() will throw an error if this has not been done.

When ks_pg_rf() is run in cveval() (on HOST), the field .rfpulse.activity that was first set to 0 by ks_eval_rf() is now set to PSD_APS2_ON + PSD_MPS2_ON + PSD_SCAN_ON by ks_pg_rf(). This triggers the RF functions used in ks_eval_gradrflimits() to include this KS_RF object in RF scaling and SAR calculations. Each time ks_pg_rf() is called, the field .rfpulse.num is incremented after being first set to 0 by ks_eval_rf(). Hence, it is crucial that the sequence generating function (c.f. KS_SEQ_CONTROL) containing all ks_pg_***() calls is executed between the ks_eval_rf() setup call and the call to ks_eval_gradrflimits()

Parameters
[in,out]rfPointer to a KS_RF sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when to place the KS_RF
[in,out]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_RF
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1799  {
1800 
1801  /* input validation */
1802  if (rf == NULL) {
1803  return ks_error("%s: First argument is NULL", __FUNCTION__);
1804  }
1805 
1806  /* duration of 0 should not throw an error as this is a sign of that it has not been set up
1807  or has manually been disabled this way */
1808  if (rf->rfwave.duration == 0) {
1809  return SUCCESS;
1810  }
1811  if (rf->rfwave.description == NULL || rf->rfwave.description[0] == 0 || rf->rfwave.description[0] == ' ') {
1812  return ks_error("ks_pg_rf: Invalid description ('%s')", rf->rfwave.description);
1813  }
1814 
1815 #ifdef IPG
1816  /* TGT: Don't place anything on hardware if ctrl->duration = 0.
1817  This is in concert with:
1818  - not performing createseq() in KS_SEQLENGTH if seqctrl.duration = 0
1819  - not playing sequence modules in scan() using ks_scan_playsequence() if seqctrl.duration = 0
1820  */
1821  if (ctrl->duration == 0) {
1822  return ks_error("%s(%s): Refusing to place RF since seqctrl.duration = 0 (indicating `%s` not to be played in scan())", __FUNCTION__, rf->rfwave.description, ctrl->description);
1823  }
1824  /* TGT: make sure (the RF pulses in) the sequence module were a part of the seqcollection when GEReq_eval_rfscaling() was called */
1825  if (ctrl->rfscalingdone == FALSE && ctrl->duration > 0) {
1826  return ks_error("%s(%s): Missing RF scaling for sequence module with non-zero duration. Add `%s` to seqcollection *before* calling GEReq_eval_rfscaling(seqcollection)", __FUNCTION__, rf->rfwave.description, ctrl->description);
1827  }
1828 
1829  if (!ctrl->gradrf.is_cleared_on_tgt) /* Reset gradrfctrl on tgt to remove dead pointers copied from host. */
1830  {
1831  ks_tgt_reset_gradrfctrl(&ctrl->gradrf);
1832  }
1833 
1834 #endif
1835 
1836  loc.pos = RUP_RF(loc.pos);
1837 
1838  RFEnvelopeWaveformGeneratorCheck(rf->rfwave.description, ks_rhoboard);
1839 
1840  if (rf->omegawave.res) {
1841  if (rf->omegawave.duration != rf->rfwave.duration) {
1842  ks_error("ks_pg_rf (%s): The duration of the omega waveform must be equal to the RF duration", rf->rfwave.description);
1843  return FAILURE;
1844  }
1845  }
1846  if (rf->thetawave.res) {
1847  if (rf->thetawave.duration != rf->rfwave.duration) {
1848  ks_error("ks_pg_rf (%s): The duration of the theta waveform must be equal to the RF duration", rf->rfwave.description);
1849  return FAILURE;
1850  }
1851  }
1852 
1853  /* Set ctrl->momentstart if this is an excitation pulse */
1854  if (rf->role == KS_RF_ROLE_EXC) {
1855  ctrl->momentstart = RUP_GRD(loc.pos + rf->start2iso); /* RUP_GRD: make sure it is on a 4us raster too for gradient timing calcs */
1856  }
1857 
1858  /* register this KS_RF for later heating calculations - and do this *before* calls to ks_pg_wave() below (in this function) to avoid double registrations (c.f. ks_eval_addwavetogradrfctrl()).
1859  N.B.: While RF/sar calcs (ks_eval_rfscaling()) are not affected by this, registering the rf->rfwave both as a part of the RF object and as a separate wave in ctrl->gradrf would otherwise lead to problems for
1860  ks_gnuplot_seqmodule(). This would cause the RF pulse to show up twice in the plot / pdf / image.
1861  ks_eval_addwavetogradrfctrl() is called in ks_pg_wave() and checks if this wave also belongs to a parent registered RF pulse in which case the wave will not be registered again */
1862  {
1863  STATUS status = ks_eval_addrftogradrfctrl(&ctrl->gradrf, rf);
1864  if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
1865  }
1866 
1867 #ifdef HOST_TGT
1868 
1869  /* update rfpulse.num counter on host only. We can use this ninst variable as info
1870  for RF heating calculations */
1871  rf->rfpulse.num++;
1872 
1873  /* now that we have shown that we are really going to use this pulse, set its
1874  activity flag to SCAN, APS2, MPS2 */
1875  rf->rfpulse.activity = PSD_APS2_ON + PSD_MPS2_ON + PSD_SCAN_ON;
1876 
1877 #else
1878 
1879  if (rf->rfpulse.num == 0) {
1880  ks_error("ks_pg_rf @tgt(%s): pulsegen was never run on HOST (rf->rfpulse.num = 0)", rf->rfwave.description);
1881  return FAILURE;
1882  }
1883 
1884  if (rf->rfpulse.activity == 0) {
1885  ks_error("ks_pg_rf @tgt(%s): RF pulse with zero activity", rf->rfwave.description);
1886  return FAILURE;
1887  }
1888 
1889  /* The values in rf->rfwave.waveform[] are relative (unit-less). The actual amplitude of the RF wave
1890  is only controlled by rf->amp (which in turn is set by GE's setScale() and indirectly by peakB1()).
1891  Prepare RF waveform with correct amplitude on TGT side that can be used with ks_pg_wave() to give the right
1892  RF amplitude, after we have done RF scaling on HOST and hence have a final value for rf->amp.
1893  The units of this RF waveform, before and after calling ks_wave_multiplywal(), are relative (not [G])
1894  due to GE's RF scaling process involving e.g. xmtaddScan.
1895  Look in GERequired.e:GEReq_eval_gradrflimits() for more info on how peakB1() and setScale() are used. */
1896 
1897  ks_wave_multiplyval(&rf->rfwave, rf->amp / ks_wave_absmax(&rf->rfwave));
1898 
1899 #endif
1900 
1901 
1902 
1903  /* place the RF wave */
1904  loc.board = RHO;
1905  if (ks_pg_wave(&rf->rfwave, loc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
1906  return FAILURE;
1907 
1908 #ifdef IPG
1909  /* add SSP RF bits that handles the frequency control and blanking/unblanking the receiver */
1910  addrfbits(&rf->rfwave.wfpulse[RHO][KS_WF_MAIN], 0, loc.pos + psd_rf_wait, rf->rfwave.duration);
1911  /* set RF frequency offset */
1912  setfrequency(rf->cf_offset / TARDIS_FREQ_RES, &rf->rfwave.wfpulse[RHO][KS_WF_MAIN], INSTRALL);
1913 #endif
1914 
1915  /* set ampscale to 1. If you want to scale the omega or theata board, do it seperatly */
1916  loc.ampscale = 1;
1917 
1918  /* place the OMEGA wave */
1919  loc.board = OMEGA;
1920  if (rf->omegawave.res) {
1921  if (ks_pg_wave(&rf->omegawave, loc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
1922  return FAILURE;
1923  }
1924 
1925 #ifdef IPG
1926  if (rf->omegawave.res) {
1927  /* add SSP RF bits that handles the frequency control and blanking/unblanking the receiver */
1928  addrfbits(&rf->omegawave.wfpulse[OMEGA][KS_WF_MAIN], 0, loc.pos + psd_rf_wait, rf->omegawave.duration);
1929  }
1930 #endif
1931 
1932  /* place the THETA wave */
1933  loc.board = THETA;
1934  if (rf->thetawave.res) {
1935  if (ks_pg_wave(&rf->thetawave, loc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
1936  return FAILURE;
1937  }
1938 
1939 #ifdef IPG
1940  if (rf->thetawave.res) {
1941  /* add SSP RF bits that handles the frequency control and blanking/unblanking the receiver */
1942  addrfbits(&rf->thetawave.wfpulse[THETA][KS_WF_MAIN], 0, loc.pos + psd_rf_wait, rf->thetawave.duration);
1943  }
1944 #endif
1945 
1946  return SUCCESS;
1947 
1948 } /* ks_pg_rf */

◆ ks_pg_selrf()

STATUS ks_pg_selrf ( KS_SELRF *  selrf,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places a KS_SELRF sequence object on a gradient (and RF) board at some position in the pulse sequence

This function should be called in the @pg section to place out a KS_SELRF sequence object that creates an RF pulse with associated trapezoids in the pulse sequence. The same KS_SELRF object can be placed out as many times as desired, by only changing the second argument each time (to avoid waveform overlaps). The second argument is a KS_SEQLOC struct with three fields:

  • .board: Choose between XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD for the board on which .pregrad, .grad (or .gradwave) and .postgrad should be placed
  • .pos: Absolute time in [us] of the start of the .pregrad attack ramp. If .pregrad has zero duration, .pos will in effect refer to the start of the .grad attack ramp
  • .ampscale: A factor that must be in range [-1.0,1.0] that is multiplied with rf.rfwave.amp to yield a per-instance (i.e. per-placement) amplitude. For KS_SELRF objects the .ampscale value will be passed on its internal call to ks_pg_rf(), but not to its internal ks_pg_trap() calls. Hence .ampscale will have the same effect for ks_pg_selrf() as for ks_pg_rf(), with no per-instance control of the amplitude of the gradients involved. A reduced .ampscale will cause the flip angle to be reduced on a per-instance basis. This can be used to generate a variable flip-angle train of selective RF pulses using a single KS_SELRF object. An .ampscale of -1.0 is equivalent to adding a 180 degree RF phase shift to the RF pulse

If the .gradwave field has a non-zero resolution, ks_pg_selrf() will place out the .gradwave (KS_WAVE) instead of the .grad (KS_TRAP) during the time the RF pulse is played out. An error is thrown if .gradwave.duration (if .gradwave.res > 0) is not equal to the .rf.rfwave.duration. If .pregrad or .postgrad has zero duration, they will not be placed out. The existance of non-zero .pregrad and .postgrad is determined by ks_eval_selrf() based on .rf.role

As ks_pg_selrf() internally calls ks_pg_wave() for its KS_WAVEs, hardware double buffering will be used for all waveforms, allowing waveforms to be replaced in run-time (scan()) using ks_scan_wave2hardware()

Regardless of the order placed out in the @pg section the KS_SELRF object is placed, the instance number of the KS_SELRF is automatically sorted in time. These abstract, sorted, instance numbers are used by ks_scan_***() functions in scan() to refer to a specific instance of a KS_SELRF object in the sequence.

GENERAL NOTE: It is a requirement that the function in the @pg section containing all ks_pg_***() calls is also called exactly once in cveval() after the calls to the corresponding ks_eval_***() functions that design the KS_*** sequence objects. Each ks_pg_***() will throw an error if this has not been done.

Parameters
[in,out]selrfPointer to a KS_SELRF sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when and where to place the KS_SELRF
[in,out]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_SELRF
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
1954  {
1955  KS_SEQLOC rfloc;
1956  KS_SEQLOC gradloc;
1957  float gradmax;
1958 
1959  if (loc.board != XGRAD && loc.board != YGRAD && loc.board != ZGRAD) {
1960  return ks_error("%s(%s): loc.board (2nd arg) must be a gradient board", __FUNCTION__, selrf->rf.rfwave.description);
1961  }
1962 
1963  /* gradient max on current logical board */
1964  gradmax = ks_syslimits_gradtarget(loggrd, loc.board);
1965 
1966  /* loc.ampscale should only affect the RF amp, not the gradients */
1967  gradloc = loc; gradloc.ampscale = 1.0;
1968  rfloc = loc; rfloc.board = RHO;
1969 
1970  /* RF starts after the preselgrad (if present) */
1971  rfloc.pos += selrf->pregrad.duration;
1972 
1973  /* delay the RF pulse start by the ramptime of the slice sel gradient
1974  when .gradwave is used, .grad.ramptime will be correctly zero */
1975  rfloc.pos += selrf->grad.ramptime;
1976 
1977 
1978  /************* generate the RF (incl. optional THETA & OMEGA) *************/
1979 
1980  if (ks_pg_rf(&selrf->rf, rfloc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
1981  return FAILURE;
1982 
1983  /************************ place gradients *********************************/
1984 
1985  /* Pre-slice sel gradient. Roles: e.g. left crusher or dephasing gradient in bSSFP */
1986  if (ks_pg_trap(&selrf->pregrad, gradloc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
1987  return FAILURE;
1988  gradloc.pos += selrf->pregrad.duration;
1989 
1990 
1991 
1992  /* slice select gradient */
1993  if (selrf->gradwave.res) {
1994  /* use gradwave (not trapezoid) */
1995 
1996  if (selrf->rf.rfwave.duration != (selrf->gradwave.duration) || (selrf->gradwave.res * GRAD_UPDATE_TIME != selrf->gradwave.duration)) {
1997  return ks_error("%s(%s): The duration of 'gradwave' (%d [us]) must equal the RF duration (%d [us])", __FUNCTION__,
1998  selrf->rf.rfwave.description, selrf->gradwave.duration, selrf->rf.rfwave.duration);
1999  }
2000 
2001  if (ks_pg_wave(&selrf->gradwave, gradloc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2002  return FAILURE;
2003 
2004  gradloc.pos += selrf->gradwave.duration;
2005 
2006  } else {
2007  /* use trapezoid (not gradwave) */
2008 
2009  if (selrf->grad.plateautime != selrf->rf.rfwave.duration) {
2010  return ks_error("%s(%s): Plateau time of slice select (%d) != RF duration (%d)", __FUNCTION__, selrf->rf.rfwave.description, selrf->grad.plateautime, selrf->rf.rfwave.duration);
2011  } else {
2012  if (ks_pg_trap(&selrf->grad, gradloc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2013  return FAILURE;
2014 
2015  gradloc.pos += selrf->grad.duration;
2016  }
2017 
2018  } /* slice select */
2019 
2020 
2021  /* post-slice sel gradient. Roles: e.g. right crusher or refocusing gradient */
2022  if (ks_pg_trap(&selrf->postgrad, gradloc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2023  return FAILURE;
2024  gradloc.pos += selrf->postgrad.duration;
2025 
2026 
2027  return SUCCESS;
2028 
2029 } /* ks_pg_selrf */

int plateautime

◆ ks_pg_wait()

STATUS ks_pg_wait ( KS_WAIT *  wait,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places a KS_WAIT sequence object on all boards at some position in the pulse sequence

This function should be called in the @pg section to place out a KS_WAIT sequence object that creates a wait pulse. The same KS_WAIT object can be placed out as many times as desired, by only changing the second argument each time (to avoid waveform overlaps). The second argument is a KS_SEQLOC struct with three fields:

  • .board: Ignored
  • .pos: Absolute time in [us] of the start of the wait pulse
  • .ampscale: Ignored

This function will insert a deadtime of duration equal to the .duration field in the KS_WAIT object at position .pos. This delay can be changed in run-time by calling ks_scan_wait().

GENERAL NOTE: It is a requirement that the function in the @pg section containing all ks_pg_***() calls is also called exactly once in cveval() after the calls to the corresponding ks_eval_***() functions that design the KS_*** sequence objects. Each ks_pg_***() will throw an error if this has not been done.

Parameters
[in,out]waitPointer to a KS_WAIT sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when and where to place the KS_WAIT
[in,out]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_WAIT
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
2038  {
2039  int i;
2040  const int first = loc.board == KS_ALL ? XGRAD : loc.board;
2041  const int last = loc.board == KS_ALL ? SSP : loc.board;
2042 
2043  /* checking for NULL pointers */
2044  if (wait == NULL) {
2045  return ks_error("ks_pg_wait: First argument is NULL");
2046  }
2047 
2048  /* duration of 0 should not throw an error as this is a sign of that it has not been set up
2049  or has manually been disabled this way */
2050  if (wait->duration == 0) {
2051  return SUCCESS;
2052  }
2053 
2054  if (wait->description == NULL || wait->description[0] == 0 || wait->description[0] == ' ') {
2055  return ks_error("ks_pg_wait: Invalid description ('%s')", wait->description);
2056  }
2057 
2058  /* disallow EPI dual boards */
2059  if (loc.board >= KS_FREQX_PHASEY && loc.board <= KS_XYZ) {
2060  return ks_error("ks_pg_wait(%s): Invalid board selection: %d", wait->description, loc.board);
2061  }
2062 
2063  loc.pos = RUP_GRD(loc.pos);
2064 
2065 
2066 #ifdef IPG
2067  {
2068 
2069  /* TGT: Don't place anything on hardware if ctrl->duration = 0.
2070  This is in concert with:
2071  - not performing createseq() in KS_SEQLENGTH if seqctrl.duration = 0
2072  - not playing sequence modules in scan() using ks_scan_playsequence() if seqctrl.duration = 0
2073  */
2074  if (ctrl->duration == 0) {
2075  ks_dbg("%s(%s): Refusing to place wait pulse since seqctrl.duration = 0 (indicating `%s` not to be played in scan())", __FUNCTION__, wait->description, ctrl->description);
2076  return SUCCESS;
2077  }
2078 
2079  if (wait->base.ngenerated >= wait->base.ninst) {
2080  return ks_error("ks_pg_wait @tgt(%s): the number of instances generated on the target exceed the number of ones generated on the host", wait->description);
2081  }
2082 
2083  if (wait->wfpulse == NULL) {
2084  WF_PULSE wfInit = INITPULSE;
2085 
2086  const char boardc[8] = "xyzrrtos";
2087  char tmpstr[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 4];
2088  tmpstr[KS_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH + 4 - 1] = 0;
2089 
2090  wait->wfpulse = (WF_PULSE *) AllocNode(8 * sizeof(WF_PULSE));
2091  for (i = XGRAD; i <= SSP; i++) {
2092  if (i != RHO2){
2093  /* init pulse structure */
2094  wait->wfpulse[i] = wfInit;
2095 
2096  /* Name for WF_PULSEs */
2097  sprintf(tmpstr, "%s.w%c", wait->description, boardc[i]); pulsename(&(wait->wfpulse[i]), tmpstr);
2098  createconst(&(wait->wfpulse[i]), i, wait->duration, 0);
2099 
2100  } /* per board */
2101  }
2102 
2103  } /* wfpulse == NULL */
2104 
2105  if (!wait->wfi) {
2106  wait->wfi = (KS_WFINSTANCE *) AllocNode(wait->base.ninst * sizeof(KS_WAIT));
2107  }
2108 
2109  for (i = first; i <= last; ++i) {
2110  if (i == KS_RHO2) continue; /* skip RHO2 */
2111 
2112  loc.board = i;
2113  int isrf = loc.board == RHO || loc.board == RHO2 || loc.board == THETA || loc.board == OMEGA;
2114  int isssp = loc.board == SSP;
2115 
2116  createinstr(&(wait->wfpulse[i]), loc.pos + (isrf * psd_rf_wait) + (isssp * psd_grd_wait), wait->duration, 0);
2117  wait->wfi[wait->base.ngenerated].boardinstance = wait->wfpulse[i].ninsts - 1; /* zero based */
2118  wait->wfi[wait->base.ngenerated].wf = &(wait->wfpulse[i]);
2119  wait->wfi[wait->base.ngenerated].loc = loc;
2120  wait->base.ngenerated++;
2121  }
2122 
2123  /* sort after the last instance is generated */
2124  if (wait->base.ngenerated == wait->base.ninst) {
2125  ks_sort_wfi_by_timeboard(wait->wfi, wait->base.ninst);
2126  }
2127  }
2128 #else
2129  {
2130  for (i = first; i <= last; ++i) {
2131  if (i == KS_RHO2) continue; /* skip RHO2 */
2132  loc.board = i;
2133  wait->locs[wait->base.ninst] = loc;
2134  wait->base.ninst++;
2135  }
2136  }
2137 #endif
2138 
2139  return SUCCESS;
2140 
2141 } /* ks_pg_wait */
ks_sort_wfi_by_timeboard

Sort WF_INSTANCEs in time, then board

psd_grd_wait
int psd_grd_wait
KS_WAIT::wfpulse
WF_PULSE * wfpulse
Definition: KSFoundation.h:313
KS_SEQ_CONTROL::description
KS_DESCRIPTION description
Definition: KSFoundation.h:990
KS_BASE::ngenerated
int ngenerated
Definition: KSFoundation.h:262
psd_rf_wait

◆ ks_pg_isirot()

STATUS ks_pg_isirot ( KS_ISIROT *  isirot,
SCAN_INFO  scan_info,
int  pos,
void *  rotfun,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places out an intersequence interrupt at a specific time in the sequence module

This function connects the execution of a psd-specific rotation function in realtime when time passes this point in the sequence. This is done by two KS_WAIT pulses (being part of KS_ISIROT) on the SSP board.

Example of use in a myseqmodule_pg() function of the sequence module (in pulsegen()):

// add some padding time before the SSP pulses (not well tested how much of KS_ISI_predelay that is necessary)
mypos += RUP_GRD(KS_ISI_predelay);
status = ks_pg_isirot(&myisirot, myscaninfo, mypos, myisirotatefun, myseqctrl);
if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
// add some padding time after the SSP pulses (not well tested how much of KS_ISI_postdelay that is necessary)
mypos += RUP_GRD(myisirot.duration + KS_ISI_postdelay);

where the psd-specific rotation function is declared as:

// Intra sequence interrupts placed as WAIT pulses on the SSP board may be used to call for an immediate
// rotation of the logical coordinate system in real time as these WAIT pulses are played out, as
// opposed to during the SSI time for the sequence module.
// The WAIT pulse is assigned a control number (isi number) that is then connected to this void function
// using `isivector()` in ks_pg_isirot(). No input arguments can be passed to this function. Instead the
// rotation information specific to the sequence module is provided in `myscaninfo.oprot`. The acutal
// rotation work, incl. keeping track of number of isi pulses played out is done by ks_scan_isirotate().
void myisirotatefun() {
#ifdef IPG
ks_scan_isirotate(&myisirot);
#endif
}

Note that the only difference between the psd-specific myisirotatefun() and the general ks_scan_isirotate() is that myisirotatefun() has no input arguments. Input arguments cannot be used as it is called from an interrupt routine, not from some other parent function.

Care must be taken when mixing the use of ks_scan_rotate() (executing during the SSI time) and these ISI interrupts, so that they are executed in the correct order. One way is to consistently avoid the use of ks_scan_rotate() and instead return to the prescribed slice rotation by calling ks_pg_isirot() again, last in the same myseqmodule_pg() function, this time using the prescribed scan_info struct:

status = ks_pg_isirot(&myisirot, ks_scan_info[0], mypos, myisirotatefun, myseqctrl);
if (status != SUCCESS) return status;
Parameters
[in,out]isirotPointer to a KS_ISIROT sequence object
[in]scan_infoSCAN_INFO struct holding an .oprot matrix to be used for real-time rotation
[in]posAbsolute position in [us] in the pulse sequence when this rotation should occur
[in]rotfunFunction pointer to the psd-specific rotation function
[in,out]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
2145  {
2146  KS_SEQLOC tmploc = KS_INIT_SEQLOC;
2147 
2148  if (! isirot->duration) {
2149  /* must have called ks_eval_isirot() first */
2150  return SUCCESS;
2151  }
2152 
2153  if (rotfun == NULL)
2154  return ks_error("%s: 4th arg (rotfun) cannot be NULL", __FUNCTION__);
2155 
2156 
2157  /* Set the ctrl_word to binary match the isi vector interupt number */
2158  /* /--------------------------------------------------------------\ */
2159  /* | interupt number | ctrl_word | */
2160  /* |--------------------------------------------------------------| */
2161  /* | 4 | PSD_ISI2_BIT | */
2162  /* | 5 | PSD_ISI0_BIT + PSD_ISI2_BIT | */
2163  /* | 6 | PSD_ISI1_BIT + PSD_ISI2_BIT | */
2164  /* | 7 | PSD_ISI0_BIT + PSD_ISI1_BIT + PSD_ISI2_BIT | */
2165  /* \--------------------------------------------------------------/ */
2166 
2167  tmploc.board = SSP;
2168  tmploc.pos = RUP_GRD(pos);
2169 
2170  if (ks_pg_wait(&isirot->waitfun, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2171  return FAILURE;
2172 
2173  tmploc.pos += RUP_GRD(isirot->waitfun.duration);
2174 
2175  if (ks_pg_wait(&isirot->waitrot, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2176  return FAILURE;
2177 
2178 
2179 #ifdef IPG
2180  {
2181  long ctrl_word = 0;
2182  int placementindx = isirot->waitfun.base.ngenerated - 1;
2183 
2184  /* SSP ISI number */
2185  getctrl(&ctrl_word, &isirot->waitfun.wfpulse[SSP], isirot->waitfun.wfpulse[SSP].ninsts - 1);
2186 
2187  if (isirot->isinumber == 4)
2188  ctrl_word = ctrl_word | PSD_ISI2_BIT;
2189  else if (isirot->isinumber == 5)
2190  ctrl_word = ctrl_word | PSD_ISI0_BIT | PSD_ISI2_BIT;
2191  else if (isirot->isinumber == 6)
2192  ctrl_word = ctrl_word | PSD_ISI1_BIT | PSD_ISI2_BIT;
2193  else if (isirot->isinumber == 7)
2194  ctrl_word = ctrl_word | PSD_ISI0_BIT | PSD_ISI1_BIT | PSD_ISI2_BIT;
2195 
2196  setctrl(ctrl_word, &isirot->waitfun.wfpulse[SSP], isirot->waitfun.wfpulse[SSP].ninsts - 1);
2197 
2198  /* SSP Rotation */
2199  getctrl(&ctrl_word, &isirot->waitrot.wfpulse[SSP], isirot->waitrot.wfpulse[SSP].ninsts - 1);
2200  ctrl_word |= PSD_MTX_UPDT;
2201  setctrl(ctrl_word, &isirot->waitrot.wfpulse[SSP], isirot->waitrot.wfpulse[SSP].ninsts - 1);
2202 
2203  /* Allocate memory for scan info array */
2204  if (isirot->scan_info == NULL) {
2205  isirot->scan_info = (SCAN_INFO *) AllocNode(isirot->numinstances * sizeof(SCAN_INFO));
2206  }
2207 
2208  /* Store the scan info for current ISI, where scan_info.oprot contains the rotation matrix */
2209  isirot->scan_info[placementindx] = scan_info;
2210 
2211  /* Reset num ISI and counter */
2212  isirot->counter = 0; /* make sure it is zero before scan starts */
2213 
2214  /* Connect ths isi number with the function pointer */
2215  isivector((short) isirot->isinumber, rotfun, (short) FALSE);
2216 
2217  }
2218 #else
2219 
2220  if (0) { /* make sure the WAIT pulses have been placed out in temporal order */
2221  int i;
2222  int lastpos = -1;
2223  WF_INSTR_HDR *instr = isirot->waitfun.wfpulse[SSP].inst_hdr_tail;
2224  for (i = 0; i < (isirot->waitfun.base.ninst - 1); i++) {
2225  if (lastpos > instr->start) {
2226  return ks_error("%s: Must place the ISI pulses in temporal order", __FUNCTION__);
2227  } else {
2228  lastpos = instr->start;
2229  instr = instr->next;
2230  }
2231  }
2232  }
2233 
2234  /* copy for convenience */
2235  isirot->numinstances = isirot->waitfun.base.ninst;
2236 
2237 #endif
2238 
2239  return SUCCESS;
2240 
2241 } /* ks_pg_isirot() */
KS_ISIROT::isinumber
int isinumber

◆ ks_pg_epi_dephasers()

STATUS ks_pg_epi_dephasers ( KS_EPI *  epi,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places out the dephasing gradients of a KS_EPI object (used by ks_pg_epi())

This function is called internally by ks_pg_epi() to place out the dephasing gradients of a KS_EPI object. See ks_pg_epi() for more details

For advanced usage of KS_EPI, it is possible to call ks_pg_epi_dephaser(), ks_pg_epi_echo() and ks_pg_epi_rephasers() separately instead of the single call to ks_pg_epi(). This allows the dephasing and rephasing gradients to be detached from the core EPI readout part

Parameters
[in,out]epiPointer to a KS_EPI sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when and where to place the dephasers of the KS_EPI object
[in]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_EPI
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
2247  {
2248  int readaxis, blipaxis, sliceaxis;
2249  KS_SEQLOC tmploc = KS_INIT_SEQLOC;
2250  int maxduration;
2251 
2252  if (!epi) { return FAILURE; }
2253 
2254  /* loc.ampscale may only be +1 or -1 and will control the read polarity.
2255  The blip polarity is controlled in run time with ks_scan_epi_shotcontrol() */
2256  if (loc.ampscale != 1.0 && loc.ampscale != -1.0) {
2257  return ks_error("ks_pg_epi_dephasers: loc.ampscale must be +1 or -1 (controls read polarity)");
2258  }
2259 
2260  loc.pos = RDN_GRD(loc.pos);
2261 
2262  switch (loc.board) {
2263  case KS_FREQX_PHASEY:
2264  readaxis = XGRAD; blipaxis = YGRAD; sliceaxis = ZGRAD; break;
2265  case KS_FREQY_PHASEX:
2266  readaxis = YGRAD; blipaxis = XGRAD; sliceaxis = ZGRAD; break;
2267  case KS_FREQX_PHASEZ:
2268  readaxis = XGRAD; blipaxis = ZGRAD; sliceaxis = YGRAD; break;
2269  case KS_FREQZ_PHASEX:
2270  readaxis = ZGRAD; blipaxis = XGRAD; sliceaxis = YGRAD; break;
2271  case KS_FREQY_PHASEZ:
2272  readaxis = YGRAD; blipaxis = ZGRAD; sliceaxis = XGRAD; break;
2273  case KS_FREQZ_PHASEY:
2274  readaxis = ZGRAD; blipaxis = YGRAD; sliceaxis = XGRAD; break;
2275  default:
2276  ks_error("ks_pg_epi_dephasers: loc.board is not valid: %d", loc.board);
2277  return FAILURE;
2278  }
2279 
2280  /* allocate time corresponding to the longest of the three, but push the dephasers to the right below */
2281  maxduration = IMax(3, epi->readphaser.duration, epi->blipphaser.grad.duration, epi->zphaser.grad.duration);
2282 
2283  /* read phaser (same KS_TRAP for DE/REphasing => 2 instances per EPI) */
2284  if (epi->readphaser.duration > 0) {
2285  tmploc.board = readaxis;
2286  tmploc.ampscale = loc.ampscale;
2287  tmploc.pos = loc.pos + maxduration - epi->readphaser.duration;
2288  if (ks_pg_trap(&epi->readphaser, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2289  return FAILURE;
2290  }
2291 
2292  /* blip phaser (same KS_PHASER for DE/REphasing => 2 instances per EPI) */
2293  if (epi->blipphaser.grad.duration > 0) {
2294  tmploc.board = blipaxis;
2295  tmploc.ampscale = 1.0;
2296  tmploc.pos = loc.pos + maxduration - epi->blipphaser.grad.duration;
2297  if (ks_pg_phaser(&epi->blipphaser, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2298  return FAILURE;
2299  }
2300 
2301  /* slice phaser (same KS_PHASER for DE/REphasing => 2 instances per EPI) */
2302  if (epi->zphaser.grad.duration > 0) {
2303  tmploc.board = sliceaxis;
2304  tmploc.ampscale = 1.0;
2305  tmploc.pos = loc.pos + maxduration - epi->zphaser.grad.duration;
2306  if (ks_pg_phaser(&epi->zphaser, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2307  return FAILURE;
2308  }
2309 
2310  return SUCCESS;
2311 } /* ks_pg_epi_dephasers */
ks_pg_phaser
STATUS ks_pg_phaser(KS_PHASER *phaser, KS_SEQLOC loc, KS_SEQ_CONTROL *ctrl)
Places a KS_PHASER sequence object on a board at some position in the pulse sequence

◆ ks_pg_epi_rephasers()

STATUS ks_pg_epi_rephasers ( KS_EPI *  epi,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places out the rephasing gradients of a KS_EPI object (used by ks_pg_epi())

This function is called internally by ks_pg_epi() to place out the rephasing gradients of a KS_EPI object. See ks_pg_epi() for more details

For advanced usage of KS_EPI, it is possible to call ks_pg_epi_dephaser(), ks_pg_epi_echo() and ks_pg_epi_rephasers() separately instead of the single call to ks_pg_epi(). This allows the dephasing and rephasing gradients to be detached from the core EPI readout part

Parameters
[in,out]epiPointer to a KS_EPI sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when to place the rephasers of the KS_EPI object
[in]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_EPI
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
2316  {
2317  int readaxis, blipaxis, sliceaxis;
2318  KS_SEQLOC tmploc = KS_INIT_SEQLOC;
2319 
2320  if (!epi) { return FAILURE; }
2321 
2322  /* loc.ampscale may only be +1 or -1 and will control the read polarity.
2323  The blip polarity is controlled in run time with ks_scan_epi_shotcontrol() */
2324  if (loc.ampscale != 1.0 && loc.ampscale != -1.0) {
2325  return ks_error("ks_pg_epi_rephasers: loc.ampscale must be +1 or -1 (controls read polarity)");
2326  }
2327 
2328  loc.pos = RDN_GRD(loc.pos);
2329 
2330  switch (loc.board) {
2331  case KS_FREQX_PHASEY:
2332  readaxis = XGRAD; blipaxis = YGRAD; sliceaxis = ZGRAD; break;
2333  case KS_FREQY_PHASEX:
2334  readaxis = YGRAD; blipaxis = XGRAD; sliceaxis = ZGRAD; break;
2335  case KS_FREQX_PHASEZ:
2336  readaxis = XGRAD; blipaxis = ZGRAD; sliceaxis = YGRAD; break;
2337  case KS_FREQZ_PHASEX:
2338  readaxis = ZGRAD; blipaxis = XGRAD; sliceaxis = YGRAD; break;
2339  case KS_FREQY_PHASEZ:
2340  readaxis = YGRAD; blipaxis = ZGRAD; sliceaxis = XGRAD; break;
2341  case KS_FREQZ_PHASEY:
2342  readaxis = ZGRAD; blipaxis = YGRAD; sliceaxis = XGRAD; break;
2343  default:
2344  ks_error("ks_pg_epi_rephasers: loc.board is not valid: %d", loc.board);
2345  return FAILURE;
2346  }
2347 
2348  /* read phaser (same KS_TRAP for DE/REphasing => 2 instances per EPI) */
2349  if (epi->readphaser.duration > 0) {
2350  tmploc.board = readaxis;
2351  tmploc.pos = loc.pos;
2352  if (epi->etl % 2) /* same polarity of rephaser as dephaser if odd ETL */
2353  tmploc.ampscale = loc.ampscale;
2354  else
2355  tmploc.ampscale = -loc.ampscale;
2356  if (ks_pg_trap(&epi->readphaser, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2357  return FAILURE;
2358  }
2359 
2360  /* blip phaser (same KS_PHASER for DE/REphasing => 2 instances per EPI) */
2361  if (epi->blipphaser.grad.duration > 0) {
2362  tmploc.board = blipaxis;
2363  tmploc.pos = loc.pos;
2364  tmploc.ampscale = 1.0;
2365  if (ks_pg_phaser(&epi->blipphaser, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2366  return FAILURE;
2367  }
2368 
2369  /* slice phaser (same KS_PHASER for DE/REphasing => 2 instances per EPI) */
2370  if (epi->zphaser.grad.duration > 0) {
2371  tmploc.board = sliceaxis;
2372  tmploc.pos = loc.pos;
2373  tmploc.ampscale = 1.0;
2374  if (ks_pg_phaser(&epi->zphaser, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2375  return FAILURE;
2376  }
2377 
2378  return SUCCESS;
2379 } /* ks_pg_epi_rephasers */

◆ ks_pg_epi_echo()

STATUS ks_pg_epi_echo ( KS_EPI *  epi,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places out the core part a KS_EPI object (used by ks_pg_epi())

This function is called internally by ks_pg_epi() to place out the core part of a KS_EPI object. The core part is the EPI train without leading dephaser gradients or trailing rephaser gradients. See ks_pg_epi() for more details

For advanced usage of KS_EPI, it is possible to call ks_pg_epi_dephaser(), ks_pg_epi_echo() and ks_pg_epi_rephasers() separately instead of the single call to ks_pg_epi(). This allows the dephasing and rephasing gradients to be detached from the core EPI readout part

Parameters
[in,out]epiPointer to a KS_EPI sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when to place the core part of the KS_EPI object
[in]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_EPI
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
2384  {
2385  int readaxis, blipaxis;
2386  KS_SEQLOC readloc, bliploc;
2387  int i;
2388 
2389  if (!epi || !epi->read.grad.description) { return FAILURE; }
2390 
2391  /* loc.ampscale may only be +1 or -1 and will control the read polarity.</
2392  The blip polarity is controlled in run time with ks_scan_epi_shotcontrol() */
2393  if (loc.ampscale != 1.0 && loc.ampscale != -1.0) {
2394  return ks_error("ks_pg_epi_echo: loc.ampscale must be +1 or -1 (controls read polarity)");
2395  }
2396 
2397  loc.pos = RUP_GRD(loc.pos);
2398 
2399  readloc.pos = loc.pos;
2400 
2401  switch (loc.board) {
2402  case KS_FREQX_PHASEY:
2403  readaxis = XGRAD; blipaxis = YGRAD; break;
2404  case KS_FREQY_PHASEX:
2405  readaxis = YGRAD; blipaxis = XGRAD; break;
2406  case KS_FREQX_PHASEZ:
2407  readaxis = XGRAD; blipaxis = ZGRAD; break;
2408  case KS_FREQZ_PHASEX:
2409  readaxis = ZGRAD; blipaxis = XGRAD; break;
2410  case KS_FREQY_PHASEZ:
2411  readaxis = YGRAD; blipaxis = ZGRAD; break;
2412  case KS_FREQZ_PHASEY:
2413  readaxis = ZGRAD; blipaxis = YGRAD; break;
2414  default:
2415  ks_error("ks_pg_epi_echo: field 'board' in 2nd arg is not valid: %d", loc.board);
2416  return FAILURE;
2417  }
2418 
2419  if (fabs(loc.ampscale) != 1.0) {
2420  return ks_error("ks_pg_epi_echo: field 'ampscale' in 2nd arg must be +1 or -1 (controls read lobe polarity)");
2421  }
2422 
2423 
2424  for (i = 0; i < epi->etl; i++) {
2425 
2426  /* read trapezoid */
2427  readloc.board = readaxis;
2428  readloc.ampscale = (float) (i % 2) ? -loc.ampscale : loc.ampscale; /* +1 or -1 */
2429  if (ks_pg_readtrap(&epi->read, readloc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2430  return FAILURE;
2431 
2432  /* phase encoding blip */
2433  if (i < epi->etl - 1) {
2434  /* etl-1, since no blip after the last read lobe */
2435  bliploc.board = blipaxis;
2436  bliploc.pos = RUP_GRD(readloc.pos + epi->read.grad.duration - epi->blip.duration / 2 + epi->read_spacing / 2);
2437  bliploc.ampscale = 1.0;
2438  if (ks_pg_trap(&epi->blip, bliploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2439  return FAILURE;
2440  }
2441 
2442  /* read_spacing is additional gap between lobes (normally 0) */
2443  readloc.pos += RUP_GRD(epi->read.grad.duration + epi->read_spacing);
2444 
2445  } /* etl */
2446 
2447 
2448  return SUCCESS;
2449 
2450 } /* ks_pg_epi_echo */
KS_EPI::blip
KS_TRAP blip
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1687
KS_FREQX_PHASEY
Definition: KSFoundation.h:1738

int pos

◆ ks_pg_epi()

STATUS ks_pg_epi ( KS_EPI *  epi,
KS_SEQLOC  loc,
KS_SEQ_CONTROL *  ctrl 
)

Places out a KS_EPI object (EPI train including dephaser and rephaser gradients)

This function should be called in the @pg section to place out a KS_EPI sequence object that creates an EPI readout including dephaser and rephaser gradients. The moments of all trapezoids in the KS_EPI object sum to zero on the two axes the KS_EPI object is placed on. The KS_EPI object is to be placed on two out of three gradients, why special values for the field loc.board must be used. The value should state which logical board (X,Y or Z) that should be used for the readout lobes (FREQ) and which logical board (X, Y or Z) that should be used for the blips (PHASE). One example is KS_FREQX_PHASEY, which will put the EPI readout lobes on XGRAD and the phase encoding blips on YGRAD

The same KS_EPI object can be placed out 16 times per sequence. This limitation is due to the hard limitation on the number of echoes (i.e. different k-spaces per image plane and image volume) that can be acquired per scan. Each time an instance of the KS_EPI object is placed out using ks_pg_epi(), the second argument (the KS_SEQLOC struct) should be modified:

  • .board: Choose between KS_FREQX_PHASEY, KS_FREQY_PHASEX, KS_FREQX_PHASEZ, KS_FREQZ_PHASEX, KS_FREQY_PHASEZ, KS_FREQZ_PHASEY
  • .pos: Absolute time in [us] of the start of the first dephaser gradient
  • .ampscale: For KS_EPI objects, valid values are only +1.0 and -1.0, and this will control the polarity of the first readout gradient. This is rarely needed, and 1.0 should be the standard choice as this does only affect gradient delays and Nyquist ghosting, not the geometric distortion direction.

The sign of the EPI blips will control the direction of the geometric distortions, and this is not done via .ampscale but in run-time using ks_scan_epi_shotcontrol()

For advanced usage of KS_EPI, it is possible to call ks_pg_epi_dephaser(), ks_pg_epi_echo() and ks_pg_epi_rephasers() separately instead of the single call to ks_pg_epi(). This allows the dephasing and rephasing gradients to be detached from the core EPI readout part

Parameters
[in,out]epiPointer to a KS_EPI sequence object
[in]locKS_SEQLOC struct to specify when to place the core part of the KS_EPI object
[in]ctrlPointer to the KS_SEQ_CONTROL struct corresponding to the sequence module for this KS_EPI
Return values
STATUSSUCCESS or FAILURE
2455  {
2456  KS_SEQLOC tmploc = loc;
2457 
2458  /* loc.ampscale may only be +1 or -1 and will control the read polarity.
2459  The blip polarity is controlled in run time with ks_scan_epi_shotcontrol() */
2460  if (loc.ampscale != 1.0 && loc.ampscale != -1.0) {
2461  return ks_error("ks_pg_epi: loc.ampscale must be +1 or -1 (controls read polarity)");
2462  }
2463 
2464  if (ks_pg_epi_dephasers(epi, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2465  return FAILURE;
2466 
2467  tmploc.pos += IMax(3, epi->readphaser.duration, epi->blipphaser.grad.duration, epi->zphaser.grad.duration);
2468 
2469  if (ks_pg_epi_echo(epi, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE) /* main epi train (w/o DE/REphasers) */
2470  return FAILURE;
2471 
2472  tmploc.pos += epi->read.grad.duration * epi->etl;
2473  if (ks_pg_epi_rephasers(epi, tmploc, ctrl) == FAILURE)
2474  return FAILURE;
2475 
2476  return SUCCESS;
2477 } /* ks_pg_epi */
KS_PHASER::grad
KS_TRAP grad

◆ ks_mat4_multiply()

void ks_mat4_multiply ( KS_MAT4x4  lhs,
const KS_MAT4x4  rhs_left,
const KS_MAT4x4  rhs_right 
)

Multiplication of two 4x4 matrices

Matrix product: [rhs_left] * [rhs_right]

Parameters
[out]lhsMatrix product (KS_MAT4x4)
[in]rhs_leftLeft matrix (KS_MAT4x4)
[in]rhs_rightRight matrix (KS_MAT4x4)
Returns
void
2654  {
2655 
2656  /* Define local variables */
2657  int m, n, k;
2658  int msize = 4;
2659  KS_MAT4x4 Mtmp;
2660  double *ptr;
2661 
2662  if (lhs == rhs_left || lhs == rhs_right) { /* Check if output is equal to any input */
2663  ptr = Mtmp;
2664  } else {
2665  ptr = lhs;
2666  }
2667  for (k = 0; k < (msize * msize); k++) { /* Zero left-hand side*/
2668  ptr[k] = 0.0;
2669  }
2670 
2671  /* Multiply the matrices*/
2672  for (n = 0; n < msize; n++) {
2673  for (m = 0; m < msize; m++) {
2674  for (k = 0; k < msize; k++) {
2675  ptr[m + (n * msize)] += rhs_left[m + (k * msize)] * rhs_right[k + (n * msize)];
2676  }
2677  }
2678  }
2679 
2680  if (lhs == rhs_left || lhs == rhs_right ) { /* Write back (if needed) */
2681  for (k = 0; k < (msize * msize); k++) {
2682  lhs[k] = ptr[k];
2683  }
2684  }
2685 }
KS_MAT4x4
double KS_MAT4x4[16]
Definition: KSFoundation.h:182

◆ ks_mat4_invert()

void ks_mat4_invert ( KS_MAT4x4  lhs,
const KS_MAT4x4  rhs 
)

Inversion of a 4x4 matrix

4x4 matrix inversion (http://download.intel.com/design/PentiumIII/sml/24504301.pdf

Parameters
[out]lhsInverted matrix (KS_MAT4x4)
[in]rhsMatrix to be inverted (KS_MAT4x4)
Returns
void
2688  {
2689  double tmp[12]; /* temp array for pairs */
2690  double src[16]; /* array of transpose source rhsrix */
2691  double det; /* determinant */
2692  int i, j;
2693 
2694  /* transpose rhsrix */
2695  for (i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
2696  src[i] = rhs[i * 4];
2697  src[i + 4] = rhs[i * 4 + 1];
2698  src[i + 8] = rhs[i * 4 + 2];
2699  src[i + 12] = rhs[i * 4 + 3];
2700  }
2701 
2702  /* calculate pairs for first 8 elements (cofactors) */
2703  tmp[0] = src[10] * src[15];
2704  tmp[1] = src[11] * src[14];
2705  tmp[2] = src[9] * src[15];
2706  tmp[3] = src[11] * src[13];
2707  tmp[4] = src[9] * src[14];
2708  tmp[5] = src[10] * src[13];
2709  tmp[6] = src[8] * src[15];
2710  tmp[7] = src[11] * src[12];
2711  tmp[8] = src[8] * src[14];
2712  tmp[9] = src[10] * src[12];
2713  tmp[10] = src[8] * src[13];
2714  tmp[11] = src[9] * src[12];
2715 
2716  /* calculate first 8 elements (cofactors) */
2717  lhs[0] = tmp[0] * src[5] + tmp[3] * src[6] + tmp[4] * src[7];
2718  lhs[0] -= tmp[1] * src[5] + tmp[2] * src[6] + tmp[5] * src[7];
2719  lhs[1] = tmp[1] * src[4] + tmp[6] * src[6] + tmp[9] * src[7];
2720  lhs[1] -= tmp[0] * src[4] + tmp[7] * src[6] + tmp[8] * src[7];
2721  lhs[2] = tmp[2] * src[4] + tmp[7] * src[5] + tmp[10] * src[7];
2722  lhs[2] -= tmp[3] * src[4] + tmp[6] * src[5] + tmp[11] * src[7];
2723  lhs[3] = tmp[5] * src[4] + tmp[8] * src[5] + tmp[11] * src[6];
2724  lhs[3] -= tmp[4] * src[4] + tmp[9] * src[5] + tmp[10] * src[6];
2725  lhs[4] = tmp[1] * src[1] + tmp[2] * src[2] + tmp[5] * src[3];
2726  lhs[4] -= tmp[0] * src[1] + tmp[3] * src[2] + tmp[4] * src[3];
2727  lhs[5] = tmp[0] * src[0] + tmp[7] * src[2] + tmp[8] * src[3];
2728  lhs[5] -= tmp[1] * src[0] + tmp[6] * src[2] + tmp[9] * src[3];
2729  lhs[6] = tmp[3] * src[0] + tmp[6] * src[1] + tmp[11] * src[3];
2730  lhs[6] -= tmp[2] * src[0] + tmp[7] * src[1] + tmp[10] * src[3];
2731  lhs[7] = tmp[4] * src[0] + tmp[9] * src[1] + tmp[10] * src[2];
2732  lhs[7] -= tmp[5] * src[0] + tmp[8] * src[1] + tmp[11] * src[2];
2733 
2734  /* calculate pairs for second 8 elements (cofactors) */
2735  tmp[0] = src[2] * src[7];
2736  tmp[1] = src[3] * src[6];
2737  tmp[2] = src[1] * src[7];
2738  tmp[3] = src[3] * src[5];
2739  tmp[4] = src[1] * src[6];
2740  tmp[5] = src[2] * src[5];
2741  tmp[6] = src[0] * src[7];
2742  tmp[7] = src[3] * src[4];
2743  tmp[8] = src[0] * src[6];
2744  tmp[9] = src[2] * src[4];
2745  tmp[10] = src[0] * src[5];
2746  tmp[11] = src[1] * src[4];
2747 
2748  /* calculate second 8 elements (cofactors) */
2749  lhs[8] = tmp[0] * src[13] + tmp[3] * src[14] + tmp[4] * src[15];
2750  lhs[8] -= tmp[1] * src[13] + tmp[2] * src[14] + tmp[5] * src[15];
2751  lhs[9] = tmp[1] * src[12] + tmp[6] * src[14] + tmp[9] * src[15];
2752  lhs[9] -= tmp[0] * src[12] + tmp[7] * src[14] + tmp[8] * src[15];
2753  lhs[10] = tmp[2] * src[12] + tmp[7] * src[13] + tmp[10] * src[15];
2754  lhs[10] -= tmp[3] * src[12] + tmp[6] * src[13] + tmp[11] * src[15];
2755  lhs[11] = tmp[5] * src[12] + tmp[8] * src[13] + tmp[11] * src[14];
2756  lhs[11] -= tmp[4] * src[12] + tmp[9] * src[13] + tmp[10] * src[14];
2757  lhs[12] = tmp[2] * src[10] + tmp[5] * src[11] + tmp[1] * src[9];
2758  lhs[12] -= tmp[4] * src[11] + tmp[0] * src[9] + tmp[3] * src[10];
2759  lhs[13] = tmp[8] * src[11] + tmp[0] * src[8] + tmp[7] * src[10];
2760  lhs[13] -= tmp[6] * src[10] + tmp[9] * src[11] + tmp[1] * src[8];
2761  lhs[14] = tmp[6] * src[9] + tmp[11] * src[11] + tmp[3] * src[8];
2762  lhs[14] -= tmp[10] * src[11] + tmp[2] * src[8] + tmp[7] * src[9];
2763  lhs[15] = tmp[10] * src[10] + tmp[4] * src[8] + tmp[9] * src[9];
2764  lhs[15] -= tmp[8] * src[9] + tmp[11] * src[10] + tmp[5] * src[8];
2765 
2766  /* calculate determinant */
2767  det = src[0] * lhs[0] + src[1] * lhs[1] + src[2] * lhs[2] + src[3] * lhs[3];
2768 
2769  /* calculate rhsrix inverse */
2770  det = 1 / det;
2771  for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)
2772  lhs[j] *= det;
2773 }

◆ ks_mat4_setgeometry()

void ks_mat4_setgeometry ( KS_MAT4x4  lhs,
float  x,
float  y,
float  z,
float  xr,
float  yr,
float  zr 
)

Set geometry for KS_MAT4x4

Parameters
[out]lhsset matrix (KS_MAT4x4)
[in]xdisplacement (mm)
[in]ydisplacement (mm)
[in]zdisplacement (mm)
[in]xrrotation (deg)
[in]yrrotation (deg)
[in]zrrotation (deg)
Returns
void
2775  {
2776  double cosa;
2777  double sina;
2778  double cosb;
2779  double sinb;
2780  double cosg;
2781  double sing;
2782 
2783  ks_mat4_identity(lhs);
2784 
2785  xr *= PI / 180.0;
2786  yr *= PI / 180.0;
2787  zr *= PI / 180.0;
2788 
2789  /*
2790  Rotation matrices for positive counterclockwise angles about the positive
2791  coordinate axis for a right handed coordinate system:
2792 
2793  | 1 0 0 |
2794  R1(xr) = | 0 cos(xr) -sin(xr)|
2795  | 0 sin(xr) cos(xr)|
2796 
2797 
2798  | cos(yr) 0 sin(yr) |
2799  R2(yr) = | 0 1 0 |
2800  | -sin(yr) 0 cos(yr) |
2801 
2802  | cos(zr) -sin(zr) 0 |
2803  R3(zr) = | sin(zr) cos(zr) 0 |
2804  | 0 0 1 |
2805  */
2806 
2807  cosa = cos(xr);
2808  sina = sin(xr);
2809  cosb = cos(yr);
2810  sinb = sin(yr);
2811  cosg = cos(zr);
2812  sing = sin(zr);
2813 
2814  /* Rotations: R_z * R_y * R_x */
2815  lhs[ 0] = cosb * cosg;
2816  lhs[ 1] = sina * sinb * cosg - cosa * sing;
2817  lhs[ 2] = cosa * sinb * cosg + sina * sing;
2818  lhs[ 4] = cosb * sing;
2819  lhs[ 5] = sina * sinb * sing + cosa * cosg;
2820  lhs[ 6] = cosa * sinb * sing - sina * cosg;
2821  lhs[ 8] = -sinb;
2822  lhs[ 9] = sina * cosb;
2823  lhs[10] = cosa * cosb;
2824 
2825  /* Translations */
2826  lhs[ 3] = x;
2827  lhs[ 7] = y;
2828  lhs[11] = z;
2829 }
ks_mat4_identity
void ks_mat4_identity(KS_MAT4x4 m)
Creates a 4x4 identity matrix
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:2636

◆ ks_mat4_setrotation1axis()

void ks_mat4_setrotation1axis ( KS_MAT4x4  rhs,
float  rot,
char  axis 
)

Create a new 4x4 matrix with a rotation around a single axis

Parameters
[out]rhsRotation matrix (KS_MAT4x4)
[in]rotAmount of rotation around axis [degrees]
[in]axisOne of (include the quotes): 'x', 'y', 'z'
Returns
void
2833  {
2834  ks_mat4_identity(rhs);
2835 
2836  rot *= PI / 180.0; /* deg->rad */
2837 
2838  switch (axis) {
2839  case 'x':
2840  rhs[5] = cos(rot);
2841  rhs[6] = sin(rot);
2842  rhs[9] = -sin(rot);
2843  rhs[10] = cos(rot);
2844  break;
2845  case 'y':
2846  rhs[0] = cos(rot);
2847  rhs[2] = sin(rot);
2848  rhs[8] = -sin(rot);
2849  rhs[10] = cos(rot);
2850  break;
2851  case 'z':
2852  rhs[0] = cos(rot);
2853  rhs[1] = sin(rot);
2854  rhs[4] = -sin(rot);
2855  rhs[5] = cos(rot);
2856  break;
2857  }
2858 
2859 }

Creates a 4x4 identity matrix
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:2636

◆ ks_mat4_extractrotation()

Extract a 3x3 rotation matrix from a 4x4 transformation matrix

[in]MTransformation matrix (KS_MAT4x4), row major
Returns
void
2861  {
2862  int i, j;
2863  for (i = 0; i < 3; ++i) {
2864  for (j = 0; j < 3; ++j) {
2865  R[3 * i + j] = M[4 * i + j];
2866  }
2867  }
2868 }

2870  {

2872  for (i = 0; i < 3; ++i) {

◆ ks_mat3_multiply()

void ks_mat3_multiply ( KS_MAT3x3  lhs,
const KS_MAT3x3  rhs_left,
const KS_MAT3x3  rhs_right 
)

Multiplication of two 3x3 matrices

Matrix product: [rhs_left] * [rhs_right]

Parameters
[out]lhsMatrix product (KS_MAT3x3)
[in]rhs_leftLeft matrix (KS_MAT3x3)
[in]rhs_rightRight matrix (KS_MAT3x3)
Returns
void
2888  {
2889 
2890  /* TODO: add checks for overlapping arrays */
2891 
2892  int i, j, k;
2893  for (i = 0; i < 3; ++i) {
2894  for (j = 0; j < 3; ++j) {
2895  double acc = 0;
2896  for (k = 0; k < 3; ++k) {
2897  acc += rhs_left[3 * i + k] * rhs_right[3 * k + j];
2898  }
2899  lhs[3 * i + j] = acc;
2900  }
2901  }
2902 }

◆ ks_mat3_print()

void ks_mat3_print ( const KS_MAT3x3  m)

Prints a 3x3 matrix to stdout

Parameters
[in]mMatrix (KS_MAT3x3)
Returns
void
2904  {
2905  int i;
2906  for (i = 0; i < 3; ++i) {
2907  fprintf(stderr, "|%.2f,\t%.2f\t%.2f|\n", m[3 * i], m[3 * i + 1], m[3 * i + 2]);
2908  }
2909  fprintf(stderr, "\n");
2910 }

◆ ks_mat3_apply()

void ks_mat3_apply ( double *  w,
const KS_MAT3x3  R,
const double *  v 
)

Rotate a 3x1 vector by a 3x3 rotation matrix (alibi)

Apply an active (alibi) rotation – i.e w = R * v

Parameters
[out]wOutput vector (float array with 3 elements)
[in]RRotation matrix (KS_MAT3x3)
[in]vInput vector (float array with 3 elements)
Returns
void
2912  {
2913  int i, j;
2914  for (i = 0; i < 3; ++i) {
2915  double acc = 0;
2916  for (j = 0; j < 3; ++j) {
2917  acc += R[3 * i + j] * v[j];
2918  }
2919  w[i] = acc;
2920  }
2921 }

◆ ks_mat3_invapply()

void ks_mat3_invapply ( double *  w,
const KS_MAT3x3  R,
const double *  v 
)

Rotate a 3x1 vector by the inverse of 3x3 rotation matrix (alias)

Apply a passive (alias) rotation – i.e w = R' * v = R^-1 * v

Parameters
[out]wOutput vector (float array with 3 elements)
[in]RRotation matrix (KS_MAT3x3)
[in]vInput vector (float array with 3 elements)
Returns
void
2923  {
2924  int i, j;
2925  for (i = 0; i < 3; ++i) {
2926  double acc = 0;
2927  for (j = 0; j < 3; ++j) {
2928  acc += v[j] * R[3 * j + i];
2929  }
2930  w[i] = acc;
2931  }
2932 }

◆ ks_scan_update_slice_location()

void ks_scan_update_slice_location ( SCAN_INFO *  new_loc,
const SCAN_INFO  orig_loc,
const KS_MAT4x4  M_physical,
const KS_MAT4x4  M_logical 
)

Updates a SCAN_INFO struct using physical and logical 4x4 transformation matrices

Updates the slice location – e.g for motion correction (physical space) or propeller rotations (logical space)

M_physical and M_logical are row-major 4x4 matricies that describe rotations (R_physical, R_logical) and translations (T_physical, T_logical) of the FOV in the physical and logical coordinate systems, respectively. If R_slice and T_slice describe the position of the prescribed FOV contained in orig_loc then new_loc will describe the overall rotation R_new and translation T_new of the FOV such that:

R_new = R_physical * R_slice * R_logical

T_new = R_logical^-1 * (R_slice^-1 * R_physical^-1 * T_physical + T_slice + T_logical)

NOTE: All transformations are expected to be active (alibi) that denote a change of position/orientation, not passive (alias) that denote a change of coordinates system. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_and_passive_transformation

SCAN_INFO is defined in $ESE_TOP/psd/include/epic_geometry_types.h and the global scan_info variable is an array of SCAN_INFO structs holding information of the graphically prescribed slices

Parameters
[out]new_locPointer to a SCAN_INFO struct holding the new slice information
[in]orig_locSCAN_INFO struct holding the original slice information
[in]M_physicalTransformation matrix (4x4) in the physical space
[in]M_logicalTransformation matrix (4x4) in the logical (i.e. XGRAD, YGRAD, ZGRAD) space
Returns
void
927  {
928  int i;
929  KS_MAT3x3 R_m;
930  KS_MAT3x3 R_l;
931  KS_MAT3x3 R_ms;
932  KS_MAT3x3 R_msl;
933 
934  const double T_s[3] = {orig_loc.oprloc, orig_loc.opphasoff, orig_loc.optloc};
935  double T_m[3];
936  double T_l[3];
937  double T_msl[3];
938  double T_new[3];
939 
940  /* initialize to identity matrix (will be used if NULL in 3rd or 4th arg) */
941  KS_MAT4x4 Mphys = KS_MAT4x4_IDENTITY;
942  KS_MAT4x4 Mlog = KS_MAT4x4_IDENTITY;
943 
944  /* copy slice rotation and translation */
945  KS_MAT3x3 R_s;
946  for (i = 0; i < 9; i++) {
947  R_s[i] = orig_loc.oprot[i];
948  }
949 
950  /* copy transformation matrices (if they are not NULL) to local matrices */
951  if (M_physical != NULL) {
952  memcpy(Mphys, M_physical, sizeof(KS_MAT4x4));
953  }
954  if (M_logical != NULL) {
955  memcpy(Mlog, M_logical, sizeof(KS_MAT4x4));
956  }
957 
958  ks_mat4_extractrotation(R_m, Mphys);
959  ks_mat4_extractrotation(R_l, Mlog);
960 
961  ks_mat4_extracttranslation(T_m, Mphys);
962  ks_mat4_extracttranslation(T_l, Mlog);
963 
964  /* R_ms = R_m * R_s */
965  ks_mat3_multiply(R_ms, R_m, R_s);
966 
967  /* R_ms^-1 * T_m = T_m' * R_ms' */
968  ks_mat3_invapply(T_msl, R_ms, T_m);
969 
970  for (i = 0; i < 3; ++i) {
971  T_msl[i] += T_s[i] + T_l[i];
972  }
973 
974  ks_mat3_invapply(T_new, R_l, T_msl);
975  new_loc->oprloc = T_new[0];
976  new_loc->opphasoff = T_new[1];
977  new_loc->optloc = T_new[2];
978 
979  ks_mat3_multiply(R_msl, R_ms, R_l);
980  for (i=0; i<9; ++i) {
981  new_loc->oprot[i] = R_msl[i];
982  }
983 } /* ks_scan_update_slice_location */
ks_mat3_multiply
void ks_mat3_multiply(KS_MAT3x3 lhs, const KS_MAT3x3 rhs_left, const KS_MAT3x3 rhs_right)
Multiplication of two 3x3 matrices
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:2888
KS_MAT4x4
double KS_MAT4x4[16]
Definition: KSFoundation.h:182
ks_mat4_extractrotation
void ks_mat4_extractrotation(KS_MAT3x3 R, const KS_MAT4x4 M)
Extract a 3x3 rotation matrix from a 4x4 transformation matrix
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:2861
KS_MAT3x3
double KS_MAT3x3[9]
Definition: KSFoundation.h:181
KS_MAT4x4_IDENTITY
#define KS_MAT4x4_IDENTITY
Definition: KSFoundation.h:173
ks_mat4_extracttranslation
void ks_mat4_extracttranslation(double *T, const KS_MAT4x4 M)
Extract a 3 element array with translations from a 4x4 transformation matrix
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:2870
ks_mat3_invapply
void ks_mat3_invapply(double *w, const KS_MAT3x3 R, const double *v)
Rotate a 3x1 vector by the inverse of 3x3 rotation matrix (alias)
Definition: KSFoundation_common.c:2923

◆ ks_scan_rotate()

void ks_scan_rotate ( SCAN_INFO  slice_info)

Performs a rotation of the logical system on hardware (WARP)

The field .oprot (9-element array) in the SCAN_INFO struct holds the rotation matrix that should be played out

This function performs the necessary scaling of the rotation matrix using loggrd and phygrd and then calls setrotatearray(), which performs the actual rotation on hardware during the next SSI time.

See ks_scan_update_slice_location() for detail on how to create new SCAN_INFO structs in run-time

Parameters
[in]slice_infoSCAN_INFO struct holding new slice information
Returns
void
988  {
989 #ifdef IPG
990 
991  /* scale to long int rotation matrix (accounting for gradient scaling) */
992  scale(&slice_info.oprot, &rsprot[0], 1, &loggrd, &phygrd, 0);
993 
994  setrotatearray(1, rsprot[0]);
995 
996 #endif
997 }
phygrd
PHYS_GRAD phygrd
rsprot
long rsprot[DATA_ACQ_MAX][9]
loggrd
LOG_GRAD loggrd

◆ ks_scan_isirotate()

void ks_scan_isirotate ( KS_ISIROT *  isirot)

Performs an immediate rotation of the logical system on hardware (WARP)

This function needs a psd-specific wrapper function to execute (see ks_pg_isirot()) since the ISI interupt routine is calling a void function without input arguments. This psd-specific wrapper function should only contain the call to ks_scan_isirotate() with the psd-specific KS_ISIROT set up in pulsegen().

For N number of calls to ks_pg_isirot() in the sequence module's pg-function, the field isirot.numinstances will be set to N, and this many ISI interrupt with a corresponding isirot.isinumber exist in the sequence module. Valid ISI numbers are 4-7, and one available number should be linked to one specific wrapper function using ks_eval_isirot() and ks_pg_isirot().

In real-time, ks_scan_isirotate() will increment the isirot.counter field by 1 and restart at 0 after isirot->numinstances. isirot.counter is set to 0 in ks_pg_isirot(). Based on the value of the .counter field, it will assign a pre-stored SCAN_INFO struct corresponding to this counter value. Again, this connection is done by ks_pg_isirot().

ks_scan_isirotate() takes the current SCAN_INFO and converts it to long int, and then calls setrotateimm(..., WARP_UPDATE_ON_SSP_INT);

Parameters
[in]isirotPointer to the KS_ISIROT struct set up by ks_pg_isirot()
Returns
void
1001  {
1002 #ifdef IPG
1003 
1004  if (isirot == NULL || isirot->numinstances < 1)
1005  return;
1006 
1007  /* wrap around after numinstances interupts */
1008  isirot->counter = isirot->counter % isirot->numinstances;
1009 
1010  /* scale to long int rotation matrix (accounting for gradient scaling) */
1011  scale(&isirot->scan_info[isirot->counter++].oprot, &rsprot[0], 1, &loggrd, &phygrd, 0);
1012 
1013  /* rotate on SSP interrupt */
1014  setrotateimm(rsprot[0], WARP_UPDATE_ON_SSP_INT);
1015 
1016 #endif
1017 }
KS_ISIROT::scan_info
SCAN_INFO * scan_info
Definition: KSFoundation.h:324
phygrd
PHYS_GRAD phygrd
rsprot
long rsprot[DATA_ACQ_MAX][9]
loggrd
LOG_GRAD loggrd
KS_ISIROT::counter
int counter
Definition: KSFoundation.h:327
KS_ISIROT::numinstances
int numinstances
Definition: KSFoundation.h:328

◆ ks_pg_fse_flip_angle_taperoff()

STATUS ks_pg_fse_flip_angle_taperoff ( double *  flip_angles,
int  etl,
double  flip1,
double  flip2,
double  flip3,
double  target_flip,
int  start_middle 
)
2518  {
2519 
2520  int i;
2521 
2522  flip_angles[0] = flip1;
2523  flip_angles[1] = flip2;
2524  for (i = 2; i < etl; i++) {
2525  flip_angles[i] = flip3;
2526  }
2527 
2528  if (flip3 <= target_flip || etl < 5) {
2529  /* flip3 must be larger than target_flip and etl must be larger than 4 */
2530  return SUCCESS;
2531  }
2532 
2533  /* after half of the echo train or third pulse, ramp down flip angles to last_flip */
2534  double first_flip = flip3;
2535  double last_flip = target_flip;
2536  int start_pulse = start_middle ? etl/2 : 2;
2537  for (i = start_pulse; i < etl; i++) {
2538  flip_angles[i] = first_flip + (((last_flip - first_flip)/(etl - start_pulse - 1)) * (i - start_pulse));
2539  }
2540 
2541  return SUCCESS;
2542 
2543 } /* ks_pg_fse_flip_angle_taperoff */

◆ ks_pg_mod_fse_rfpulse_structs()

void ks_pg_mod_fse_rfpulse_structs ( KS_SELRF *  rf1,
KS_SELRF *  rf2,
KS_SELRF *  rf3,
const double *  flip_angles,
const int  etl 
)
2483  {
2484 
2485  float SAR_scale_1 = 0.0;
2486  float SAR_scale_2 = 0.0;
2487  float SAR_scale_3 = 0.0;
2488  int i;
2489 
2490  SAR_scale_1 = pow(flip_angles[0] / rf1->rf.flip, 2.0);
2491  SAR_scale_2 = pow(flip_angles[1] / rf2->rf.flip, 2.0);
2492  for (i = 2; i < etl; i++) {
2493  SAR_scale_3 += pow(flip_angles[i] / rf3->rf.flip, 2.0);
2494  }
2495  SAR_scale_3 /= etl - 2;
2496 
2497  rf1->rf.rfpulse.effwidth *= SAR_scale_1;
2498  rf1->rf.rfpulse.max_rms_b1 *= sqrt(SAR_scale_1);
2499  rf1->rf.rfpulse.abswidth *= sqrt(SAR_scale_1);
2500 
2501  rf2->rf.rfpulse.effwidth *= SAR_scale_2;
2502  rf2->rf.rfpulse.max_rms_b1 *= sqrt(SAR_scale_2);
2503  rf2->rf.rfpulse.abswidth *= sqrt(SAR_scale_2);
2504 
2505  rf3->rf.rfpulse.effwidth *= SAR_scale_3;
2506  rf3->rf.rfpulse.max_rms_b1 *= sqrt(SAR_scale_3);
2507  rf3->rf.rfpulse.abswidth *= sqrt(SAR_scale_3);
2508 
2509 } /* ks_pg_mod_fse_rfpulse_structs */
KS_RF::rfpulse
RF_PULSE rfpulse
Definition: KSFoundation.h:797

float flip

◆ ks_instancereset_trap()

void ks_instancereset_trap ( KS_TRAP *  trap)

Resets the usage counters on TGT for a KS_TRAP sequence object (advanced use)

This function is for advanced use where a single sequence generating function is used in parallel in multiple sequences (i.e. in different SEQLENGTH()). This should be called after calling ks_copy_and_reset_obj()

The function sets .base.ngenerated to 0 (counter for number of times placed out on TGT), and sets .wfpulse and .wfi to NULL to trigger the allocation of new hardware memory, before running the sequence generating function again.

Parameters
[in,out]trapPointer to a KS_TRAP sequence object
Returns
void
2548  {
2549  if (!trap) { return; }
2550 
2551  trap->base.ngenerated = 0;
2552  trap->wfpulse = NULL;
2553  trap->wfi = NULL;
2554 }
KS_TRAP::base
KS_BASE base
Definition: KSFoundation.h:431

◆ ks_compare_wfi_by_timeboard()

int ks_compare_wfi_by_timeboard ( const KS_WFINSTANCE *  a,
const KS_WFINSTANCE *  b 
)

Compares two WF_INSTANCEs by time, then board

This function is used by the qsort() routine in ks_compare_wfi_by_timeboard()

If two WF_INSTANCEs occur at the same time, XGRAD will come before YGRAD and YGRAD before ZGRAD

Parameters
[in]aPointer to the first KS_WFINSTANCE
[in]bPointer to the second KS_WFINSTANCE
Return values
valueLarger or less than 0 depending on sorting order
2937  {
2938 
2939  return (a->loc.pos > b->loc.pos) - (a->loc.pos < b->loc.pos) +
2940  (a->loc.pos == b->loc.pos) * ((a->loc.board > b->loc.board) - (a->loc.board < b->loc.board));
2941 }
KS_SEQLOC::pos
int pos
Definition: KSFoundation.h:242
KS_SEQLOC::board
int board
Definition: KSFoundation.h:241
KS_WFINSTANCE::loc
KS_SEQLOC loc
Definition: KSFoundation.h:253

◆ ks_compare_wfi_by_boardtime()

int ks_compare_wfi_by_boardtime ( const KS_WFINSTANCE *  a,
const KS_WFINSTANCE *  b 
)

Compares two WF_INSTANCES by board, then time

This function is used by the qsort() routine in ks_compare_wfi_by_boardtime()

WF_INSTANCEs are sorted first by board. If two WF_INSTANCEs occur on the same board, t they will be sorted in time

Parameters
[in]aPointer to the first KS_WFINSTANCE
[in]bPointer to the second KS_WFINSTANCE
Return values
valueLarger or less than 0 depending on sorting order
2944  {
2945 
2946  return (a->loc.board > b->loc.board) - (a->loc.board < b->loc.board) +
2947  (a->loc.board == b->loc.board) * ((a->loc.pos > b->loc.pos) - (a->loc.pos < b->loc.pos));
2948 }
KS_SEQLOC::pos
int pos
Definition: KSFoundation.h:242
KS_SEQLOC::board
int board
Definition: KSFoundation.h:241
KS_WFINSTANCE::loc
KS_SEQLOC loc
Definition: KSFoundation.h:253

◆ ks_compare_wfp_by_time()

int ks_compare_wfp_by_time ( const WF_PULSE *  a,
const WF_PULSE *  b 
)

Compares two WF_PULSES in time

This function is used by the qsort() routine in ks_sort_wfp_by_time(), which is called from ks_pg_read() for data acquisition sorting purposes. It is assumed both WF_PULSEs have only one instance

Parameters
[in]aPointer to the first WF_PULSE
[in]bPointer to the second WF_PULSE
Return values
valueLarger or less than 0 depending on sorting order
2950  {
2951 
2952  return (a->inst_hdr_head->start > b->inst_hdr_head->start) - (a->inst_hdr_head->start < b->inst_hdr_head->start);
2953 }

)

valueLarger or less than 0 depending on sorting order
2980  {
2981  const int i1 = **(const int **) v1;
2982  const int i2 = **(const int **) v2;
2983 
2984  return i1 < i2 ? -1 : (i1 > i2);
2985 }

◆ ks_sort_getsortedindx()

void ks_sort_getsortedindx ( int *  sortedindx,
int *  array,
int  n 
)

Sort an array of integers (int)

Parameters
[out]sortedindxArray of indices into the array to make it sorted
[in,out]arrayArray to be sorted
[in]nNumber of elements in array
Returns
void
3021  {
3022  int i;
3023  int *parray[n];
3024 
3025  for (i = 0; i < n; i++)
3026  parray[i] = &array[i];
3027 
3028  qsort(parray, n, sizeof * parray, ks_compare_pint);
3029 
3030  for (i = 0; i < n; i++)
3031  sortedindx[i] = parray[i] - array;
3032 
3033 }

3903  return;

3916  /* Reset file */

3918  fprintf(fp,
3919  "{\n"

3921  "\t\"psdname\": \"%s\",\n"

)
3984  {

3986  return;
3987  }
3988  static FILE *fp;
3989  int i;
3990  char excmode_str[50];
3991  char fname[1000];
3992 
3993  ks_plot_host_slicetime_fullfile(fname);
3994  switch (excmode) {
3995  case KS_PLOT_STANDARD: strcpy(excmode_str, "KS_PLOT_STANDARD"); break;
3996  case KS_PLOT_NO_EXCITATION: strcpy(excmode_str, "KS_PLOT_NO_EXCITATION"); break;
3997  }
3998 
3999  if (ctrl->duration > 0) {
4000  fp = fopen(fname, "r+");
4001  if (fp == NULL) {return;}
4002  fseek(fp, 0, SEEK_END);
4003  /* fputs(" {\n", fp); */
4004  fprintf(fp,
4005  "{\n"
4006  "\t\t\"description\": \"%s\",\n"
4007  "\t\t\"excitationmode\": \"%s\",\n"
4008  "\t\t\"duration\": %0.3f,\n"
4009  "\t\t\"nseqinstances\": %d,\n"

4011  "\t\t\"numrf\": %d,\n"
4012  "\t\t\"numtrap\": %d,\n"

4017  ctrl->description, excmode_str, ctrl->duration / 1000.00, ctrl->nseqinstances , ctrl->min_duration / 1000.00, ctrl->gradrf.numrf, ctrl->gradrf.numtrap, ctrl->gradrf.numwave, ctrl->gradrf.numacq, slthick_mm);
4018 
4019  /* SMS slice locations */
4020  for (i = 0; i < (nslices - 1); i++) {
4021  fprintf(fp, "%0.3f, ", slicepos_mm == NULL ? 0.0 : slicepos_mm[i]);
4022  }
4023  fprintf(fp, "%0.3f]\n\t},", slicepos_mm == NULL ? 0.0 : slicepos_mm[nslices - 1]);
4024  fflush(fp);
4025  fclose(fp);
4026  }
4027 
4028 }
